f130339c-96c0-43b4-be65-ab8fb6532ad6.question: A junior orthopaedic surgery resident is completing a carpal tunnel repair with the department chairman as the attending physician. During the procedure, the resident inadvertently cuts a flexor tendon, which is subsequently repaired without complication. The attending advises the resident not to report this complication in the operative report, stating that disclosure may unnecessarily worry the patient. What is the appropriate next action for the resident to take in this situation?
f130339c-96c0-43b4-be65-ab8fb6532ad6.correct_answer: Tell the attending that he cannot fail to disclose this mistake

e9f93fa5-9e2d-47f0-b9b4-5e2de17102b2.question: A 67-year-old man with transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of ringing sensation in his ear. He received his first course of neoadjuvant chemotherapy 1 week ago. Pure tone audiometry shows a sensorineural hearing loss of 45 dB. What mechanism of action is responsible for the therapeutic benefit of the chemotherapeutic agent most likely causing this patient's symptoms?

6efd3408-90b3-4229-9081-367303c77149.question: A 61-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus and osteoarthritis presents with decreased urinary output and malaise two weeks after undergoing emergency cardiac catheterization with stenting for unstable angina. His medications include insulin, naproxen, aspirin, clopidogrel, and metoprolol. Vital signs show a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F), pulse 93/min, and blood pressure 125/85 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals mottled, reticulated purplish discoloration of the feet. Laboratory studies demonstrate leukocytosis with eosinophilia, elevated serum urea nitrogen and creatinine, and a renal biopsy showing intravascular spindle-shaped vacuoles. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?

3b35c432-192b-45db-acb4-67120e2da365.question: A 39-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with fevers, chills, and left lower quadrant pain. Her vital signs show a temperature of 39.1°C (102.3°F), pulse 126/min, respirations 28/min, and blood pressure 80/50 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals blood oozing at an IV site, mucopurulent cervical discharge, and left adnexal tenderness. Laboratory results include a platelet count of 14,200/mm³, fibrinogen 83 mg/mL, D-dimer 965 ng/mL, and a positive phenol test identifying a phosphorylated N-acetylglucosamine dimer with six fatty acids. What Gram stain characteristics and colony morphology on MacConkey agar would most likely be observed in the organism causing this infection?
3b35c432-192b-45db-acb4-67120e2da365.correct_answer: Lactose-fermenting, gram-negative rods forming pink colonies on MacConkey agar

11269a15-8c31-4156-88a9-1f673521ce0a.question: A 35-year-old man presents with a one-week history of itchy, watery eyes and frequent sneezing, similar to an episode he experienced last spring. His medical history includes iron deficiency anemia and ankylosing spondylitis. Current medications are ferrous sulfate, artificial tear drops, and indomethacin. Vital signs are normal, and ocular examination reveals bilateral conjunctival injection with watery discharge, normal pupils, and unremarkable anterior chamber. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

569d61b9-8b92-4529-b51d-cf6729e866f6.question: A 39-year-old man presents to the emergency department with progressively worsening chest pain and nausea that began 30 minutes prior at a local bar. The pain radiates to the epigastric area. His medical history includes untreated hypertension for 5 years, a 5-year smoking habit of one pack daily, and recent cocaine abuse starting 2 weeks ago. On examination, he is diaphoretic and in marked distress. What should be the first step in managing this patient?

bb96c9ae-eaac-47f9-ad39-e86cd65ef1ea.question: A 68-year-old male with a history of diabetes and peripheral artery disease presents with right flank pain, abdominal tenderness, and right flank tenderness. His blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg, and an ultrasound reveals dilation of the right ureter and renal pelvis. What is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?

58fa6684-7813-4497-9738-401b71635da1.question: A 65-year-old man with hypertension and asthma is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after the onset of acute chest pain. His current medications include atorvastatin, lisinopril, and an albuterol inhaler. He appears pale and diaphoretic, with a pulse of 114/min and blood pressure of 130/88 mm Hg. An ECG reveals ST-segment depressions in leads II, III, and aVF, and laboratory studies show elevated serum troponin T. After treatment for acute coronary syndrome and percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty, echocardiography at discharge demonstrates a left ventricular ejection fraction of 58%. In addition to aspirin, what medication should be added to this patient's regimen at discharge?

5e4acfd9-16d0-4476-b22c-d6ec090a3090.question: A 37-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician requesting a new form of birth control. She has been using oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) for the past 8 years but wishes to switch to an intrauterine device (IUD). Her vital signs are blood pressure 118/78 mm Hg, pulse 73/min, respiratory rate 16/min, and she is afebrile. Physical examination is within normal limits. What specific past medical history finding would contraindicate the placement of a copper IUD in this patient?
5e4acfd9-16d0-4476-b22c-d6ec090a3090.correct_answer: Active or recurrent pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)

911243b6-0fc9-41d0-9be1-8d2725ef4430.question: A 23-year-old woman presents to the physician due to embarrassment about the appearance of her nails. She has no significant medical history and takes no medications. Physical examination reveals no acute distress. A photograph of her nails is provided. What additional clinical finding is most likely present in this patient?

5fd80a41-0bcd-43c4-a486-ab3eb512fdd6.question: A 24-year-old G2P1 woman at 39 weeks’ gestation presents to the emergency department complaining of painful contractions occurring every 10 minutes for the past 2 hours, consistent with latent labor. She reports no vaginal discharge, bleeding, or fluid leakage and is not taking medications. Her blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, heart rate is 86/min, and temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F). She has had minimal prenatal care and uses condoms inconsistently, with unknown sexually transmitted infection status. Following rapid screening tests, zidovudine is administered during delivery and to the infant to reduce transmission risk. What confirmatory test is most likely performed in the mother to definitively diagnose HIV infection?
5fd80a41-0bcd-43c4-a486-ab3eb512fdd6.correct_answer: It is an HIV-1/HIV2 antibody differentiation immunoassay

e7cd5543-1ba1-4cd1-aeae-eda03c74b192.question: A 72-year-old man presents with a 2-month history of fatigue, worsening abdominal pain, excessive night sweats, exertional dyspnea, and a 5.6-kg weight loss over 3 months. His medical history includes myocardial infarction, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, chronic bronchitis, and a 45-pack-year smoking history. Medications include insulin, aspirin, lisinopril, and albuterol. Physical examination reveals splenomegaly (6 cm below the left costal margin). Laboratory studies show hemoglobin 6.4 g/dL, normal mean corpuscular volume (85 μm³), leukopenia (5,200/mm³), thrombocytopenia (96,000/mm³), and bone marrow aspiration demonstrating extensive fibrosis with scattered plasma cells. A JAK2 assay is positive. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

46091a10-83cd-4ebb-b7b9-088b34590a4d.question: A 20-year-old man presents to the physician with worsening gait unsteadiness, bilateral hearing loss over the past month, and intermittent tingling sensations on both cheeks. He has no significant medical history or current medications. Audiometry reveals bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, and genetic testing identifies a mutation in a tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 22 that encodes merlin. Given these findings, which condition is this patient at increased risk of developing?

6b4cefbe-862e-4fa9-b22f-c7b96505906c.question: A 47-year-old executive schedules an appointment with his physician for a routine medical check-up. He currently has no complaints and claims to be “as fit as a fiddle.” The physical examination findings are unremarkable, except for a mid-systolic murmur heard in the 2nd left intercostal space that radiates to the carotids on auscultation. The physician instructs the patient to stand from a supine position with the stethoscope still placed on his chest. What physiological change in cardiac function would most likely occur as a result of this maneuver?
6b4cefbe-862e-4fa9-b22f-c7b96505906c.correct_answer: A reduction in diastolic filling time

f76933d6-b4d5-4c0e-8502-52ee85557294.question: A microbiologist is studying the emergence of a virulent strain of the virus. After a detailed study of the virus and its life cycle, he proposes a theory: Initially, a host cell is co-infected with two viruses from the same virus family. Within the host cell, concomitant production of various genome segments from both viruses occurs. Ultimately, the different genome segments from the viruses are packaged into a unique and novel virus particle. The newly formed virus particle is both stable and viable and is a new strain from the virus family that caused the outbreak of infection. Which virus is capable of undergoing this process?

e8e5349c-1f67-4fe9-9dd2-1479018d8d64.question: A 59-year-old overweight woman presents to the urgent care clinic with severe abdominal pain for the past 2 hours, accompanied by dull back pain, nausea, and vomiting. The pain is not related to food intake. Her medical history includes recurrent abdominal pain due to cholelithiasis, and her father died of abdominal cancer at age 60. Vital signs are temperature 37°C, respirations 15/min, pulse 67/min, blood pressure 122/98 mm Hg. Physical exam is unremarkable. Abdominal CT scan reveals a calcified mass near the gallbladder. What diagnosis should be excluded first in this patient?

aee853a6-8242-40f2-b46b-55e8224495f2.question: A 7-year-old boy with a history of asthma since age 3 presents for follow-up. His symptoms worsen during spring, particularly when exposed to pollen in his mother's garden, causing chest tightness and shortness of breath. An experimental therapy aimed at reducing his asthmatic attacks targets a mediator that promotes antibody class switching, thereby diminishing the exaggerated immune response to allergens. Which mediator is most likely being targeted in this experimental therapy?

e633ebb3-274d-4b2c-a80e-054a471464a0.question: A 3-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents after an episode of cyanosis and muscle hypotonia that resolved after 2 minutes. Diagnostic evaluation fails to discover an exact etiology of the boy's symptoms, and the episode is classified as a brief resolved unexplained event (BRUE). The pediatrician recruits 75 infants under 1 year of age with BRUE and 75 infants without BRUE of the same age, socioeconomic background, and family history of medical illness. She then compares the two groups regarding history of feeding problems and recent upper respiratory infection. What method did the pediatrician use to control confounding bias in this study?

63cbf4fa-ca32-439f-8278-2b4a3f9eae25.question: A 29-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to central chest pain over the past 3 days, described as sharp, severe, and constant, unrelated to exertion. The pain worsens when lying down, improves with leaning forward, and radiates to his shoulders and neck. He has no significant past medical history but reports smoking 10 cigarettes daily for 7 years and occasional alcohol use. Vital signs include blood pressure 110/70 mm Hg, regular radial pulse of 95/min, and temperature 37.3°C (99.1°F). Physical examination reveals a to-and-fro scratching sound over the left sternal border at end-expiration when leaning forward. Chest X-ray is normal, and ECG findings are consistent with pericarditis. What is the optimal therapeutic regimen for this patient?

a1148200-f9e2-43f6-8603-91e23872ad13.question: A 46-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of altered mental status. He was found on the floor in front of his apartment. He is somnolent but responsive when aroused. His pulse is 64/min, respiratory rate is 15/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. On physical examination, an alcoholic smell and slurred speech are noted. Neurological exam shows diminished deep tendon reflexes bilaterally and an ataxic gait. His pupils are normal. Blood alcohol concentration is 0.04%. An ECG shows no abnormalities. What is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

493f64b4-a366-41dd-9640-8c166ee308c2.question: A 77-year-old woman presents to the emergency room with complaints of fever, malaise, and night sweats. She recently noticed enlargement of her axillary lymph nodes, which she examines weekly. She has a remote history of breast cancer in her 60s treated with radiation and chemotherapy, a history of extensive travel to Africa, and a 30-pack-year smoking history. Physical exam reveals several palpable axillary lymph nodes and a large non-tender right axillary mass measuring 10 x 8 cm. Fine-needle aspiration shows centroblastic and immunoblastic cells, suspicious for diffuse large B-cell non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma. Based on her history and presentation, which risk factor is most likely responsible for her current condition?

80d681f2-68af-48f6-83eb-91d0cf9b2772.question: A 3-month-old infant is brought to her pediatrician due to coughing, difficulty breathing during feeding, lethargy, and listlessness. She was born via cesarean section to a G1P1 mother with no prior medical history, had a normal APGAR score, and has never exhibited cyanosis. Physical examination reveals a high-pitched holosystolic murmur best auscultated at the lower left sternal border. What genetic abnormality is most likely associated with this patient's clinical presentation?

dddb9be5-05d1-49c9-9908-65584a4718bf.question: A 30-year-old African American woman presents with a 3-day history of dry cough, chest discomfort, headaches, muscle aches, joint pain, fever, and chills. She reports hiking in Mississippi 10 days ago and has a history of asthma managed with an albuterol inhaler. Her mother has a lung disease treated with methotrexate. The patient smokes one pack of cigarettes daily. Vital signs reveal a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F), and physical examination shows bilateral wheezing. Laboratory studies and urinalysis are positive for polysaccharide antigen, while bronchoalveolar lavage with silver/PAS staining demonstrates macrophages containing a dimorphic fungus with septate hyphae. What is the most likely causative organism responsible for this patient's condition?

1cfacdc9-ac16-4d1d-9647-27cfcfd0b924.question:
A 62-year-old patient has been hospitalized for a week due to a stroke. One week into the hospitalization, he develops a fever and purulent cough. His vitals include: heart rate 88/min, respiratory rate 20/min, temperature 38.4°C (101.1°F), and blood pressure 110/85 mm Hg. On physical examination, he has basal crackles on the right side of the chest. Chest radiography shows a new consolidation on the same side. Complete blood count is as follows:  
Hemoglobin 16 mg/dL  
Hematocrit 50%  
Leukocyte count 8,900/mm³  
Neutrophils 72%  
Bands 4%  
Eosinophils 2%  
Basophils 0%  
Lymphocytes 17%  
Monocytes 5%  
Platelet count 280,000/mm³  
What is the most likely causal microorganism for this patient’s condition?

05962ccf-1b7c-4b4b-bb40-738984f74172.question: A 6-year-old boy with a history of asthma and eczema is brought to the emergency department with worsening wheezing and shortness of breath over the past day. He has missed his glucocorticoid and albuterol inhalers for a week. Initial vital signs include a pulse of 120/min, respirations of 40/min, and blood pressure of 100/80 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals expiratory and inspiratory wheezing, moderate intercostal and subcostal retractions, and a decreased inspiratory-to-expiratory ratio. After receiving nebulized albuterol, ipratropium, intravenous methylprednisolone, and magnesium sulfate, he becomes limp and lethargic. Repeat assessment shows a pulse of 150/min, respirations of 22/min, blood pressure of 100/70 mm Hg, and absent wheezing on lung auscultation. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

2aa081dd-8664-41d7-b010-329bc370ee20.question: A 5-year-old female suffers from recurrent infections by Aspergillus species, Pseudomonas species, and Staphylococcus aureus. Laboratory examination of the patient’s neutrophils reveals no reaction during the nitroblue tetrazolium test. What cellular process is most likely dysfunctional in this patient?

2154f5d8-d146-4c5d-99bf-18150696c111.question: A 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a ‘cough-like-a-seal bark’ and a high-pitched inspiratory noise audible without a stethoscope. His mother reports worsening cough over the last few hours. Vital signs include blood pressure of 118/78 mm Hg, pulse 90/min, respiratory rate 35/min, and temperature 38.3°C (101.1°F). Physical examination reveals respiratory distress with suprasternal and intercostal retractions, inspiratory stridor without wheezing, frequent barking cough, and hoarse voice. What radiographic finding is most likely to be seen on this patient’s chest X-ray?

daaf31ce-60d3-4dc2-9557-539d16e81eec.question: A 26-year-old woman presents to a gynecologist after a missed period and is diagnosed with pregnancy despite regularly taking oral contraceptives. She reports undergoing treatment for pulmonary tuberculosis with rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol for the past 2 months. What mechanism best explains the failure of oral contraceptives in this patient?
daaf31ce-60d3-4dc2-9557-539d16e81eec.correct_answer: Induction of CYP3A4 by rifampin leading to decreased serum levels of ethinylestradiol and progesterone

7b038894-0045-49bb-a088-d7e60457891c.question: A 4-year-old previously healthy boy presents with 4 days of intermittent vomiting and 5-6 daily loose stools. His mother noted bloody stools and decreased oral intake of food and water over the last 24 hours. He is normally in daycare but has been home for the past 3 days. On physical exam, his temperature is 102.2°F (39°C), blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 22/min, and O2 saturation is 99% on room air. He has dry mucous membranes. Abdominal exam reveals diffuse tenderness to palpation without rebound or guarding, no masses or hepatosplenomegaly, and hyperactive bowel sounds. Right lower quadrant ultrasound is negative for appendicitis. Stool is guaiac positive. After receiving 15mg/kg acetaminophen and fluids, he develops lower extremity weakness, tingling, 3/5 strength, and diminished patellar reflexes the next day. What cerebrospinal fluid finding is most likely present in this patient?
7b038894-0045-49bb-a088-d7e60457891c.correct_answer: Increased cerebrospinal fluid protein with normal cell count

a6507415-d165-4ab4-99d9-9b28531b7449.question: A 3-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician because of an inward turning of his left forefoot. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation by cesarean section due to breech presentation. The pregnancy was complicated by oligohydramnios. Examination reveals concavity of the medial border of the left foot with a skin crease just below the ball of the great toe, a convex lateral border of the foot, and a neutral heel position. Tickling the lateral border of the foot corrects the deformity. X-ray of the left foot demonstrates an increased angle between the 1st and 2nd metatarsal bones. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

ad0b7862-1f9e-4bed-8508-efed7beac17d.question: A 42-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of right upper abdominal pain and nausea. Her BMI is 34 kg/m², and she has a fever of 38.5°C (101.3°F). Physical examination reveals abdominal distension and right upper quadrant tenderness. Laboratory results include a leukocyte count of 14,000/mm³ and normal liver enzymes. Abdominal ultrasonography is inconclusive, but cholescintigraphy visualizes the intrahepatic bile ducts, hepatic ducts, common bile duct, and proximal small bowel. What is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

7cd2063f-0dcb-4605-a98e-4c52836797c1.question: A 72-year-old woman is admitted to the intensive care unit for shortness of breath and palpitations. Cardiac catheterization reveals measurements of left ventricular volume and pressure during the cardiac cycle, with her pressure-volume loop (gray) showing reduced filling capacity compared to a normal loop (black). Based on these findings, what is the most likely underlying cause of her symptoms?

69ecc2b1-56c6-4571-ad8c-850b34ffe327.question: A 22-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of fever, intermittent rigors, and night sweats. She also has a 1-month history of progressive fatigue. Five weeks ago, she was hospitalized and received intravenous antibiotics for treatment of bacterial meningitis while visiting relatives in Guatemala. Her temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), pulse is 130/min, and blood pressure is 105/70 mm Hg. Examination shows pallor and scattered petechiae and ecchymoses. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 9.0 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 1,100/mm³ with 30% segmented neutrophils, and a platelet count of 20,000/mm³. Blood cultures grow coagulase-negative staphylococci. Based on her clinical presentation and laboratory findings, which antibiotic was this patient most likely treated with during her hospitalization for bacterial meningitis?

0eae409e-8762-4fef-a27f-644ad64f4e35.question: An otherwise healthy 50-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of increasingly frequent episodes of upper abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and a 3.2-kg (7-lb) weight loss. Physical examination reveals bilateral pitting pedal edema. Endoscopy shows prominent rugae in the gastric fundus, and biopsy demonstrates parietal cell atrophy. What is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?

e879485e-630c-4d24-904a-093b7cc8700c.question: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department with unresponsiveness. He is a known IV drug user and attends a methadone clinic. Vital signs on arrival include a temperature of 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure of 97/48 mmHg, pulse of 140/min, respirations of 29/min, and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. Laboratory findings show hyperglycemia (589 mg/dL), hyperkalemia (6.3 mEq/L), and metabolic acidosis (HCO3- 17 mEq/L). After treatment, his glucose normalizes to 90 mg/dL and potassium decreases to 4.3 mEq/L, with improved vital signs. Based on the initial presentation, what is the most appropriate management for this patient?
e879485e-630c-4d24-904a-093b7cc8700c.correct_answer: Insulin, potassium, IV fluids, and glucose

c9454e63-7171-4143-929b-5b576b6b4ed1.question: A 67-year-old man with a 16-year history of arthritis presents with right knee swelling and pain, preceded by left knee swelling a few weeks earlier. He reports bilateral joint involvement causing difficulty walking, back pain that improves with rest, and persistent dandruff managed with specialized shampoos. Physical examination reveals nail pitting. What is the most likely diagnosis?

9ef28332-eb0f-463f-b24e-4f1b5cd071e5.question: A 65-year-old woman presents with weight loss and progressive weakness, particularly noticeable when climbing stairs or combing her hair. Her weakness temporarily improves after brief exercise. She also reports bladder incontinence over the past 4 weeks and showed no improvement with anticholinesterase therapy. What is the most likely underlying cause of these clinical findings?
9ef28332-eb0f-463f-b24e-4f1b5cd071e5.correct_answer: Paraneoplastic syndrome from small cell carcinoma of the lung

293ea876-c841-48b9-ac7d-10635f9f949d.question: A 3-month-old boy presents to his pediatrician with persistent diarrhea, oral candidiasis, and signs and symptoms suggestive of respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) pneumonia. His weight is in the 10th percentile. He is being evaluated for an immunodeficiency disease. Laboratory results for HIV are negative by PCR. What is the most likely cause of these findings in this patient?

efbc9159-d338-4ae6-af71-60ee99b06a10.question:
A 53-year-old man with recurrent pancreatic adenocarcinoma is enrolled in a clinical trial for a novel chemotherapeutic agent. The drug was previously tested in a small population and is now undergoing a phase 3 trial. The following dose-response and safety data were observed:  

**Dose-response results**:  
10 mg - 6/59 patients improved  
20 mg - 19/49 patients improved  
30 mg - 26/53 patients improved  
40 mg - 46/51 patients improved  

**Safety profile**:  
20 mg - 5/49 patients had adverse events  
40 mg - 11/51 patients had adverse events  
60 mg - 15/42 patients had adverse events  
80 mg - 23/47 patients had adverse events  
100 mg - 47/52 patients had adverse events  

Based on these results, calculate the most likely therapeutic index for this drug.

2b8afdd0-6f0d-46e2-8a4d-11c4161f163d.question: A 67-year-old male is seen by neurology after his family noticed abnormal speech patterns. Following acute treatment with tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), the patient regained most speech functions. Neurologic examination reveals fluent speech, intact comprehension of one- and two-step instructions, but persistent inability to perform verbal repetition tasks. Which brain structure's residual damage is most likely responsible for this patient's syndrome?

921e9bcd-9a1b-47b5-97a0-69bed161766c.question: A 27-year-old woman presents to the office with concerns about her long-standing struggle with body image since adolescence, including being targeted for her size. She reports severe inflammatory acne, unwanted facial hair on her upper lip, and dark coarse hairs on her back. Despite trying diet plans, exercise, and cosmetic products, her symptoms persist. She has a 45-day menstrual cycle and a family history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. A recent 2-hour oral glucose tolerance test showed a plasma glucose level of 160 mg/dL (8.9 mmol/L). Her height is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in), weight is 85 kg (187 lb), and vital signs are within normal limits. What is the most likely diagnosis?

857ea022-88be-4dd0-aba5-a7ebfdcfd05a.question: A 43-year-old man presents with tingling and numbness of the lower limbs for 2 weeks, along with persistent leg pain unrelieved by over-the-counter analgesics. His past medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus managed inconsistently with metformin and glimepiride for 2 years. Physical examination reveals decreased pain sensation in both lower limbs with intact deep tendon reflexes. Vital signs are blood pressure 122/84 mmHg, temperature 36.7°C (98.1°F), and respiratory rate 10/min. Ankle-brachial pressure index on the right side is 1.1. Laboratory results show fasting blood glucose of 141 mg/dL, 2-hour post-prandial glucose of 235 mg/dL, and HbA1c of 8.1%. What is the best measure to prevent the progression of this patient's symptoms?

f4b0e86b-903e-4303-8750-61bee8c8d631.question: A one-day-old male is evaluated in the hospital nursery for bilious vomiting. The patient has urinated multiple times since birth but has not yet passed meconium. He was born at 38 weeks gestation to a 36-year-old gravida 3 via vaginal delivery. The pregnancy was complicated by gestational diabetes. The patient’s mother received routine prenatal care and declined first trimester screening. She subsequently underwent a quadruple screen at 15 weeks gestation that demonstrated decreased maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), increased beta-hCG, decreased unconjugated estriol, and increased inhibin A. Her last ultrasound prior to onset of labor demonstrated an amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 28 cm. The patient’s two older siblings are both healthy. The patient’s temperature is 97.8°F (36.6°C), blood pressure is 58/37 mmHg, pulse is 166/min, and respirations are 38/min. On physical exam, the patient is in moderate distress. His abdomen is firm and distended with hypoactive bowel sounds. What is the most likely etiology of this infant’s clinical presentation?

1bcc1d12-da6a-414f-898f-a000dbe4f762.question: A healthy 23-year-old male is undergoing an exercise stress test as part of his physiology class. If blood were sampled at different locations before and after the stress test, which area of the body would contain the lowest oxygen content at both time points?

1d210ea3-3e5f-4bca-9fc0-60149346d81b.question: A 45-year-old G5P4105 presents to her gynecologist’s office with six months of increasingly heavy periods, now soaking one super absorbent tampon every two hours for five days each cycle. Her cycles have become irregular with intermenstrual bleeding for the last two months, and she experiences significant dysmenorrhea requiring 400 mg ibuprofen every four hours during menses. She reports new-onset mild dyspareunia, pelvic heaviness, and increased urinary frequency but denies bowel changes. Her history includes obesity, type II diabetes managed with metformin, and five spontaneous vaginal deliveries. Vital signs at the visit are temperature 98.5°F (36.9°C), blood pressure 137/84 mmHg, pulse 87/min, and respirations 14/min. What physical exam finding is most likely to be present in this patient?

f57da622-2a19-47da-b02f-440ebb563151.question: A man is brought into the emergency department by the police department. The officers state that the man has been arrested multiple times for public alcohol intoxication but recently became homeless. On exam, he is behaving erratically, appears confused, and has slurred speech. His vitals are within normal limits. Gait examination reveals ataxia and an inability to stand without support for more than a few seconds. Lab results are as follows: Na 140 mEq/L, K 4 mEq/L, Cl 106 mEq/L, BUN 8 mg/dL, Cr 2 mg/dL. Arterial blood gas shows pH 7.3, PaCO₂ 13 mmHg, PaO₂ 130 mmHg, and HCO₃⁻ 7 mEq/L. Blood salicylate levels are normal. What is the most appropriate immediate treatment for this patient?

5f194cde-4bdd-48d4-a56d-3447e3ac6e9f.question: A medical research study evaluated an investigational novel drug (medication 1) compared with standard therapy (medication 2) in 3,000 patients with myocardial infarction, with 1,500 subjects in each study arm. At 45 days post-MI, 134 patients in the medication 1 group and 210 patients in the medication 2 group experienced the primary endpoint of death from cardiac causes. What is the number needed to treat (NNT) for the primary endpoint? Round your answer to the nearest whole number.

0385def1-ccf9-4a0d-9d10-eda3ccf5d5c4.question: A 55-year-old man with an 8-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and a 34-year smoking history of two packs daily presents with a 6-week history of tingling pain in the sole of his right foot when raising it above chest level during exercise. He reports right calf cramping during treadmill incline use, relieved by rest. Vital signs include a blood pressure of 170/92 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals absent right pedal pulses, pallor and tingling pain in the right foot during straight leg raise, normal muscle strength, and no back pain. What is the most likely diagnosis?

93f80413-a499-403b-9143-c7c76016efb2.question: A 29-year-old primigravid woman at 35 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in labor. She has no history of serious medical illness and has had an uncomplicated pregnancy. Her last ultrasound at 22 weeks' gestation was normal. On admission, fetal heartbeats cannot be detected by fetal Doppler monitor. Ultrasound shows decreased amniotic fluid levels and no evidence of fetal movement, respiration, or heart activity. The patient gives birth to a 2296 g (5 lb 1 oz) male infant with no signs of life or visible malformations. The placenta appears unremarkable. What is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?

782744dd-c34b-4aec-b2aa-3d88756037ca.question: A 67-year-old man is hospitalized after several days of fever and increasing shortness of breath. Respiratory viral panel testing is positive for influenza A, and he is started on a standard five-day course of oseltamivir. Despite therapy, his shortness of breath worsens, requiring ICU transfer and intubation due to declining oxygen saturation. Chest radiograph reveals bilateral infiltrates consistent with Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS). After weeks of supportive therapy, his lung function improves to near-normal levels. What cellular process is primarily responsible for regenerating the alveolar lining following alveolar damage in this clinical scenario?

86be5a54-6462-4d7b-b317-7ae325f43608.question: A 65-year-old male is treated for anal carcinoma with therapy including external beam radiation. What is the primary mechanism by which the radiation affects the cancer cells?

96ace582-b6da-4636-ae50-b5cfe059c898.question: A 56-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents to his physician with progressive fatigue and new-onset muscle cramps. He has had no recent changes to his medication regimen, which includes hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, and amlodipine. His blood pressure is 174/111 mmHg, and laboratory studies reveal serum potassium of 3.3 mEq/L and bicarbonate of 33 mEq/L. What is the most likely underlying etiology of this patient's hypertension?

eaea8b54-e281-4561-a672-1275d16df268.question: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of yellowish discoloration of his skin and generalized pruritus. Examination shows jaundice of the skin and scleral icterus. Urinalysis shows an elevated concentration of bilirubin and a low concentration of urobilinogen. What is the most likely underlying pathophysiological mechanism responsible for these findings?

51e013ef-ebe3-42fe-8c2a-23e56a7c0a15.question: A 72-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter due to a 6-month history of worsening short-term memory deficits and social withdrawal. Treatment with galantamine is initiated. Two weeks later, she develops vomiting, mild crampy abdominal pain, and watery, nonbloody diarrhea. What is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy to address these new symptoms?

24d305d5-7709-43b6-8897-1958bd5871df.question: A 61-year-old man with schizophrenia residing in a locked inpatient psychiatry unit has been observed developing unusual smacking motions with his lips, pursing of the mouth, and excessive blinking over the past 2 weeks. These symptoms began gradually, have progressively worsened, and do not appear to distress him. He has been receiving haloperidol treatment for several months with successful management of his psychiatric condition. His physical examination and vital signs are unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis to explain these symptoms?

51c355d5-e531-4197-abcb-4ba0dfb9f4e0.question: A 17-year-old football player with no significant past medical, social, or family history presents to his pediatrician with itching in his groin that began during summer workouts. He reports no rash elsewhere on his body. Vital signs include a temperature of 38.1°C (98.7°F). Physical examination reveals a well-demarcated erythematous patch with peripheral scale on the left thigh, pubic region, and perineum, without scrotal involvement. What diagnostic method should be used to confirm the suspected condition?

db6b64aa-7279-4283-b804-21a6ba24b20b.question: An otherwise healthy 26-year-old man comes to the physician for medication counseling after recently being diagnosed with schizophrenia, and risperidone therapy is initiated. What adverse effect is this patient at increased risk for?

c8eed5a0-67ab-4049-a9d5-96192ad7059e.question: A 15-year-old woman presents with fever, altered mental status, and a petechial rash on her lower extremities and back since yesterday evening. She reports nausea and vomiting over the past 3 hours. The patient mentions heavy menstrual bleeding for the past few days. Her blood pressure is 95/80 mm Hg, temperature is 40.0°C (104.0°F), and she appears diaphoretic. Pelvic examination reveals a tampon in her vagina. Which specific region of the T cell receptor is primarily responsible for the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?
c8eed5a0-67ab-4049-a9d5-96192ad7059e.correct_answer: Variable β-sequence of the T cell receptor

97bf23cd-a3c7-4250-96ab-350dc9fb1a4c.question: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of pallor and increasing lethargy over the past 2 days. One week ago, he experienced abdominal pain, vomiting, and bloody diarrhea that have since resolved. The patient's father states they returned early from a 6-week road trip in Mexico due to these symptoms. The parents have administered oral rehydration therapy. Immunizations are up-to-date. The child appears pale, with a temperature of 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse 130/min, respirations 35/min, and blood pressure 95/50 mm Hg. Examination reveals scleral icterus, a soft and nontender abdomen without rebound or guarding, and hyperactive bowel sounds. Laboratory results include hemoglobin 8.5 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume 94 μm³, leukocyte count 18,000/mm³, platelet count 45,000/mm³, urea nitrogen 28 mg/dL, creatinine 1.6 mg/dL, total bilirubin 2.5 mg/dL (direct 0.1 mg/dL), lactate dehydrogenase 1658 U/L, and a blood smear showing schistocytes. What is the most likely diagnosis?

c76df36f-4465-4c35-9598-640a049e1b25.question: A 17-year-old girl is referred by her dentist for a suspected eating disorder. She has been visiting the same dentist since childhood and for the past 2 years has had at least 2 visits for dental caries. She eventually admitted to him that she regularly induces vomiting by putting her fingers down her throat. She says she has been doing this for the last few years and purging at least once a week. More recently, she has been inducing emesis more often and even looked into diuretics as she feels that she is gaining more and more weight compared to her ‘skinny friends’. Her BMI is at the 50th percentile for her age and sex. What is a key diagnostic feature of the classification of this patient’s eating disorder?
c76df36f-4465-4c35-9598-640a049e1b25.correct_answer: Patients with this disorder are not further sub-typed

ac051a28-b962-4f98-aec7-9239d7f25685.question: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her father due to fever, chills, abdominal pain, and profuse non-bloody diarrhea. Her symptoms began one week ago with several days of low-grade fever and constipation. She returned from Indonesia 2 weeks ago, where she spent the summer with her grandparents. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.8°F). Examination reveals diffuse abdominal tenderness, mild hepatosplenomegaly, and a faint salmon-colored maculopapular rash on her trunk and abdomen. What is the most likely causative organism responsible for this patient's condition?

d8e45d20-2e9c-405d-82f0-7354906f56e5.question: A 22-year-old female college student was treated with metronidazole for vaginal itching, discharge, and pain. Shortly after consuming alcohol at a party, she developed facial flushing, nausea, tachycardia, dyspnea, headache, and abdominal cramps. Which substance is most likely elevated in her serum following alcohol consumption?

7f70f2b5-d7d0-4bd8-8ba1-f922d90e34a0.question: A 23-year-old primigravida presents for a regular prenatal care visit at 16 weeks gestation. She complains of increased fatigability but is otherwise well. She takes folic acid, iron, and vitamin D supplementation. Her vital signs are blood pressure 110/70 mm Hg, heart rate 86/min, respiratory rate 13/min, and temperature 36.6℃ (97.9℉). Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory results include erythrocyte count 3.9 million/mm³, Hb 11.1 g/dL, HCT 32%, reticulocyte count 0.2%, MCV 90 fL, platelet count 210,000/mm³, and leukocyte count 8,100/mm³. What further testing is required to investigate the cause of the patient’s laboratory findings?

c8b87a64-5cdd-4756-8ee4-9847a295c305.question: An 80-year-old man is transferred from a step-down unit to a med-surg floor following successful hernia surgery 14 hours ago. He received preoperative atropine, scopolamine, and morphine and had an uncomplicated recovery in the PACU and step-down unit. On arrival to the med-surg floor, his vital signs include a temperature of 36.8°C (98.2°F), heart rate of 98/min, respiratory rate of 15/min, blood pressure of 100/75 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation of 90%. Physical exam reveals a well-developed, obese male with clear lungs, regular heart sounds, and a clean, intact surgical incision. The patient reports abdominal and pelvic discomfort, and records indicate he has not voided since before surgery. A bladder scan is inconclusive due to body habitus. What is the next best step in managing this patient?
c8b87a64-5cdd-4756-8ee4-9847a295c305.correct_answer: Insert a ‘straight cath’ into the patient’s bladder

1efa49d7-8483-47ff-a961-218ce82dc065.question: A healthy 19-year-old man presents to his primary care provider complaining of painless “blisters” in his mouth. He reports noticing a white film on his tongue and the sides of his mouth 2 days ago while brushing his teeth, which was easily brushed off. He also describes a bitter metallic taste but denies pain, burning, dysphagia, or hoarseness. He is otherwise healthy, takes no medications, is a competitive swimmer, and reports 8 sexual partners in the past year with intermittent barrier protection use. Oral examination reveals patches of white pseudomembranes that can be wiped away to expose erythematous mucosa. What mechanism of action would the most appropriate medication for this patient’s condition primarily target?

65aa5ae9-6d84-4db2-86d2-d4d82c721088.question: A 56-year-old man presents to the clinic complaining of subacute back pain for the past month. The pain is described as a dull, constant ache that is worse at night. He could not recall any precipitating event except for an amateur weight-lifting competition that he participated in 2 months ago. His past medical history is significant for non-small cell lung cancer that was diagnosed and successfully treated. A PET scan 1 year ago demonstrated no recurrence. Physical exam was unremarkable except for some point tenderness along the lumbosacral area. Based on this presentation, what is the most likely imaging finding in this patient?
65aa5ae9-6d84-4db2-86d2-d4d82c721088.correct_answer: Lytic lesions of the lumbar spine

5a0afc55-45fc-4459-8403-b1bd79f20a2b.question: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his 14-year-old brother due to severe abdominal pain, bilious vomiting for 6 hours, and absence of bowel movements for 24 hours. The child appears ill, with a temperature of 37.8°C (100°F), pulse of 122/min, abdominal distension, lower abdominal tenderness, guarding, rebound tenderness, and decreased bowel sounds. Abdominal x-ray reveals dilated bowel loops. The surgeon recommends an emergency laparotomy, but the parents are unavailable. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

ef01272c-b248-4813-aeab-887da83de959.question: A 3-week-old male newborn is brought to the hospital due to poor weight gain since birth. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation via normal vaginal delivery, weighing 3005 g (6 lb, 10 oz) at birth and currently 2835 g (6 lb, 4 oz). He has been latching and breastfeeding well since birth. His mother has a history of Graves' disease and underwent near-total thyroidectomy in the second trimester of pregnancy after antithyroid drugs failed to control her symptoms. She is currently on L-thyroxine therapy. The infant’s temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 176/min, and respirations are 42/min. He appears irritable, diaphoretic, with reduced subcutaneous fat and midline neck swelling. What is the most likely underlying cause of this infant’s clinical presentation?
ef01272c-b248-4813-aeab-887da83de959.correct_answer: Transplacental passage of TSH receptor antibodies

760c4285-62ba-415f-aa91-021f2b3f1588.question: A 57-year-old female with a history of alcoholism presents to the emergency room with hematemesis and a several-day history of melena. Vital signs on arrival include tachycardia and hypotension, and physical examination reveals splenomegaly and ascites. After stabilization and upper endoscopy confirming bleeding esophageal varices, she receives IV octreotide. Following resolution of the acute bleed, what pharmacologic agent is indicated for secondary prophylaxis in this patient?

8558104c-a1f2-4fc4-a14c-e0a1ffcca8c0.question: A 65-year-old man with a history of hypertension, obesity, and alcoholic cirrhosis is seen in clinic for follow-up. He reports feeling well and currently drinks 5 glasses of wine each night. His medications include atenolol and lisinopril. On physical exam, his temperature is 98.1°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 151/82 mmHg, pulse is 71/min, and respirations are 14/min. Spider angiomata are noted on his chest, but there is no asterixis, jaundice, ascites, or peripheral edema. Screening ultrasound reveals a new liver nodule, and follow-up CT demonstrates a 2 cm right hepatic lobe lesion with enhancement in the arterial phase but no hypodense attenuation on venous or delayed phases. Based on this presentation and imaging findings, what is the next step in management?

ae0e533e-0c5b-4bce-ad16-0f0d60a83b9b.question: A 66-year-old man with a history of alcoholic liver cirrhosis is brought to the emergency room due to abdominal distension and persistent somnolence over the past 2 weeks, with increased sleep over the last 5 days. His vital signs include a temperature of 38.0°C (100.4°F), and physical examination reveals altered mental status, abdominal shifting dullness, a positive fluid wave, hyperreflexia, and asterixis. Laboratory results show elevated ammonia levels (100 µg/dL), and imaging confirms cirrhosis with ascites but no other abnormalities. Upper GI endoscopy reveals gastric varices without active bleeding, and brain MRI is unremarkable. What is the most likely precipitating factor for this patient’s current condition?

4eaae63c-9b08-4a77-ab73-2331c5133581.question: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision where he was the unrestrained driver in a head-on collision. His ECG shows sinus tachycardia, and his vital signs include a temperature of 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure of 107/58 mmHg, pulse of 120/min, respirations of 17/min, and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. After receiving 2 liters of Ringer lactate solution and morphine, his pulmonary capillary wedge pressure and troponin levels are elevated. He complains of ongoing chest pain, and physical exam reveals bruising over the chest wall. What is the most likely diagnosis?

9628d804-b157-4f04-a059-96841c0861e1.question: A 56-year-old man presents to the emergency department with progressively worsening fatigue, malaise, fever, and abdominal pain for one week, accompanied by episodes of diarrhea. He recently started melatonin and magnesium supplements to improve sleep. His medical history includes alcohol use disorder with multiple hospital admissions for acute pancreatitis and cirrhosis, and he reports occasional intravenous heroin use. Vital signs include a temperature of 100°F (37.8°C), blood pressure 105/70 mmHg, pulse 92/min, and respirations 17/min. Physical examination reveals scleral icterus, hepatomegaly, ascites, and diffuse abdominal tenderness. Laboratory findings include leukocytosis and metabolic acidosis. Paracentesis shows ascitic fluid with 280 polymorphonuclear cells/mm³, a serum-ascites albumin gradient of 1.3 g/dL, and a positive Escherichia coli culture sensitive to cefotaxime and ceftriaxone. He is admitted and treated with intravenous cefotaxime and albumin. On hospital day 2, he develops oliguria despite constant fluid intake, with serum sodium of 131 mEq/L and creatinine rising from 0.9 mg/dL to 1.8 mg/dL. Urine studies show low sodium without blood or protein, and no new medications have been initiated. What is the best treatment option for this patient?

0ef6db63-4f32-4990-bfee-0ebdc202e643.question: A 29-year-old woman presents to the clinic after several months of unintentional weight loss (6.8 kg) without dietary or exercise changes. She reports feeling excessively warm, leading to disagreements about room temperature. Vital signs include tachycardia (110/min) and elevated blood pressure (146/78 mm Hg). Physical examination shows warm, moist skin and a fine hand tremor when her arms are outstretched. Urine pregnancy test is negative. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?

73c9a293-fbbf-499f-b06b-1c39fad9160d.question: A 21-year-old man presents with pruritus and a hypopigmented rash on his upper body that began 5 days after returning from a trip to the Bahamas, where he visited beaches and hiked. The rash started as a single lesion on his upper back and spread to his shoulders. His medical history includes type 1 diabetes mellitus managed with an insulin pump, with a recent hemoglobin A1C of 7.8%. He has no known exposure to melanocytotoxic chemicals. Vital signs are within normal limits. What diagnostic test is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

6724082e-ce8f-47e0-9112-82778d223f5a.question: A 5-year-old female is brought to a speech therapist for continuing work on improving her communication skills. She is only able to verbalize two-word sentences and has generalized developmental delay. When she was born, it was noted that she had a high-pitched mewing cry, and subsequent physical examination revealed microcephaly, prominent epicanthal folds, and a holosystolic murmur best heard in the left fifth intercostal space near the sternum. Which chromosomal abnormality is most likely responsible for this patient's disorder?

efb2cfed-a99a-4d88-acec-2611d084609c.question: A 62-year-old female presents with vaginal spotting and urinary urgency lasting 4 days. She is postmenopausal since age 52 and has hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, diabetes, and takes atorvastatin, hydrochlorothiazide, metformin, and aspirin. Her pelvic exam reveals a 4 x 3 cm firm, immobile, erythematous mass on the right inner vaginal wall, and her last Pap smear 1 year ago was normal. There is no fever, abdominal pain, or diarrhea. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

ed9d7a43-a950-4d1e-a642-8e469dd97b32.question: A 59-year-old man is evaluated for progressive joint pain with swelling and tenderness over the first, second, and third metacarpophalangeal joints of both hands. His hand radiograph shows relevant findings. He has poorly controlled diabetes mellitus of 2 years duration. Laboratory studies reveal a transferrin saturation of 88% and serum ferritin of 1,200 ng/mL. What is the most likely underlying etiology of this patient's joint condition?

25d3375d-49f7-4845-8c6b-beef556003fe.question: A newborn is found to be extremely cyanotic immediately after birth and develops progressive respiratory failure, requiring admission to the neonatal ICU. Physical examination reveals a single loud S2 heart sound and a machine-like murmur at the left upper sternal border. Radiography demonstrates an enlarged "egg-shaped" heart. An atrial septostomy is performed to stabilize the newborn pending definitive surgical correction. What is the most likely diagnosis for this newborn's condition?

dd3a9ad3-b579-4220-9524-07eb61a40f81.question: A 25-year-old male involved in a knife fight presents with a penetrating chest wound, unconscious and unable to provide history. Vital signs include blood pressure 85/55 mm Hg, pulse 115/min, respirations 19/min, and oxygen saturation 92% on room air. Physical examination reveals diaphoresis, unresponsiveness, pale and cool extremities, and a 3-inch left-sided chest wound between the 3rd and 4th intercostal space with profuse bleeding. Transthoracic echocardiography shows a full-thickness penetrating injury to the right ventricular free wall without coronary artery involvement. The patient is intubated and undergoing aggressive fluid resuscitation, including blood transfusion. What is the best definitive surgical approach for this injury?
dd3a9ad3-b579-4220-9524-07eb61a40f81.correct_answer: Interrupted 2-0 polypropylene suture with supporting pledgets

6bf7a579-57e1-4d9a-82f8-6c69bedcf993.question: A post-mortem lung examination of a 68-year-old overweight male with evidence of chronic lower extremity edema, a 60 pack-year smoking history, and daily productive cough would most likely reveal which histopathological finding?

d9c0616d-d08a-4016-b084-cfdc785a7f8b.question: A 54-year-old male presents to his primary care physician with chronic fatigue limiting his ability to engage in physically demanding activities. He has well-controlled hypertension and diabetes, no smoking history, and social alcohol use. Physical examination reveals nontender enlarged nodules. A biopsy demonstrates a characteristic chromosomal abnormality in chromosome 18. Which protein's regulation is most likely to be disrupted in this patient?

5d33c58c-6b86-4ff0-adfe-d89d873114f1.question: A 44-year-old African-American woman comes to the physician for a routine examination. She is concerned about cancer because her uncle died of metastatic melanoma 1 year ago. She has no history of serious illness and does not take any medication. She has been working in a law firm for the past 20 years and travels to the Caribbean regularly with her husband. Examination of her skin shows no abnormal moles or warts. What type of melanoma is this woman at greatest risk of developing?

b308e494-ccfe-474a-9e2c-e9807df2b732.question: A 60-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her daughter for evaluation. The daughter reports that her mother has recently been having difficulty combing her hair in the mornings. The patient’s family history is significant for an ischemic stroke in her father. Her past medical history includes diverticulosis. She takes no medication. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals neck stiffness and bilateral shoulder tenderness, with intact muscle strength. Laboratory results show an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 65 mm/h and C-reactive protein of 44 mg/dL. Based on this presentation, which specific symptom should the patient be screened for?

bcb36ff5-558b-46f9-8981-7f13ee251819.question: A 30-year-old woman presents with a 3-year history of infertility despite her husband having normal semen analysis. She reports episodic pelvic and back pain accompanied by painful diarrhea occurring monthly for 4–6 days over the past 5 years, partially relieved by ibuprofen. She has regular 29-day menstrual cycles lasting 7 days since menarche. Physical and pelvic examinations are unremarkable, and a prior hysterosalpingogram showed normal results. What is the most likely underlying pathophysiological mechanism responsible for her symptoms?
bcb36ff5-558b-46f9-8981-7f13ee251819.correct_answer: Endometrial tissue outside the uterine cavity

45aa52a2-bc80-48ff-ad98-1226dd81cb93.question: A 55-year-old truck driver is brought to a physician by his wife. She states that her husband developed a fever and began feeling weak 3 days ago, but has refused medical help. He has been unable to go to work because of his symptoms. The patient has been previously hospitalized for a tricuspid valve replacement surgery 1 year ago and takes aspirin daily. The medical history is also relevant for myocardial infarction 3 years ago and hypertension for the past 10 years, for which he takes lisinopril. His blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg, the pulse is 82/min, respirations are 18/minute, and temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F). On examination, several hemorrhages are noted on the nail beds of several fingers. What clinical or diagnostic finding would be most helpful in establishing a diagnosis?
45aa52a2-bc80-48ff-ad98-1226dd81cb93.correct_answer: Friable irregular masses attached to the valve

8e4c9324-87bd-4d09-beed-946c9c724d34.question: A previously healthy 30-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of pain during sexual intercourse for 6 months. She also reports frequent episodes of crampy pelvic pain that starts one day before menses and lasts for 7 days, unrelieved by pain medication. Her menstrual cycles are regular at 28-day intervals, lasting 5 days, with her last period 2 weeks ago. She is sexually active with her husband and uses combined oral contraceptives. Vital signs are normal, and physical examination reveals rectovaginal tenderness. Cervical and urethral swabs are negative, and transvaginal ultrasonography shows no abnormalities. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

bedb70a1-ccf4-4fa5-bd1c-ef7c38212e00.question: A 50-year-old man visits his physician after 20 years of not seeking medical care, concerned about cardiovascular health following a colleague's heart attack. He reports no active complaints but leads a sedentary lifestyle. His family history includes a father with a heart attack at age 54. Current blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg, and physical exam reveals obesity. Laboratory results show fasting serum glucose of 105 mg/dL, total cholesterol 250 mg/dL, HDL-cholesterol 35 mg/dL, LDL-cholesterol 186 mg/dL, and triglycerides 170 mg/dL. Other labs and urinalysis are unremarkable. Based on these findings, which specific laboratory abnormality warrants initiation of treatment in this patient?

a540086f-d663-4198-bd00-2b773e6b9899.question: A 26-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which she was a restrained passenger. On arrival, she is lethargic and incoherent. She has severe facial lacerations and is in respiratory distress. Her pulse is 130/min, respirations are 29/min, and blood pressure is 90/58 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 70%. Examination shows multiple facial lacerations. There is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the left lung base. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness with no guarding or rebound. Bowel sounds are normal. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Her hemoglobin concentration is 12.1 g/dL. An x-ray of the chest reveals a fractured left second rib, depression of the left mainstem bronchus, deviation of the nasogastric tube to the right, and a widened mediastinum. What is the most likely diagnosis?

1111ace9-1165-446a-824b-2f174f3c0531.question: A 26-year-old G1P0 woman presents to her primary care physician’s office with feelings of anxiety, trouble initiating sleep, occasional palpitations, and fatigue. She denies prior similar symptoms or recent medication/drug use and is currently 10 weeks pregnant. Vital signs include a pulse of 105/min, and physical exam reveals mild diaphoresis, warm skin, diffusely enlarged thyroid with bruits. Laboratory studies show a thyroid-stimulating hormone level of 0.01 µU/mL (normal 0.5-5.0 µU/mL) and an elevated free thyroxine (FT4) inappropriate for pregnancy. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

6fd894d4-75a5-4d0f-9e9c-2bdf8e4571ba.question: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of intermittent loose stools and a 1.2-kg (2.6-lb) weight loss. She immigrated to the US from Uganda 6 weeks ago. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness with no guarding or rebound. The liver is firm and palpable 3 cm below the right costal margin, and the spleen is palpable just below the left costal margin. Her leukocyte count is 12,800/mm³ (12% eosinophils). Stool culture reveals several oval-shaped eggs with lateral spines. Microscopic examination of a liver biopsy specimen shows granulomatous inflammation with periportal fibrosis. What exposure is most likely responsible for the development of this patient’s condition?

f8459a09-ae9e-4c6e-9ee6-d2879b85a9fc.question: A 3-month-old girl is brought to a pediatrician by her parents. She has central cyanosis without signs of respiratory distress or heart failure. An echocardiogram reveals severe pulmonary outflow obstruction, right ventricular hypertrophy, a ventricular septal defect, and an overriding of the aorta. An elective primary surgical repair is planned at 4 months of age. What is the relationship between hemoglobin levels and iron deficiency anemia in patients with this congenital heart defect?
f8459a09-ae9e-4c6e-9ee6-d2879b85a9fc.correct_answer: Normal hemoglobin in patients with tetralogy of Fallot does not rule out iron deficiency anemia.

12d4ecb4-191e-456a-9ffe-89d3f8187fbd.question: A 79-year-old woman with no prior medical history presents with agitation, confusion, and altered sleep-wake cycles six days after surgical repair of a hip fracture. She is oriented only to person, exhibits inattentiveness, and has no focal neurologic deficits. Her husband reports minimal alcohol intake (1-2 glasses of wine weekly), and her current medication is oxycodone for pain. Vital signs are normal, and urine dipstick results are unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?

6fbeda50-68a6-486d-8ef0-e414ccdaa36d.question: A 54-year-old woman with a history of mental retardation, hypertension, and diabetes presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset ataxic gait and reduced responsiveness below her baseline non-verbal state. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical exam reveals new spasticity, 3+ reflexes, positive Babinski sign, symmetric hand swelling and deformities, and a cervical "clunk" during spinal manipulation. What underlying condition most likely predisposed this patient to her current neurological presentation?

4c9d2a57-51e9-4e5e-b664-cd75a50ae9f4.question: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after sustaining a stab wound to the left chest just below the clavicle. On arrival, he exhibits rapid, shallow breathing, anxiety, a pulse of 135/min, respirations of 30/min, and a palpable systolic blood pressure of 80 mm Hg. Following intubation, mechanical ventilation, and initiation of 0.9% saline infusion, his pulse is 133/min and blood pressure is 82/45 mm Hg after five minutes. Examination reveals a 2.5-cm stab wound at the left 4th intercostal space in the midclavicular line, muffled heart sounds, jugular venous distention, and normal breath sounds. What is the most likely finding on further evaluation of this patient?
4c9d2a57-51e9-4e5e-b664-cd75a50ae9f4.correct_answer: A drop in systolic blood pressure of 14 mmHg during inspiration

606402a5-50f1-419d-9d24-e23dc9b04ea9.question: A 40-year-old man presents to his primary-care doctor for a follow-up of his hypertension. He is asymptomatic and denies new complaints. He has a 10-year history of poorly controlled hypertension despite maximum doses of lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, and amlodipine. His father required a kidney transplant in his forties. Physical exam reveals bilateral palpable flank masses, and laboratory studies show a creatinine of 2.5 mg/dL. Renal ultrasound findings are consistent with his clinical presentation. What is the most appropriate test to screen for additional complications of this patient’s underlying condition?

d349f853-6a25-496e-88ee-5345531ca469.question: A 17-year-old female is brought to the emergency room by her father due to shortness of breath and chest pain that worsens with breathing or coughing, along with hemoptysis. She has no significant medical history. Vital signs include a temperature of 99°F (37.2°C), blood pressure 107/65 mmHg, pulse 102/min, respirations 21/min, and O₂ saturation 91% on room air. Imaging reveals a large pulmonary filling defect, prompting intravenous treatment initiation. Subsequent monitoring of the drug’s effects via standard blood testing shows normal results. What is the most likely mode of inheritance for the underlying condition causing this patient’s symptoms?

a59bd66f-cfd0-4c7e-85cc-dbbee69c3828.question: A 26-year-old male presents to his primary care physician with complaints of burning with urination, penile discharge, and intermittent fevers. A urethral smear shows gram-negative diplococci within white blood cells. The organism grows well when cultured on Thayer-Martin agar. The patient is prescribed a course of ceftriaxone, and the infection resolves without further complication. One year later, the patient returns with the same infection. What mechanism best explains the lack of lasting immunity against the organism despite the previous infection?

a520b2b3-8196-4792-9672-cf331713b99d.question: A 37-year-old man with no significant past medical history is rear-ended in a motor vehicle accident. He reported significant neck pain to emergency responders but denies weakness, numbness, or tingling in his extremities. His vital signs on presentation to the emergency department are heart rate 90, blood pressure 140/80, respiratory rate 20, and SpO2 98%. What is the most appropriate next step upon presentation to the emergency room?

9e8b8e2a-1ec9-48b9-8a0f-b7dc59797a25.question: A 43-year-old man with a history of schizophrenia, currently controlled with medication, presents with a 3-month history of white discharge from both nipples and diminished sexual drive. His physician suspects a medication side effect. What medication is least likely to be responsible for these symptoms?

5764553f-e3b5-4e03-9750-3a130fa2669b.question:
A 2-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician because of yellowing of the skin and sclerae for 16 hours. He had previously been well. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation via uncomplicated vaginal delivery and weighed 3.1 kg (6 lb 13 oz). The mother has no medical insurance and did not receive prenatal care. The newborn's 4-year-old brother has sickle cell disease. Examination shows jaundice. The abdomen is mildly distended. The liver is palpated 1 cm below the right costal margin and the spleen tip is palpated just below the left costal margin. Laboratory studies show:  
Hemoglobin 11 g/dL  
Reticulocytes 9%  
Leukocytes 9,100/mm³  
Platelets 244,000/mm³  
Maternal blood group O, Rh-negative  
Anti-Rh antibody titer positive  
Fetal blood group B, Rh-negative  
Serum bilirubin, total 11.3 mg/dL  
Direct 0.3 mg/dL  
What is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?

7f5ecf67-3c90-4880-b09e-0047ec61e83d.question: A 65-year-old man presents with gradually worsening rigidity of his arms and legs, slowness in performing tasks, and hand tremors that increase at rest and decrease with focused movements. On examination, he exhibits reduced arm swing while walking and a shortened, shuffling gait. An antiviral drug is prescribed, which alleviates his symptoms. What is the most likely drug prescribed to this patient?

87947f4c-4d46-4527-b898-7db0e65861d7.question: A patient who has been administered prophylactic labetalol and magnesium sulfate presents with absent deep tendon reflexes bilaterally. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?
87947f4c-4d46-4527-b898-7db0e65861d7.correct_answer: Stop magnesium sulfate and give calcium gluconate

5d97d64a-eb05-4444-af49-2dcb3cf2b531.question: A 75-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by a patrolman due to altered mental status after being found wandering near a highway. She is unable to answer questions and collapsed during transport. Vital signs include a temperature of 33.0°C (91.4°F), pulse of 40/min, respirations of 12/min, blood pressure of 80/50 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation of 85% on room air. Physical examination reveals decorticate posturing, incomprehensible speech, eyes opening to pain, dry hair, coarse and waxy skin, and non-pitting edema of the face and extremities. Electrocardiogram shows sinus bradycardia. Laboratory results are as follows: calcium 9.0 mg/dL, hematocrit 34%, potassium 4.0 mEq/L, sodium 120 mEq/L, TSH 110.0 µU/mL, thyroxine (T4) 1.2 µg/dL, and triiodothyronine (T3) 70 ng/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

e7b1cdf3-806b-4546-bd06-bc569e85a9cc.question: A 66-year-old male presents to his primary care physician to discuss his increasing shortness of breath over the last 3 months, particularly noticeable during activities like mowing the lawn or climbing stairs. His medical history includes well-controlled hypertension with lisinopril. Vital signs are T 37.6°C, HR 88 bpm, BP 136/58 mm Hg, RR 18 breaths/min, and SpO2 97% on room air. Physical examination reveals an early diastolic blowing decrescendo murmur at the left sternal border, a midsystolic murmur at the right upper sternal border, a late diastolic rumbling murmur at the apex, an S3 heart sound, and bilateral bounding radial pulses. What is the most likely diagnosis?

0398e683-d02f-45a6-bd53-b1619711b829.question: A 28-year-old woman presents following a suicide attempt 2 days ago. She states her attempt resulted from a fight with her boyfriend, during which she slit her wrists to prevent him from ending their relationship. She has a history of turbulent interpersonal relationships, both romantic and familial, and family members describe her as impulsive and manipulative. Since hospitalization, she has exhibited spitting at staff and rapid mood shifts between sobbing and anger. She denies substance use or significant medical history. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

cd932c64-f305-45af-94c8-9c0a604a301b.question: A 50-year-old man presents to his primary care doctor following an inguinal hernia repair. He reports no abdominal or groin pain, maintains a normal diet, and has resumed work as a cruise ship attendant. Preoperative chest radiography revealed right middle lobe opacification, prompting a non-contrast CT scan that identified an 8 mm peripheral nodule with regular margins and calcification. A repeat non-contrast CT scan one year later shows the nodule has grown to 10 mm but maintains similar characteristics. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
cd932c64-f305-45af-94c8-9c0a604a301b.correct_answer: Positive emission tomography (PET) of chest now

b544725d-4814-4c69-9359-5a9bf36f90fc.question: A 29-year-old man comes in for evaluation of infertility. He has been trying to conceive for over 2 years with his wife, and previous evaluation of his wife's fertility revealed no abnormalities. Physical exam reveals a tall man with long extremities, sparse body hair, gynecomastia, and small testes. Laboratory studies show increased serum follicle-stimulating hormone concentration and an elevated estradiol-to-testosterone ratio. Genetic testing confirms a cytogenetic abnormality. If this abnormality was inherited from the patient's father, at which stage of spermatogenesis did this error most likely occur?

c4ea6c29-272a-4601-b6d6-cde103a4d9a7.question: A 13-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with severe knee, hip, and groin pain. His past medical history includes obesity and asthma. Vital signs show a temperature of 98°F (36.7°C), blood pressure of 124/65 mmHg, pulse of 128/min, respirations of 14/min, and oxygen saturation of 99% on room air. Physical examination reveals an inability to bear weight on the left leg and limited range of motion of the left hip. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
c4ea6c29-272a-4601-b6d6-cde103a4d9a7.correct_answer: Surgical pinning of the femoral head

eeffedf5-70e1-440d-b8c5-bd4ffead95a2.question: A 28-year-old man presents with 5 weeks of diarrhea, crampy abdominal pain, mucoid strings in stool, abdominal bloating, and a 3.2-kg weight loss. He reports a resolved painful lower extremity rash and has no fever, cough, or bloody stools. Vital signs are stable. Lab findings include hemoglobin 11.9 g/dL, MCV 79 fL, ferritin 106 ng/dL, and platelet count 410,000/mm³. What laboratory finding in stool is most likely associated with this patient's condition?

9f9339c1-1f64-4e0e-8556-9640c563c272.question: A 51-year-old man with a history of hepatitis C and recurrent acute pancreatitis presents with a 2-day history of fever, abdominal pain, confusion, and memory deficits. Physical examination reveals confusion, scleral icterus, spider angiomas, hand tremors, abdominal distension with shifting dullness, diffuse tenderness, and absent bowel sounds. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis and hypoalbuminemia. Ascitic fluid analysis demonstrates an albumin concentration of 0.8 g/dL, glucose of 62 mg/dL, and a leukocyte count of 1900/mm³ with 60% neutrophils. What is the most likely underlying cause of these ascitic fluid findings?

08661e40-0e20-48bf-bcdd-f72634b736ee.question: An 18-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department due to a cough, runny nose, low-grade fever, hoarseness, and a barking cough that began this afternoon. She developed high-pitched breathing sounds and mild respiratory distress this evening but remains alert. Vital signs include a temperature of 38.0°C (100.4°F), respiratory rate of 50/min, and oxygen saturation of 97%. Physical examination reveals inspiratory stridor worsening with crying, a mildly erythematous pharynx, and normal tonsils without exudate. A frontal X-ray of the upper chest airways is obtained. What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?
08661e40-0e20-48bf-bcdd-f72634b736ee.correct_answer: Racemic epinephrine and intramuscular corticosteroid therapy

780eeca8-b690-4f55-be69-840407e7b9d6.question: A 43-year-old woman presents with complaints of retrosternal burning associated with eating, which has persisted for several years and is worsening. She reports episodic hand pain that is worse in winter, a chronic severe cough with dyspnea, and a history of smoking. Vital signs include a blood pressure of 174/104 mmHg and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Physical examination reveals coarse breath sounds. What is the most likely pathophysiology underlying her chief complaint?

d1111c33-07ba-4777-b7a2-85af3092e59e.question: A 67-year-old man with chronic kidney disease and a 20-year history of poorly-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with worsening fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion for 6 months. His medications include metformin and insulin. Vital signs show tachycardia, and physical examination reveals conjunctival pallor and bounding pulses. Laboratory results include hemoglobin 8.6 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume 90 μm³, reticulocyte count 0.5%, serum ferritin 325 ng/mL, urea nitrogen 45 mg/dL, and creatinine 2.2 mg/dL. A drug is prescribed to address the cause of his symptoms. What signaling pathway is directly targeted by the mechanism of action of this drug?

478e5ef3-28b0-42c0-ba35-97eb27cee46f.question: A 41-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 6-hour history of muscle cramping, decreased appetite, and diarrhea. His symptoms developed rapidly, with no identifiable trigger, and he has no prior history of similar episodes. His medical history includes obesity, sleep apnea, type 2 diabetes managed with metformin, and gastroesophageal reflux disease treated occasionally with antacids. On examination, he has tachypnea and diffuse abdominal tenderness. Laboratory results are as follows: sodium 139 mEq/L, chloride 106 mEq/L, bicarbonate 11 mEq/L, arterial pH 7.25, and pCO₂ 22 mmHg. Based on this presentation and lab findings, what is the most likely etiology of the acid-base disturbance observed in this patient?

4391b90a-3bc6-421e-9cba-6d15d737c330.question: A scientist is studying the properties of myosin-actin interactions in a sample of human muscle tissue. She has identified a drug that selectively inhibits phosphate release by the myosin head. If this drug is administered to the muscle tissue under physiologic conditions, which specific step in the cross-bridge cycling process will most likely be blocked?

985a3286-3104-47aa-82ca-cf1f994bf0d6.question: A 16-year-old boy with a seizure disorder and cognitive delay is brought to the physician because of progressively worsening right lower extremity weakness for the past 6 months. He does not make eye contact and sits very close to his mother. Physical examination shows a grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur at the cardiac apex. Neurological examination shows decreased strength in the right lower leg with normal strength in the other extremities. Fundoscopic examination shows several multinodular, calcified lesions in the retina bilaterally. A photograph of his skin findings is shown. Which gene mutation and chromosomal location are most likely responsible for this patient's condition?

fdf479f8-6fdf-4e8a-82ea-2dd43ac4fe42.question: A 66-year-old man with a history of diabetic nephropathy, hypertension, dyslipidemia, depression, morbid obesity, and current treatment for genital herpes presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diffuse tenderness. His blood pressure is 184/102 mmHg, and imaging shows no acute abdominal pathology. Laboratory results reveal a serum bicarbonate level of 11 mEq/L and creatinine of 3.1 mg/dL, with other electrolytes within normal ranges. His abdominal pain improves after bowel evacuation. What is the most likely etiology of this patient's metabolic derangement?

08162196-577c-4558-9cd7-1c3513f53d10.question: A 56-year-old man presents to the clinic for a check-up with a 1-year history of worsening shortness of breath and weight loss. He reports a history of working in a steel mill during high school and later as a construction worker, along with a 36-pack-year smoking history. Vital signs include blood pressure 130/78 mm Hg, pulse 90/min, respiratory rate 17/min, BMI 31 kg/m², and oxygen saturation 95% on room air. Pulmonary examination reveals a mildly prolonged expiratory phase without wheezing or crackles. Pulmonary function tests demonstrate an FEV1/FVC ratio of 60%, FEV1 at 50% of predicted, total lung capacity 110% of predicted, residual volume 115% of predicted, and DLCO 60% of predicted. What is the most likely diagnosis?

41e20e51-6b89-4b73-8b9c-1ff6df90ec11.question: A 25-year-old zookeeper presents to the office complaining of a dry cough, fever, and chills for the past month. He states that the symptoms occur episodically at the end of the workday and last a few hours, along with persistent fatigue. His job involves caring for various birds. He denies recent travel, trauma, smoking, alcohol use, or medications. His medical history is unremarkable except for allergies to peanuts, dust, and pollen, and a family history of childhood asthma. Chest X-ray shows diffuse haziness in both lower lung fields, and a PPD skin test is negative. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

ab745c9e-65fe-467f-bcba-b0135fab48aa.question: A 60-year-old female presents to her gynecologist with vaginal bleeding. She underwent menopause ten years prior and has a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus. Physical examination reveals a uniformly enlarged uterus. Ultrasound shows a thickened endometrial stripe, and tissue biopsy identifies neoplastic endometrial cells. After a negative metastatic workup, she undergoes laparoscopic hysterectomy.
