Postoperatively, she develops left-sided flank pain, oliguria, elevated serum creatinine (1.4 mg/dl from 1.0 mg/dl preoperatively), and hematuria. Renal ultrasound is normal. Which vessel ligation during the hysterectomy most likely contributed to these postoperative complications?

f5fa4d86-09d4-4da7-bc69-8952651cf228.question: A 40-year-old man presents to the physician with progressive weight loss over the last 3 months, frequent night sweats, and recurring low-grade fever managed with acetaminophen. He denies cough, breathlessness, or gastrointestinal symptoms. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals generalized pallor, bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy, and non-tender hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory evaluation confirms Hodgkin’s lymphoma. Which viral infection is most likely implicated in the pathogenesis of this malignancy?

5a41e29e-5ce7-4818-971f-5292f6d2a733.question: A 28-year-old gravida 1 at 32 weeks gestation is evaluated for an abnormal ultrasound showing fetal microcephaly. Early in the 1st trimester, she experienced fevers, headaches, myalgias, arthralgias, and a pruritic maculopapular rash that resolved without treatment. She had traveled to Brazil prior to symptom onset, spending evenings hiking without mosquito repellent. Toxoplasmosis IgM and IgG titers were negative. Based on her history and presentation, what is the most likely etiologic agent responsible for the fetal microcephaly?

b1eff6fe-806f-45a7-a086-f41774c39d3e.question: A 41-year-old G3P1 woman presents with a sudden onset throbbing headache, tinnitus, nausea, and left-sided weakness. She has no significant past medical history, takes no medications, and her last two pregnancies ended with spontaneous abortions before the 10th week of gestation. Vital signs include blood pressure 130/90 mm Hg, pulse 58/min, respiratory rate 11/min, and temperature 36.8℃ (98.2℉). GCS is 14/15. Physical examination reveals 3+ deep tendon reflexes and increased muscle tone in the left upper and lower extremities. Laboratory results show a platelet count of 230,000/mm³, fibrinogen 3.5 g/L, activated partial thromboplastin time of 70 seconds, and thrombin time of 34 seconds. A non-contrast CT head scan is performed. Based on these findings, what is the next best diagnostic step to evaluate the underlying cause of her presentation?

8bbd543f-f693-467f-aa17-79c7195776d6.question: An obstetrician working in a developing country delivers a newborn suspected of having congenital hypothyroidism caused by inadequate maternal iodine intake. Which clinical manifestation is not typically associated with this condition?

0f8f8f8e-6fe5-47a6-bffb-34a4107920ab.question: A 33-year-old nurse is referred to an infectious disease specialist after exhibiting a PPD skin test with 17 mm of induration. She denies cough, shortness of breath, hemoptysis, weight loss, fatigue, fevers, or night sweats over the last several months. Her temperature is 97.0°F (36.1°C), blood pressure is 120/81 mmHg, pulse is 82/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. A chest radiograph is unremarkable. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

47556641-6848-4f17-bf40-cdd2668a1e51.question: An 81-year-old woman is brought to the emergency room by her son after falling and hitting her head, preceded by complaints of chest palpitations. Her medical history includes hypertension and atrial fibrillation, with current medications being lisinopril, metoprolol, and warfarin. Vital signs show a blood pressure of 152/96 mmHg and pulse of 60/min. Physical examination reveals disorientation, intermittent drowsiness, a left pupil measuring 6 mm and non-reactive to light, a right pupil measuring 2 mm and reactive to light, a right-sided visual field defect, and right-sided hemiparesis (1/5 strength) with normal left-sided strength. A head CT scan is obtained. What is the most likely explanation for this patient’s clinical presentation?

eaaba70d-36b2-47b6-b42b-5268540107a5.question: A 67-year-old man with peripheral neuropathy comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after the results of serum protein electrophoresis showed monoclonal gammopathy. A complete blood count, serum creatinine, and serum electrolyte concentrations are within the reference ranges. A bone marrow biopsy shows 6% monoclonal plasma cells. Further analysis reveals that class I major histocompatibility molecules are downregulated in these monoclonal plasma cells. The proliferation of these cells is typically prevented by a class of immune cells that lyse abnormal cells without requiring opsonization, priming, or prior activation. What class of immune cells best describes this mechanism of action?

0dd3951f-fc24-4d35-b059-f5a42c62289d.question: A 47-year-old woman presents with progressive muscle weakness for five months, primarily affecting her shoulders and hips, along with difficulty rising from chairs, climbing stairs, combing her hair, and swallowing solid foods. She has a 5-year history of hyperlipidemia managed with fluvastatin and a family history of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis in her mother and Duchenne’s muscular dystrophy in her maternal uncle. Neurologic examination reveals moderate bilateral weakness in arm abductors and hip flexors. Laboratory results show an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate and creatine kinase level. What histopathologic finding on muscle biopsy would most likely confirm the diagnosis?

3e6a42d2-a3b2-4129-aa78-74eadb604842.question: A 41-year-old man presents to the emergency room with sudden onset of blurry vision one hour ago. He states that he was resting at home when he noticed difficulty reading and now reports seeing double images vertically aligned. Earlier today, he experienced nausea, vomiting, and watery diarrhea, which he attributed to food consumed at a picnic the previous day, including potato salad, hamburger, deviled eggs, and neighbor-made pickles. A friend who attended the same picnic developed similar symptoms. Vital signs show temperature 98.4°F (36.9°C), pulse 75/min, blood pressure 122/84 mmHg, and respirations 13/min. Cranial nerve examination reveals fixed pupillary dilation and impaired downward eye movement. What is the most likely pathophysiological mechanism responsible for this patient’s clinical presentation?

b3d3ca4c-a5b4-4aaf-96eb-315acf816448.question: A 4-week-old female newborn is brought to the physician because of increasing yellowing of her eyes and skin for 2 weeks. The mother has noticed that the girl's stools have become pale over the past week. She was breastfed since birth but was switched to formula feeds recently, which did not resolve the symptoms. The patient was delivered vaginally at 38 weeks' gestation with an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. Vital signs are normal, and her growth parameters are at the 50th percentile for length and 60th percentile for weight. Examination reveals scleral icterus, jaundice, and a liver palpated 2 cm below the right costal margin. Serum studies show a total bilirubin of 15 mg/dL (direct 12.3 mg/dL), alkaline phosphatase of 2007 U/L, AST 53 U/L, ALT 45 U/L, γ-glutamyl transferase 154 U/L, and blood group A positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?

3a7f0ddc-713f-4e54-9831-7e914db18ddc.question: A 43-year-old man comes to the emergency department with nausea, abdominal discomfort, diarrhea, and progressive perioral numbness for the past 24 hours. Three days ago, he underwent a total thyroidectomy for treatment of papillary thyroid cancer. His only medication is a multivitamin supplement. He appears fatigued. While measuring the patient's blood pressure, the nurse observes a spasm in the patient's hand. Physical examination shows a well-healing surgical wound on the neck. What ECG finding is most likely present in this patient?

01274f55-7431-4b11-932e-bb4d765eeda7.question: A 68-year-old woman presents with left lower quadrant pain that worsens with defecation, described as "crampy," and reports a history of mild constipation. She denies recent weight changes or urinary symptoms, with her last menstrual period 16 years ago. Vital signs include a temperature of 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse 102/min, respiratory rate 16/min, and blood pressure 133/87 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals left lower quadrant tenderness. Laboratory results show hemoglobin 13.2 mg/dL, hematocrit 48%, leukocyte count 16,000/mm³ with 89% neutrophils, 5% bands, and 11% lymphocytes. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

d485e860-1b56-48de-97bf-747a96340f5c.question: A 67-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with erectile dysfunction, reporting inability to engage in sexual intercourse for the past month despite intact sexual desire. He also describes deep, burning buttock and hip pain during walking that resolves with rest, along with absence of nocturnal or morning erections. His medical history includes diabetes, coronary artery disease, hypertension, and a 40 pack-year smoking history. Physical examination reveals diminished femoral and lower extremity pulses. What is the most specific underlying etiology responsible for this patient’s symptoms?

5b9250ab-9f0c-4e50-bdbe-b274aebba745.question: A 55-year-old man with a history of chronic glomerulonephritis due to IgA nephropathy presents to your office with bone pain. What serum laboratory findings would most likely be observed in this patient, and how do these findings correlate with his underlying condition?
5b9250ab-9f0c-4e50-bdbe-b274aebba745.correct_answer: Increased PTH, decreased calcium, increased phosphate, decreased calcitriol

cede32c8-6c47-4ce1-8f91-a5c4b3c8156e.question: A medical researcher is studying the physiology of the immune system to better understand the effects of HIV on patients. He isolates a group of cells positive for the CD8 surface marker via flow cytometry, mixes them with infected cells, crosslinks extracellular interactions, and immunoprecipitates the CD8 protein. Analysis reveals a two-chain protein from an adjacent cell bound to CD8. What is the primary function of the protein most likely identified in this experiment?
cede32c8-6c47-4ce1-8f91-a5c4b3c8156e.correct_answer: Binds endogenous peptides that have been transported by the TAP channel

b9581a40-2b81-4136-b12b-2c41e8898c0e.question: A 61-year-old Caucasian male presents to the office with chest pain, expressing concern about his heart due to his father's fatal heart attack at age 62. He reports that his pain worsens with large meals and spicy foods and improves with calcium carbonate. He denies dyspnea on exertion, and an ECG is normal. What is the most likely cause of this patient's chest pain?

f08e45cb-1c9a-4ab1-b7da-2bb813016c1f.question: A 36-year-old woman presents with bilateral tearing, foreign body sensation in the eyes, palpitations, nervousness, sweating, and heat intolerance. She has a 20-pack-year smoking history. Examination reveals eyelid retraction, incomplete eye closure, limited upgaze, proptosis on orbital CT with enlarged extraocular muscles (tendon sparing), TSH 0.1 μU/mL, elevated T4, and positive thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins. What intervention for her underlying condition is most likely to cause a transient worsening of her ocular symptoms?

afe87410-b047-4045-8be5-0d0d01dda4d2.question: A 7-year-old boy is brought to a pediatrician by his parents for evaluation of frequent bed wetting during the night. A detailed history reveals that there has been no history of urinary incontinence during the day since the boy was 4 years of age, but he has never been dry at night continuously for 1 week. There is no history of urinary tract infections, urgency, frequency, or hesitancy. His vital signs are stable, and neurologic and abdominal examinations are normal. Laboratory results show a first-morning urine-specific gravity of 1.035, absent red and white blood cells in urine, and a negative urine culture. What is the next appropriate step in the management of this patient?
afe87410-b047-4045-8be5-0d0d01dda4d2.correct_answer: Reassuring the parents and use of an enuresis alarm

5d3c413a-d1dd-44b7-88dd-e524ef8add27.question: A 52-year-old man with a history of gastric cancer treated with subtotal gastrectomy dies in a motor vehicle collision. Autopsy reveals unilateral atrophy of spinal cord neurons in a specific area. Based on this finding, what neurological deficit would most likely have been observed during a clinical examination while the patient was alive?
5d3c413a-d1dd-44b7-88dd-e524ef8add27.correct_answer: Decreased positional sense in the ipsilateral leg

1f8a017a-2f2e-4fed-8426-5514b8abc516.question: A 24-year-old pregnant woman at 28 weeks gestation presents to the emergency department with complaints of fever with chills, pain in her knee and ankle joints for the past 2 days, headaches, and difficulty moving her neck. She reports a recent tick bite on her arm while gardening. Her medical history is noncontributory, and she takes a prenatal multivitamin with iron and folate. Physical examination reveals an erythematous rash on her right arm, and obstetric evaluation shows a normally progressing pregnancy with reassuring fetal ultrasound findings. Lyme disease testing is ordered. What is the next best step in management for this patient?

a63a7a06-1f47-40bf-9cdd-ca71d638e082.question: A 25-year-old woman presents to her physician with a four-month history of fatigue, progressive weakness (now unable to climb stairs or stand from sitting), and oligomenorrhea. She has obesity with abdominal striae, hypertension (160/100 mmHg), and lab findings including hyperglycemia (314 mg/dL), elevated serum cortisol (30 µg/mL), low ACTH (2 pg/mL), and a 24-hour urinary cortisol of 470 µg. A 48-hour high-dose dexamethasone suppression trial failed to reduce serum cortisol levels. Based on this presentation and diagnostic workup, what is the most appropriate next step in management?

147f19c6-977f-4b7b-81ef-0138c94b31a9.question: A 67-year-old woman with non-Hodgkin lymphoma presents with progressively increasing numbness and tingling in her fingers and toes, along with decreased sensation to light touch in all distal extremities and reduced knee and ankle deep tendon reflexes. Her symptoms began one week after her last cycle of chemotherapy with vincristine. What is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient’s peripheral neuropathy?

dd9b77a0-673c-4b0e-82cd-4bb4db00294e.question: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician with a 1-week history of painless hematuria. A CT scan of the urinary tract shows areas of bladder wall thickening. Cystoscopy reveals several sessile masses with central necrosis arising from the bladder wall. A biopsy specimen of the bladder masses demonstrates moderately differentiated urothelial cells with abundant mitotic figures and nuclear atypia. Based on these findings, what substance is the patient most likely to have a history of exposure to?

f76295b6-a33b-4b32-a330-bd80a3c533ae.question: A 14-year-old girl presents with her father for evaluation of short stature. She reports feeling well but is concerned about being shorter than her peers. Her birth weight was normal, and her father mentions having a short stature during adolescence but now stands 177 cm tall. Her current height is at the 2nd percentile, weight at the 35th percentile, with Tanner stage 2 breast development and absent pubic and axillary hair. A left hand and wrist x-ray reveals a bone age of 11 years. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

964c1b68-f969-408f-9935-12a38d538862.question: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of facial swelling that started 5 days ago. Two weeks ago, he had a sore throat that resolved spontaneously. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 107/min, and blood pressure is 94/67 mm Hg. Examination shows pitting edema of the upper and lower extremities as well as periorbital edema. The abdomen is mildly distended. Laboratory studies reveal hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia, and significant proteinuria without hematuria or leukocyte esterase in the urine. Based on these findings, what light microscopy findings would most likely be observed on a renal biopsy of this patient?

3be0bca6-80bf-40cc-89ba-32b1c46b4fec.question: A 60-year-old man is referred to a dermatologist by his family physician for management of a rare case of dermatitis unresponsive to standard corticosteroid therapy. His medical history is unremarkable, and he works reduced hours as an accountant. Physical examination shows confluent scaly patches, plaques, generalized erythroderma on the torso and lower extremities, and a solid skin lesion exceeding 1 cm in diameter. A biopsy is ordered due to suspicion of malignancy. What is the most accurate description of this patient’s underlying condition?
3be0bca6-80bf-40cc-89ba-32b1c46b4fec.correct_answer: Tumor arising from cutaneous T cells

7b064a68-f6fb-4b67-9e69-4bd6e8fd3533.question: A 35-year-old woman presents to her physician with persistent stress and anxiety over several months, reporting difficulty relaxing, excessive worrying, and impaired concentration at work. She describes engaging in shoplifting of trivial items to relieve stress, followed by immediate guilt and discarding stolen objects, despite being unable to stop this behavior. Vital signs and physical examination are unremarkable, and mental status examination reveals anxiety but intact orientation. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?

f55cc6df-14b9-4ab0-be8f-ceedbec6c181.question: A 65-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a several-month history of behavioral changes, including inappropriate actions such as using foul language and grabbing people unexpectedly. His condition has progressed to worsening memory deficits and difficulty performing self-care tasks. Vital signs include a blood pressure of 162/103 mmHg. Physical examination reveals inappropriate laughter, poor ability to recall medical history, word-finding difficulties, and inattentiveness during conversation. What is the most likely diagnosis?

4a998665-33fe-4bec-b46b-47771b8a664b.question: An 11-month-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother for a rash on his trunk, which he has had for the past 2 days. She notes that he is eating less and is more cranky than usual. His birth history is insignificant, and his immunizations are up to date. Vital signs include: temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 98/min, and respiratory rate is 16/min. The rash features thin-walled, fluid-filled blisters that rupture easily. Fluid samples from the lesions are sent for analysis to a microbiology lab. The results reveal an infection by the gram-positive bacterium *Staphylococcus aureus*. The patient is diagnosed with staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome. What component of the immune system is primarily responsible for the initial defense against the bacteria and toxins produced in this condition?

779e0fe1-86f1-498b-ae5b-1b41b4a6f9e8.question: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with dry cough, shortness of breath, and low-grade fever that began 6 days ago. He also reports having 3 episodes of watery diarrhea per day for the last 2 days. He appears slightly pale. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 65/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 140/78 mm Hg. Diffuse crackles are heard over bibasilar lung fields. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin of 13.8 g/dL, leukocyte count of 16,000/mm³, platelet count of 150,000/mm³, serum sodium 131 mEq/L, chloride 102 mEq/L, potassium 4.7 mEq/L, bicarbonate 26 mEq/L, urea nitrogen 18 mg/dL, and creatinine 1.2 mg/dL. A chest x-ray reveals patchy infiltrates in both lungs. What is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?

1a4d62f6-1e75-49eb-b1ba-74bfd52a73d3.question: A transvaginal ultrasound reveals an intrauterine heteroechoic mass with numerous anechoic spaces and no identifiable fetus or amniotic fluid. Both ovaries are enlarged and demonstrate multiple thin-walled, septated cysts with clear content. What is the most likely cause of the ovarian findings in this patient?

234f6fa6-3456-4052-a7c1-961012eda8c0.question: A 75-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her son due to a 2-day history of fever, headache, malaise, and dry cough. The patient lives with her son and his family, and her son reports that other family members have had similar symptoms during the past week, though he remains asymptomatic. Polymerase chain reaction testing confirms infection with a virus possessing a helical capsid and segmented genome. What is the most likely explanation for the son remaining free of symptoms despite exposure?

21f356dd-e823-4a0b-bfc4-a42e044f1222.question: A 71-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine visit. His psychiatric history is significant for major depression with psychotic features, diagnosed after his wife died from pancreatic cancer four years earlier. Three years ago, he deliberately overdosed on sleeping pills. He currently denies suicidal thoughts or self-harm but reports persistent sleep disturbances. He lives alone, has access to weapons at a local hunting club, and takes sertraline and olanzapine. Based on this history, what is the strongest risk factor for suicide in this patient?

2d2d3ce3-3e14-46bd-801e-6f590bbaca4e.question: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a generalized rash for 3 days, accompanied by severe itching, fever, headache, and muscle pain. He had a runny nose 5 days ago that resolved with over-the-counter medications. He recently returned from a camping trip and attends daycare. Vital signs include a temperature of 38.2°C (100.7°F). Physical examination reveals macules, papules, crusted lesions, and a few fluid-filled vesicles on the face, trunk, extremities, abdomen, and back, with no cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis?

ea3a0fc7-73ca-467f-8fc5-e2693b049cec.question: A 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance because of unusual behavior that started 3 hours ago while he was at a party. He has a history of major depressive disorder and seasonal allergies. His mother has a history of anxiety. He drinks 5 beers on the weekends. Current medications include amitriptyline and diphenhydramine. The patient does not respond to questions and repeatedly says, "The government is following me everywhere." His temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 160/89 mm Hg. He is diaphoretic. He is not oriented to place or time. Neurologic examination shows dilated pupils bilaterally and diffuse hyperreflexia. His feet are cold, and capillary refill time is 3 seconds. After the examination, the patient starts screaming and tries to bite the physician. Urine toxicology screening is positive for ethyl glucuronide. What is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?

c03cae47-40f2-47e2-95f9-c9fe640d189f.question: A 22-year-old male presents to the emergency room complaining of neck stiffness that began three hours ago, now resulting in complete immobility. His medical history includes schizophrenia and asthma, with current medications being albuterol and an unnamed additional drug. Vital signs include a temperature of 99.0°F (37.2°C), blood pressure 130/90 mmHg, pulse 105/min, and respirations 18/min. Physical exam reveals anxiety, diaphoresis, a neck flexed and rotated 40 degrees to the right with firm right sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles, intact extraocular movements, and orientation to person, place, and time. The patient reports taking an extra dose of his medication four hours ago due to auditory hallucinations. What medication should most likely be administered to this patient?

ffad3e49-6cbe-4fd7-a354-4496ff355b9d.question: A 13-month-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. Physical examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly. A venous blood sample obtained for routine screening tests appears milky, and refrigeration results in a creamy supernatant layer on top of the sample. Genetic analysis identifies a mutation in the apolipoprotein C-II gene (APOC2) on chromosome 19. What complication is this patient at greatest risk for developing?

e5b66767-736a-4ae6-abfa-9284c08bf210.question: A 41-year-old man comes to the emergency department with nausea, abdominal discomfort, and diarrhea for the past 2 days. His abdominal discomfort worsens shortly after meals. He reports progressive perioral numbness and upper-extremity muscle cramping over the past 24 hours. Six months ago, he underwent a Roux-en-Y gastric bypass for obesity. He had a total thyroidectomy for a Hurthle cell lesion 4 days ago. His mother died of lung cancer at age 68. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 22 years. His only current medication is a multivitamin. He appears fatigued. Vital signs are temperature 36°C (96.8°F), pulse 72/min, respirations 20/min, and blood pressure 130/70 mm Hg. During blood pressure measurement, the nurse observes hand spasm. Physical exam shows a well-healing neck surgical wound and mild abdominal tenderness with healed laparoscopic incisions. Serum studies include Na⁺ 138 mEq/L, K⁺ 4.2 mEq/L, Cl⁻ 102 mEq/L, HCO3⁻ 25 mEq/L, Mg²⁺ 1.7 mEq/L, phosphorus 4.3 mg/dL, 25-hydroxyvitamin D 20 ng/mL (N: 20-100), PTH 115 pg/mL, and normal liver function tests. What is the most appropriate initial step in managing this patient?

0374f58b-878d-41db-a080-88695f1b54a2.question: A 9-year-old boy is brought to a physician by his mother for evaluation of generalized weakness, increased urination, and increased thirst. The mother reports that he has persistent fatigue worsening over time, a preference for sedentary activities, and lifelong constipation. He craves salty foods but otherwise maintains a regular diet. His medical history is unremarkable, and growth parameters are in the bottom 10th percentile for his age. Vital signs include a pulse of 90/min and blood pressure of 110/75 mm Hg. Laboratory findings show hypokalemia (3.2 mEq/L), hypochloremia (95 mEq/L), elevated plasma renin activity (10 ng/mL/hr), elevated plasma aldosterone (20 ng/dL), and increased urinary calcium excretion. What is the most likely diagnosis?

16cae871-c8bc-4d63-8fd3-451b25266920.question: A 5-year-old boy of African descent is presented to the emergency department by his parents. The child is clutching his abdomen and crying about pain in his belly. His mother reports intermittent episodes of jaundice with joint and bone pain since he was 5 months old. At presentation, the patient’s vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals slight jaundice and pale conjunctiva. The spleen is tender and easily palpable. After a complete blood count with differential and an abdominal ultrasound, the patient is found to have sickle-cell disease with splenic infarct. A partial splenectomy is performed. After the operation, the physician provides vaccines against *Neisseria meningitidis*, *Haemophilus influenzae*, and *Streptococcus pneumoniae*. A histological slide from the resected spleen is analyzed. Which dysfunctional zones of the spleen, as marked on the slide, predispose the patient to the infections requiring these vaccines?

4ead1c0c-3ee9-4b39-a0b0-b6c9332b63e0.question: A 51-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician complaining of months of dry mouth and dry eyes, with severe dryness causing difficulty swallowing food. She has a history of hypertension managed with hydrochlorothiazide (HCTZ) and a family history of systemic lupus erythematosus in her grandmother. Vital signs are blood pressure 118/76 mm Hg, heart rate 78/min, and respiratory rate 15/min. Physical exam reveals tender parotid glands bilaterally and dried mucous membranes. Serum testing confirms high titers of anti-Ro and anti-La autoantibodies. Given her primary diagnosis, what condition is this patient most at risk for developing in the future?

154ed784-62ee-4c77-b2b9-2d4e672863d1.question: A 59-year-old man presents to his primary care provider with fatigue, a progressively worsening cough with flecks of blood, shortness of breath, and dark urine. He reports feeling ill for the past 3 weeks. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He takes chlorthalidone and atorvastatin. Family history is noncontributory. He has smoked 20–30 cigarettes daily for the past 26 years. Anti-glomerular basement membrane serologies are positive. What specific immunofluorescence finding is characteristic of this patient’s condition?

e6d8dbbc-6474-40f4-a1c4-b8c952cf0147.question: A 32-year-old man with HIV infection is brought to the emergency department due to a 2-week history of progressively worsening headache and vomiting. His current medications include trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, dolutegravir, and tenofovir-emtricitabine. Vital signs reveal a temperature of 38.5°C (101.3°F). Physical examination demonstrates nuchal rigidity with positive Kernig and Brudzinski signs. Lumbar puncture shows an opening pressure of 32 cm H₂O (normal: <20 cm H₂O), and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) culture grows a pathogen on Sabouraud agar. What additional CSF finding is most likely present in this patient?

bb1160e6-0443-407f-b2b5-6fa07ca2397f.question: A 70-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of back pain. For the past six days, she has had a burning pain in her upper right back and chest. She cannot recall any recent injury and has no prior history of back pain. She has a history of hypertension and gastroesophageal reflux. The patient volunteers at an animal shelter three times a week. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Current medications include ramipril and pantoprazole. The patient appears healthy and well nourished. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.42°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 145/92 mm Hg. Examination shows a long erythematous rash covered with multiple clear vesicles and crusty lesions extending from her back to below her right breast. What is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient’s condition?
bb1160e6-0443-407f-b2b5-6fa07ca2397f.correct_answer: Viral reactivation in dorsal root ganglia

82408848-0be1-4e15-bb67-ebbd83ef6857.question: A type of fatal adrenal cancer has an average survival rate of 3 years after the onset of clinically significant symptoms, with a 4-year asymptomatic period prior to symptom development. A new screening test detects the cancer 2 years before clinical symptoms appear. An observational case-control study comparing screened and unscreened patients who declined treatment found that the screened population had statistically better median 5-year survival outcomes. What step should be taken to prevent bias when interpreting these findings?
82408848-0be1-4e15-bb67-ebbd83ef6857.correct_answer: Using mortality rates in the analysis

32826b6b-dadb-4e96-9c9b-f39f3528c76b.question: A 60-year-old man presents to the office with a one-year history of progressively worsening shortness of breath exacerbated by physical activity. He has worked in the glass manufacturing industry for 20 years. Vital signs include a heart rate of 72/min, respiratory rate of 30/min, and blood pressure of 130/80 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals diminished respiratory sounds bilaterally. Chest radiograph shows interstitial fibrosis with reticulonodular infiltrates and eggshell calcification of multiple lymph nodes. What is the most likely diagnosis?

47404b5c-d7b2-44e2-beb4-c6d2c7560c82.question: A 43-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her brother for severe chest pain. The patient recently lost her husband in a car accident and is still extremely shocked by the event. On physical examination, her blood pressure is 105/67 mm Hg, the heart rate is 96/min and regular, breathing rate is 23/min, and pulse oximetry is 96%. An S3 heart sound and rales in the lower right and left lung lobes are heard. A 12-lead ECG shows no significant findings. Echocardiography reveals an enlarged left ventricle and left atrium. What is the most likely diagnosis?

822452ae-f7fb-42a3-aadd-6890ee90fd30.question: A 56-year-old man with a long history of homelessness and alcoholism is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious. He has bloody vomit with small clots and food particles, a smell of alcohol, and black tarry stool on rectal exam. Vital signs include a pulse of 95/min, blood pressure 110/70 mm Hg, respiratory rate 20/min, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. After receiving oxygen, IV fluids, and placement of an NG tube with intermittent suction, what is the most appropriate next step in his management?

ad18004f-1ec9-4771-b1de-9cebaf38eadd.question: An 8-year-old girl presents with a 2-day history of hematuria and 1+ pitting edema of the lower legs and ankles. Two weeks prior, she experienced a sore throat that resolved without treatment. Urinalysis reveals numerous RBCs and 3+ proteinuria, and her antistreptolysin O titer is elevated. What pathological formation is most likely responsible for the underlying mechanism of her symptoms?

766e71ab-bb20-4f81-b7c1-a803c416637b.question: A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency department with altered mental status after being found unresponsive in the street. His past medical history is unknown. Vital signs include a temperature of 99.0°F (37.2°C), blood pressure of 104/64 mmHg, pulse of 70/min, respiratory rate of 5/min, and oxygen saturation of 91% on room air. The patient is undergoing resuscitation in the trauma bay. What physical exam finding is most likely present in this patient?

ac876b64-7a82-4fbf-86e1-710f7a0f34cb.question: A 38-year-old G4P3 presents to her obstetrician’s office for her 20-week anatomy ultrasound. She reports feeling well with no contractions or vaginal bleeding and notes good fetal movement. She declined prenatal screening earlier for religious reasons but requested an anatomy ultrasound to assess fetal growth. Her previous pregnancies were uncomplicated, resulting in three full-term healthy deliveries. The ultrasound reveals a male fetus with suspected intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), microcephaly, convex-rounded feet, clenched fists with overlapping fingers, and a medium-sized ventricular septal defect (VSD). The amniotic fluid index (AFI) is 26 cm. Based on these findings, what additional physical feature is most likely present in this fetus?

fbe4be15-8062-4692-a63b-033b0b91b79c.question: An 83-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with fever, weakness, and decreased responsiveness. He is diagnosed with urosepsis based on urinalysis and culture and started on ceftriaxone and intravenous fluids. By hospital day 3, he is clinically improving. During the evening, the patient becomes irritable, talks to someone despite nobody being present in the room, is easily agitated, attempts to strike a nurse with a remote control, and repeatedly tries to walk away despite being a fall risk. What is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?

3845ec35-17eb-4f42-a29c-b49cae498fc2.question: A 26-year-old woman presents to the physician with a 2-month history of fatigue, weight loss, and muscle aches. She has no personal or family history of serious illness and takes only a multivitamin. After a metyrapone stimulation test rules out adrenal insufficiency, what laboratory finding would most likely be observed following the administration of this drug?

7243dce8-6fc6-49e8-8303-a465398d92d1.question: An investigator conducts a study to determine whether earlier detection of glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) in patients increases survival time. One subset of study participants consists of asymptomatic individuals diagnosed with GBM via screening MRI, while the other subset was diagnosed only after developing symptoms. Results show asymptomatic patients had an average survival time 6 weeks longer than symptomatic patients. Which statistical bias is most likely responsible for this apparent difference in survival due to the endpoint selected for the study?

f9c2a07e-681d-4c43-80e0-8298e889f0c2.question: A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was the restrained driver. On questioning by the paramedics, he reported severe chest pain and mild dyspnea. On arrival, he is confused and unable to provide a history. His pulse is 93/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 91/65 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. He is able to move his extremities in response to commands. He opens his eyes spontaneously. Pupils are equal and reactive to light. Examination shows multiple bruises over the trunk and extremities. There is a 3-cm (1.2-in) wound at the left fifth intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Jugular venous distention is present. Decreased breath sounds and hyperresonance on percussion are noted on the left. What is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?

82322016-23cb-4ea2-8041-50c1b4061481.question: A clinical research study evaluated a novel PET radiotracer in 1,200 patients (600 with Parkinson’s disease and 600 without). The scan was positive in 590 patients with PD and 20 patients without PD. What is the specificity of this test?

c645ae65-dd6d-4ebc-a94d-b93fea4c1e5f.question: A 55-year-old man presents to a rheumatologist with a 10-year history of bilateral wrist and knee pain accompanied by morning stiffness lasting approximately 50 minutes. He reports no joint swelling, digital color changes, mucosal dryness, fever, or chills. Physical examination reveals non-tender nodules on the left 1st, 3rd, and 4th distal interphalangeal joints, tenderness at the base of both thumbs, and bilateral knee enlargement with pain and crepitus on passive range of motion. What is the most likely diagnosis?

a53473cb-a1bc-4034-a3f4-99777fe0e373.question: A 40-year-old businessman with no significant past medical history presents to the emergency department with left-sided weakness following chiropractic neck manipulation. Neurological imaging reveals a left C5 hemicord lesion. After cervical immobilization, steroid administration, and initiation of physical therapy, what additional clinical finding is most likely to be observed in this patient?

ae6a0127-4345-4dbd-a422-5c7b954d5e8a.question: A previously healthy 19-year-old man presents with a 12-hour history of dull, throbbing right-sided scrotal pain, along with a burning sensation during urination and increased urinary frequency for the past 3 days. He reports no urethral discharge and is sexually active with one female partner without condom use. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination reveals a tender right testicle that improves with elevation. The penis appears normal without discharge. Urinalysis shows 3 WBC/hpf, and a Gram stain of a urethral swab demonstrates polymorphonuclear leukocytes but no organisms. Testicular ultrasound reveals increased blood flow to the right testicle. What is the most likely causative organism responsible for this patient’s condition?

8499235d-c096-4c3b-93d7-c3fa305fbe78.question: A 4-month-old infant is brought to the office by his parents due to sudden nose bleeding without trauma. He has a 1-month history of multiple 1-cm diameter bruises on the hands and feet, as well as tiny red spots on the upper and lower extremities. There is no prior bleeding history or relevant family history. Vital signs include heart rate 190/min, respiratory rate 40/min, blood pressure 99/42 mm Hg, and temperature 36.6°C (97.9°F). Physical exam reveals pale skin, petechiae on the soft palate and extremities, and ecchymosis on the hands and feet. Laboratory results show hemoglobin 8.9 g/dL, hematocrit 41%, platelet count 450,000/mm³, normal coagulation studies, and a blood smear with hypochromia, poikilocytosis, and large platelets. Platelet aggregation testing with ristocetin is normal, but bleeding time is prolonged. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient’s condition?

1148d90a-fdac-4c73-9735-73bd3fc39591.question: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of dysuria and increased urinary frequency. Vital signs are within normal limits. Urinalysis shows cloudy, red urine. What structural features of the causative viral agent best explain this patient's clinical presentation?

280150a2-41a9-4fa1-a293-ca8cc99a1292.question: A 13-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician due to a left breast lump under his nipple. He noticed it last month and felt that it has increased slightly in size. It is tender to touch but has no overlying skin changes. There is no breast discharge. The patient has cryptorchidism as an infant and underwent a successful orchiopexy. In addition, he was recently diagnosed with ADHD and is currently on methylphenidate with improvement in his symptoms. He has a family history of type I diabetes in his father and breast fibroadenoma in his mother. On exam, the patient is at the 82nd percentile for height, 79th percentile for weight, and 80th percentile for BMI. He has Tanner IV pubic hair. Testicular volume is 7 mL on each side, and both testes are smooth and freely mobile. Breast exam shows a normal right breast and a 3-centimeter round, firm, and slightly tender discrete mass under the left nipple. What is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?

05a40ec8-7354-42d1-9423-ac31cb3cf6d2.question: A 35-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency room with unilateral leg swelling. She reports painful left-sided leg redness and swelling developing earlier in the day, with a prior episode affecting the right leg one year ago, diagnosed as a right femoral vein thrombus. She has no recent prolonged travel history and takes no medications. Examination reveals left leg erythema, swelling, and pain on passive dorsiflexion of the left ankle. Ultrasound confirms a left popliteal vein thrombus, and genetic testing identifies an inherited condition. What is the most likely pathophysiological mechanism underlying her recurrent thrombotic events?

3fc0e5d6-3c01-4d0d-9b18-4e9195efc3bf.question: A 78-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter due to increasing forgetfulness over the past 5 weeks. He previously lived independently but moved in with his daughter after struggling with daily activities, including leaving doors open and taps running. He reports poor sleep with frequent nighttime awakenings, social withdrawal, and loss of interest in previously enjoyed activities like playing the piano. His medical history includes hypertension managed with amlodipine. Vital signs and neurologic examination are unremarkable. Mental status exam reveals orientation to person, place, and time but demonstrates psychomotor retardation, blunted affect, and impairments in short-term/long-term memory, attention, and concentration. Serum electrolytes, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and vitamin B12 levels are normal. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

4d7a1871-0792-4686-afaa-7d6d3993993d.question: A previously healthy 18-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for evaluation of an abdominal mass noticed a few days ago. He appears markedly pale and lethargic. Examination shows a 6-cm, nonmobile mass in the left upper quadrant that crosses the midline. A 24-hour urine collection shows elevated homovanillic acid and vanillylmandelic acid. Further evaluation, including biopsy, confirms the diagnosis of intermediate-risk neuroblastoma. The physician recommends the standard treatment of neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgical resection if possible. After discussing the risks, benefits, likelihood of unresectability without neoadjuvant therapy, and prognosis without treatment, the parents refuse chemotherapy due to concerns about side effects and prefer supportive care only. What is the most appropriate action for the physician to take in this situation?
4d7a1871-0792-4686-afaa-7d6d3993993d.correct_answer: Seek a court order for neoadjuvant chemotherapy

fbc57772-7c48-49f5-827b-53461ddf972e.question: A laboratory studying cellular proofreading mechanisms charges a Lys-tRNA with valine instead of lysine and introduces it into a cell. The researchers design an mRNA sequence containing only lysine codons. What is the most likely outcome regarding the incorporation of the mischarged tRNA during translation?
fbc57772-7c48-49f5-827b-53461ddf972e.correct_answer: The mischarged tRNA with valine will be incorporated in the codons that specificy for lysine

0c044f6e-1caf-4452-8c11-f519816ac098.question: A 65-year-old man with metastatic lung cancer has been experiencing severe, unremitting pain requiring escalating doses of oral morphine, which now causes dose-limiting side effects. His pain management team recommends a medication that reduces opioid requirements through NMDA-receptor interaction. What is the most likely agent recommended in this scenario?

c162d252-d881-4222-ba71-4d4bef1d4798.question: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency room complaining of left shoulder pain for several weeks that worsens when lying on his left side. He reports no relief from pain medications and denies trauma despite being an amateur tennis player. Physical examination reveals severe tenderness at the greater tuberosity of the left shoulder, biceps tendon tenderness in the bicipital groove, and limited range of motion. X-ray findings include narrowing of the acromiohumeral space, acromion sclerosis, and spurring. Laboratory results are normal except for a positive rheumatoid factor. What is the most likely diagnosis?

7da34f2d-4f5f-417a-a34d-44df1a2bdcdd.question: A 17-year-old woman presents to your office concerned that she has not had her menstrual period in 4 months. She states that menses began at age 13 and have been regular until recently. She denies sexual activity, and a urine pregnancy test is negative. On exam, she appears well-nourished with a BMI of 21 kg/m², but you note bilateral enlarged cheeks and calluses on the dorsum of her hands. She reports significant stress related to school and recent episodes of binge eating. Based on these findings, what additional clinical manifestation would most likely be present in this patient?

9038b71c-5579-400b-958a-1ea00254afee.question: A 23-year-old college student presents to the clinic with a history of intermittent chest discomfort. He reports experiencing monthly episodes over the past 8-9 months characterized by a sensation of his "chest exploding," shortness of breath, limb shakiness, and profuse sweating requiring clothing changes. These episodes may coincide with academic stressors like exams or major deadlines. Due to escalating anxiety about experiencing attacks in public settings, he increasingly avoids leaving home. His medical history is unremarkable, and physical examination reveals no abnormalities. What medication is most appropriate for the long-term management of this patient's condition?

7c276a40-1021-45ec-9f5e-6cc9edb7f637.question: A stillborn infant is delivered at 38 weeks' gestation to a 32-year-old woman who had no prenatal care. Examination of the infant reveals a small pelvis, shallow intergluteal cleft, and club feet. Radiographic imaging shows absence of the sacrum and lumbar vertebrae. What is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?

1760a619-578b-4242-96f6-4668276c6462.question: The authors of a study conducted a follow-up analysis stratifying results by CD4+ T-lymphocyte count at diagnosis. Among patients with CD4+ cell counts below 200/mm³, cART adherence significantly predicted reduced DLBCL risk (RR = 0.52, p = 0.01). However, no association between cART adherence and DLBCL risk was observed in patients with CD4+ counts above 200/mm³ (RR = 0.96, p = 0.36). What epidemiological or statistical concept best explains the difference in risk ratios observed between these two CD4+ strata?

a3e3f1f0-c629-4ed3-af63-3d4d2f99952b.question: A patient with a Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection has Th1 cells secreting a factor that stimulates phagosome-lysosome fusion in macrophages, activates macrophages to produce pathogen-destroying mediators like NO, and promotes tubercle formation. What is the name of the Th1-secreted factor responsible for these immunological effects?

a1349ec0-ac42-476f-af8b-84ef42b1384f.question: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician because of abdominal pain and constipation for 3 weeks. His mother reports increasing irritability. He has a vocabulary of 50 words without sentence use, refers to himself by name, and cannot name body parts or count to three. Physical examination reveals pale conjunctivae and abdominal tenderness. Peripheral blood smear demonstrates small, pale red blood cells with basophilic stippling. Which biochemical process is most likely impaired in this patient?
a1349ec0-ac42-476f-af8b-84ef42b1384f.correct_answer: Conversion of aminolevulinic acid to porphobilinogen

4dd7016b-159f-475b-9b7e-6405ddd7b7f1.question: A group of researchers conducted a retrospective study to determine the association between folic acid supplementation before pregnancy and autism spectrum disorder (ASD) in offspring. They surveyed 200 mothers of children diagnosed with ASD and 200 mothers of healthy children, interviewing participants about prenatal folic acid consumption via questionnaires after their children’s diagnoses were established. The study reported a significant association between folic acid supplementation and reduced ASD risk (OR = 0.3, p < 0.01). Given the study design and data collection method, what type of bias is most likely to have influenced these results?

0e393e14-cf87-4f57-9b01-863683594dbe.question: A student studying pharmacology is part of a research team investigating the elimination of anticoagulant medications. During the study, the student collects serum samples from a subject every 4 hours and documents that the subject eliminates 0.5 mg of the drug during each 4-hour interval. Based on this elimination pattern, which anticoagulant is the subject most likely receiving?

ac483b5d-74a6-43a0-8113-2ff045354274.question: A 40-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for a checkup, reporting recent weakness and weight loss but no urinary symptoms. Laboratory results from four months ago showed a BUN of 45 mg/dL and creatinine of 2.0 mg/dL. Current lab values include hemoglobin 8 g/dL, hematocrit 29%, leukocyte count 9,500/mm³ with normal differential, platelet count 197,000/mm³, sodium 139 mEq/L, chloride 100 mEq/L, potassium 5.9 mEq/L, bicarbonate 17 mEq/L, BUN 59 mg/dL, glucose 99 mg/dL, creatinine 2.3 mg/dL, and calcium 9.0 mg/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis?

c2336b89-e537-4ac1-81b9-ee13de905eb9.question: A 28-year-old woman presents to the obstetrics and gynecology clinic due to inability to conceive after 2 years of attempting pregnancy. Her husband has two children from a previous marriage and has undergone evaluation for male infertility. The patient has a history of abdominal surgery and a family history of endocrine disorders. Following diagnostic testing, a treatment is initiated and administered intermittently during the week preceding her expected menstrual cycle. If this medication were administered via an alternative method or regimen, what other medical condition could it potentially be used to treat?

cb3e69fb-2ad1-45b3-a7fd-d39771b556f8.question: A 2-year-old girl with recurrent urinary tract infections is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. Renal ultrasound shows bilateral dilation of the renal pelvis. A voiding cystourethrography demonstrates retrograde flow of contrast into the ureters during micturition. What histologic finding is most likely to be observed in a kidney biopsy specimen from this patient?

8a563318-d69c-4298-9727-9568bf268a89.question: An unconscious 55-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department by ambulance after being found unresponsive in his garage with empty vodka bottles and a partially consumed antifreeze container. His medical history is unremarkable. Upon regaining consciousness, his vital signs include a blood pressure of 135/85 mmHg, heart rate of 120/min, respiratory rate of 22/min, and temperature of 36.5°C (97.7°F). Physical examination reveals slurred speech, difficulty following commands, and diffuse abdominal tenderness without rebound. Laboratory results show an elevated serum creatinine (1.9 mg/dL) and blood urea nitrogen (29 mg/dL). What urinary finding is most likely present in this patient?

8f4d9a61-dcd4-432d-b647-78cfbe55ba88.question: A 17-year-old girl presents with an 8-month history of severe acne vulgaris involving the face, upper back, arms, and buttocks, unresponsive to oral antibiotics and topical benzoyl peroxide-retinoid therapy. Examination reveals oily skin with numerous comedones, pustules, and scarring. She is started on long-term combined oral contraceptive pills. Which condition does this medication reduce the risk of developing in this patient?

23e816a8-fee5-47da-af1c-12556e4196cc.question: A 48-year-old female presents for a follow-up appointment to discuss her ultrasound results. She presented with a lump in her neck 2 weeks ago. On examination, a thyroid nodule was present; the nodule was fixed, immobile, and non-tender. Ultrasound showed a hypoechoic nodule measuring 2 cm. Histological examination of a fine needle biopsy revealed cytological findings suspicious for neoplasia. CT scan is performed to assess for bone or lung lesions, which are common metastatic sites in this condition. Treatment with radioiodine therapy is planned after near-total thyroidectomy. Based on this tumor's typical behavior, what is the most likely initial metastatic site in this patient?

3fd4931d-352b-4b5f-906a-caab78fc2a60.question: A 39-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a 2-day history of severe headaches, fever, and painless swelling of the right eyelid that is obstructing vision. He recently returned from travel to Thailand, Ethiopia, and Brazil. His vital signs include a temperature of 102°F (38.8°C), pulse of 125/min, and blood pressure of 126/81 mmHg. Physical examination reveals nontender right eyelid swelling, lymphadenopathy, and an indurated red patch with erythema and local swelling on the left leg. What medication should be initiated to treat this patient's condition?

321813c1-f0d7-4825-86d3-0fae4db1392a.question: A 10-year-old Caucasian female with Turner's syndrome underwent an abdominal imaging study, which revealed that the poles of her kidneys were fused inferiorly. During normal embryological development, which anatomical structure typically prevents the ascension of the kidneys, potentially leading to this congenital anomaly?

1602e767-f21f-4f53-82c0-36f965bcef22.question: A 34-year-old woman with no significant medical history and up-to-date vaccinations undergoes emergent splenectomy following a Grade V splenic laceration sustained during an assault. Based on her post-operative risk profile, which specific vaccines should be administered to prevent infection in this patient?

e6e6f7fb-51b0-4467-9191-b3d07bbd0d79.question: Researchers are studying the inheritance pattern of mutations in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator (CFTR) gene, the gene responsible for cystic fibrosis. In addition to the commonly found ΔF508 mutation, a novel mutation in this gene is identified in a particular population under study. What statistical measure and critical value would most likely suggest that these two loci have a high probability of being closely linked?

d7b92bc3-eb62-4e61-9519-fd4863219fdf.question: A 28-year-old woman returns to the clinic to follow up on a recent abnormal cervical biopsy that demonstrated cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) I. The patient is anxious about the implications of this diagnosis. Her physical examination and vital signs are within normal limits, and her medical, family, and social histories are non-contributory. What is the appropriate management strategy for this newly diagnosed CIN I in a 24-year-old patient?
d7b92bc3-eb62-4e61-9519-fd4863219fdf.correct_answer: Close observation, pap smear screening at 6 and 12 months, and HPV DNA testing at 12 months

d77e60ae-a84a-4284-9327-6110bebbb59f.question: A clinical researcher developed a new drug, DN501, which has the same mechanism of action as darunavir but fewer side effects. Despite darunavir's efficacy in HIV patients, some have experienced hyperglycemia. What is the mechanism of action of DN501?

369e28ff-f8ac-41d8-b83d-d46402fbbd01.question: A 58-year-old white man with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with a 3-month history of a painless lesion on his lower lip. He reports a 20-pack-year smoking history and has worked as a fruit picker for 25 years. His medications include captopril and metformin. Physical examination reveals a single ulcer near the vermillion border. What is the most likely diagnosis?

529afe14-dc1c-496e-845e-6440f7925b7a.question: An investigator is studying the effect of drug X, a cyclin-dependent kinase 4 activator, on the retinoblastoma (Rb) gene in endometrial cells. After administering drug X to cultured endometrial cells, flow cytometry is used to measure changes in cell cycle phase distribution. Based on the role of Rb in cell cycle regulation, what effect is most likely observed in the cells following drug X administration?

b361ba44-20f6-425f-bbc7-f5bc1ff00d18.question: A 65-year-old man with a history of HIV (noncompliant with antiretroviral therapy) presents with painless cervical, axillary, and inguinal lymphadenopathy, fevers, drenching night sweats, 6 kg weight loss, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase. Excisional lymph node biopsy confirmed the most likely diagnosis. What is the next best diagnostic test to perform in this patient's workup?

bfd9563e-050f-4d58-a599-dac7dd6b401b.question: A group of orthopedic surgeons conducted a study evaluating cerclage wiring as a supportive approach in osteosynthesis for 14 patients with primary and periprosthetic femur fractures, recording parameters such as demographics, implant type, number of wires, fracture union rate, and complications over a mean follow-up of 16 months. All patients achieved union within a mean of 90 days with no reported complications. The authors submitted their research as a cohort study, but the journal editor recommended reclassifying it as a case series. What key methodological limitation in the study design likely prompted the editor to suggest this reclassification?

e725f008-1a45-41e5-bd5b-065c764d4ec1.question: A 67-year-old woman presents from home hospice with a change in mental status, including increased confusion and inability to verbalize symptoms. Her vital signs show a temperature of 102°F (38.9°C), blood pressure of 117/65 mmHg, pulse of 110/min, respirations of 19/min, and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. Physical exam reveals a tender right upper quadrant mass. Ultrasound demonstrates pericholecystic fluid and gallbladder wall thickening without gallstones. What is the most likely diagnosis?

46a1f76d-4ae2-45f9-a7c7-c75fd6923518.question: A 35-year-old female is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious. Her blood glucose level is 35 mg/dL, Hgb A1c is 5.1%, and C-peptide levels are decreased. She returns to baseline after glucose replacement and reports no prior similar episodes. She has no significant past medical history but notes a family history of diabetes in her mother and mentions undergoing a stressful divorce. What is the most likely explanation for this patient’s hypoglycemic episode?

a7e378c1-184d-4d80-a510-7a07bcc9a700.question: A 45-year-old man presents to the physician with complaints of increased urinary frequency and decreasing urine volumes for the past 2 months. He reports no pain during urination and has attempted dietary modifications, including reducing evening fluid intake, without improvement in his nocturia (2–3 nightly awakenings). There is no family history of prostate disease. Physical examination reveals no suprapubic mass, tenderness, or costovertebral angle tenderness. What is the most appropriate next step in evaluating this patient?

50d6f297-35f0-4dfc-9304-35339c7eecc1.question: A 48-year-old woman with chronic tension headaches presents with several episodes of bilateral flank pain and reddish urine over the past month. Her medications include daily aspirin for headache management. Vital signs show a temperature of 37.4°C (99.3°F) and blood pressure of 150/90 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals bilateral costovertebral tenderness. Laboratory studies demonstrate hemoglobin 10.2 g/dL, serum creatinine 2.4 mg/dL, urine protein 3+, RBC >16/hpf, WBC 2/hpf, and no casts or dysmorphic RBCs on microscopy. What is the most likely underlying pathophysiological mechanism responsible for this patient's hematuria?

5451085e-8f68-4c47-87b0-7330a4d68563.question: A 37-year-old primigravid woman at 12 weeks' gestation presents to the emergency department with vaginal bleeding and dull suprapubic pain for 3 hours, preceded by 3 days of spotting. She takes folic acid and a multivitamin and has a 15-year smoking history of one pack daily. Vital signs include a temperature of 37°C (98.6°F), pulse of 110/min, and blood pressure of 89/65 mm Hg. Pelvic examination reveals a dilated cervical os and a uterus consistent with 11-week gestation. Ultrasonography demonstrates a 4 cm crown-rump length embryo without fetal cardiac activity. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

27681497-666e-47af-9b05-9a5356c7a026.question: A 17-year-old female accidentally eats a granola bar manufactured on equipment that processes peanuts. She develops type I hypersensitivity-mediated histamine release, resulting in pruritic wheals on the skin. Which layer of this patient's skin would demonstrate histologic changes on biopsy of her lesions?

05a15dca-08a3-409c-badd-d1ec096e2025.question: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with a persistent cough, fever, and vomiting. Over the past year, she has been hospitalized three times for pneumonia. For the past week, she has had a thick purulent cough and reports her chest feels 'heavy.' Her stools have been loose and foul-smelling during this period, and her parents are concerned about her lack of weight gain despite meeting developmental milestones. She was born at 39 weeks via spontaneous vaginal delivery and is up-to-date on vaccinations. Physical examination reveals a temperature of 39.1°C (102.4°F), lethargy, crackles in the lower lung bases with dullness to percussion, and a nasal polyp. What is the most likely underlying cause of her symptoms?

30b00b19-0d15-4b2c-b946-b19b0d59f46b.question: A 48-year-old man seeks evaluation at a clinic with a complaint of breathlessness for the past couple of weeks, difficulty walking a few blocks, and a dry, hacking cough for the past 3 months. His medical history includes idiopathic arrhythmia treated with daily amiodarone. He is a non-smoker with no alcohol or illicit drug use. Vital signs show a heart rate of 98/min, respiratory rate of 16/min, temperature 37.6°C (99.68°F), and blood pressure 132/70 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals inspiratory crackles over the lung bases. Echocardiogram demonstrates a normal ejection fraction, and a chest radiograph is obtained. What spirometry findings are most likely present in this patient?
30b00b19-0d15-4b2c-b946-b19b0d59f46b.correct_answer: Decreased FEV1 and FVC with normal FEV1/FVC ratio

be6a2cd8-8e4d-4c7b-986e-a24bb64b8cfe.question: A 2,300 g (5 lb) male newborn is delivered to a 29-year-old primigravid woman. The mother has HIV and received triple antiretroviral therapy during pregnancy, with a viral load of 678 copies/mL measured 1 week prior to delivery. Labor was uncomplicated, and the newborn has Apgar scores of 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively, with no abnormalities on physical examination. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this infant?

59137f44-9ccc-45a3-a116-e138ba41e36f.question: A 60-year-old woman presents to a physician for worsening shortness of breath and increasing abdominal distention over the last 3 months. She reports that the shortness of breath worsens on exertion and improves with rest. While she could previously walk to the nearby store for groceries, she now has to drive due to becoming "winded." The patient was diagnosed with diabetes 5 years ago and is compliant with her medications. Her medical history is otherwise unremarkable. Physical examination reveals gross ascites, visibly engorged periumbilical veins, and bilateral pitting edema around the ankles. Her finger-prick blood glucose level is 100 mg/dL. What is the mechanism of action of the anti-diabetic medication this patient is most likely taking?

8558894d-e070-4a35-bcf9-9ab9a9b187fa.question: A 15-year-old girl presents with episodic pelvic pain radiating to her back and thighs for 4 months, occurring a few hours before her menstrual period and lasting 2 days. She reports partial relief with ibuprofen. Her menses are regular, occurring every 28 days since menarche at age 12, lasting 5–6 days. She is sexually active with inconsistent condom use. Vital signs and physical examination are unremarkable. What is the most likely pathophysiological mechanism underlying this patient’s symptoms?
8558894d-e070-4a35-bcf9-9ab9a9b187fa.correct_answer: Endometrial sloughing and uterine contractions mediated by prostaglandin

6ae4886f-2663-49e3-a5e4-102eb1382b70.question: A 25-year-old male is hospitalized for acute agitation, photophobia, and dysphagia. His parents report that he experienced flu-like symptoms for one week prior to admission and had participated in spelunking expeditions in Mexico five weeks earlier. The patient later becomes comatose and dies, with autopsy revealing a viral infection in brain tissue. By what mechanism did the causative virus most likely spread to the central nervous system (CNS)?
6ae4886f-2663-49e3-a5e4-102eb1382b70.correct_answer: Retrograde migration up peripheral nerve axons

18301ae5-321a-450e-aedb-35f2b6c36473.question: A 19-year-old Caucasian male presents to the office with hypopigmented skin. A skin biopsy reveals an absence of melanocytes in the epidermis. What is the most likely diagnosis?

6647436f-9706-4853-af41-dc5199a4e35b.question: A 51-year-old man with a history of hypercholesterolemia and hypertension, managed with rosuvastatin, hydrochlorothiazide, and aspirin, initially presented with asymptomatic lymphocytosis (WBC 29,500/mm³, 92% small normocytic lymphocytes) confirmed as chronic lymphocytic leukemia via bone marrow biopsy and flow cytometry. Three years later, he develops bilateral cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy, 10-pound weight loss, right-sided rib pain, moderate splenomegaly with tenderness, and normal vital signs. Based on his clinical progression, what is the most appropriate treatment for his current condition?

94cafdf7-1a9b-405f-bdd7-72ec57c9cd3e.question: A 62-year-old woman is evaluated for a 3-day history of headache, nausea, and decreased urination. Laboratory studies reveal serum sodium 136 mEq/L, potassium 3.2 mEq/L, chloride 115 mEq/L, magnesium 1.4 mEq/L, urine pH 7.0, and arterial blood gas analysis on room air showing pH 7.28 with HCO3⁻ 14 mEq/L. Prolonged treatment with which medication most likely explains these findings?

25e00c06-dec1-4e1f-b92a-2dea0288ba75.question: A 21-year-old male presents to his primary care provider for fatigue. He reports that he graduated from college last month and returned 3 days ago from a 2-week vacation to Vietnam and Cambodia. For the past 2 days, he has developed a worsening headache, malaise, and pain in his hands and wrists. The patient has a past medical history of asthma managed with albuterol as needed. He is sexually active with both men and women, and he uses condoms “most of the time.” On physical exam, the patient’s temperature is 102.5°F (39.2°C), blood pressure is 112/66 mmHg, pulse is 105/min, respirations are 12/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. He has tenderness to palpation over his bilateral metacarpophalangeal joints and a maculopapular rash on his trunk and upper thighs. Tourniquet test is negative. Laboratory results show leukopenia (3,200/mm³) and thrombocytopenia (112,000/mm³), with elevated AST (106 U/L) and ALT (112 U/L). What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

3f2f7baa-0fd9-4ea7-9b1f-0262187f7030.question: A 34-year-old woman with septic shock and bacteremia from a urinary tract infection remains hypotensive on hospital day 3 despite appropriate antibiotics and norepinephrine. Her leukocyte count has decreased, repeat blood cultures are negative, and serum creatinine has normalized. Thyroid studies show a normal TSH with low free T3 and T4. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

63abe5cf-90f5-415c-99ab-635f85a08d09.question: An 11-year-old child complains of pain in the leg while playing. Blood pressure measurements show 140/90 mm Hg in the upper limbs and 110/70 mm Hg in the lower limbs, with a brachiofemoral delay in the pulse. Auscultation reveals a loud S1, loud S2, S4, and an ejection systolic murmur in the interscapular area. Chest X-ray demonstrates rib notching. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

bb822bd7-7e83-44ae-944e-6fc73d1111ca.question: A 59-year-old man presents to the emergency department with 4 days of excruciating left knee pain. He underwent a total knee arthroplasty of the left knee 4 months ago and has a history of hypertension and osteoarthritis. His current medications include glucosamine, amlodipine, and meloxicam. Vital signs show a temperature of 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse of 97/min, and blood pressure of 118/71 mm Hg. Examination reveals a tender, swollen left knee joint with limited range of motion due to pain. Synovial fluid analysis confirms septic arthritis, and the prosthesis was subsequently removed. What is the most likely causative organism in this case?

839d1f78-b0d9-4c23-9678-576c76f447b7.question: A 47-year-old man presents to the emergency department with fever, fatigue, and loss of appetite for 1 week, followed by right shoulder pain, generalized abdominal pain, and paroxysmal cough. He has had diabetes mellitus for 15 years, managed with metformin and gliclazide. Vital signs include a temperature of 38.3°C (101.0°F), pulse of 85/min, and blood pressure of 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals an ill-appearing patient with a tender liver edge palpable approximately 2 cm below the right costal margin, worsened by percussion and movement. Abdominal ultrasonography is performed, and stool testing is negative for *Entamoeba histolytica* antigen. What is the best initial step in managing this patient's condition?

4fa58f57-fcd1-4cfe-af50-2d189645df79.question: A 36-year-old recent immigrant from India presents with thickened facial skin and multiple lesions. He reports a history of recurrent injuries due to loss of sensation in his toes and fingertips. A skin biopsy is performed. What staining characteristic would the bacteria in the biopsy most likely exhibit?

ce79d03f-6fe0-48f4-aa04-fc242c995bad.question: A 55-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of a progressively enlarging axillary mass, recurrent low-grade fever episodes lasting 7–10 days, and an 8-kg weight loss. Physical examination reveals nontender right axillary, cervical, and inguinal lymphadenopathy. Laboratory studies show serum calcium of 15.1 mg/dL and parathyroid hormone (PTH) of 9 pg/mL. Lymph node biopsy demonstrates granuloma formation and large CD15-positive, CD30-positive cells with bilobed nuclei. What is the most likely pathophysiological explanation for this patient’s hypercalcemia?
ce79d03f-6fe0-48f4-aa04-fc242c995bad.correct_answer: Secretion of γ-interferon by activated T-lymphocytes

5bd31964-7fe8-458a-acce-f7119441d12c.question:
A 32-year-old man presents for a pre-employment examination and reports recent travel to Guatemala. He feels well, has no medical complaints, and has not seen a physician in several years. Immunization records are unavailable. Physical examination is unremarkable. Serum studies reveal the following:  
- Anti-HAV IgM: Positive  
- Anti-HAV IgG: Negative  
- HBsAg: Negative  
- Anti-HBs: Positive  
- HBcAg: Negative  
- Anti-HBc: Negative  
- HBeAg: Negative  
- Anti-HBe: Negative  
- Anti-HCV: Negative  
What is the most likely explanation for these laboratory findings?

9c07d94c-44de-46ad-b4a7-f90b0cda0afd.question: A 7-month-old male infant is brought to the pediatrician by his mother. She reports that the child develops severe sunburns every time he is exposed to sunlight, despite applying copious amounts of sunscreen. On examination, there are multiple areas of reddened skin in sun-exposed areas, and the child’s corneas appear irritated and erythematous. Which cellular process is most likely impaired in this patient?

5daa17d8-0f76-4a9d-8357-96f9c5e107c1.question: A 65-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a neck mass. He first noticed a firm mass on the anterior aspect of his neck approximately 4 months ago. The mass is painless and has not increased in size since then. He has also noticed occasional fatigue and has gained 10 pounds in the past 4 months despite no change in his diet or exercise frequency. His past medical history is notable for gout, for which he takes allopurinol. He denies any prior thyroid disorder. He runs 4 times per week and eats a balanced diet of mostly fruits and vegetables. He does not smoke and drinks a glass of wine with dinner. His family history is notable for medullary thyroid cancer in his maternal uncle. His temperature is 97.8°F (36.6°C), blood pressure is 127/72 mmHg, pulse is 87/min, and respirations are 19/min. On exam, he has a firm, symmetric, and stone-firm thyroid. What histological finding is most likely observed on biopsy of this patient’s thyroid mass?

c7472859-6f47-4dc8-98e1-2aa8706b9fb2.question: A group of researchers explored whether estimates of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) incidence and prevalence rates were influenced by the duration of administrative data examination, using hospital discharges and physician billing codes. Incident cases were defined as the initial SLE diagnosis in the hospital database, while prevalent cases included any SLE diagnosis recorded, with patients retaining this status until death. How does the length of the study period chosen for this specific analysis affect the relationship between incidence and prevalence rates?
c7472859-6f47-4dc8-98e1-2aa8706b9fb2.correct_answer: Incidence rates will be higher during shorter time periods than longer periods.

50730c33-1d46-425d-a052-978b3f95beee.question: A 48-year-old Caucasian female presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of progressive weakness and shortness of breath. She has had progressive shortness of breath over the last year with an intermittent non-productive cough. In addition, she complains of difficulty raising her arms to brush her hair. Her temperature is 99.6°F (37.6°C), pulse is 80/min, blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Neurologic exam shows 4/5 strength in the deltoid muscles bilaterally. Diffuse dry crackles are heard on lung auscultation. A faint erythematous rash is noted on the malar cheeks, periorbital areas, lateral proximal thighs, and the elbows. What diagnostic test is most likely to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?

b0d0dd63-8564-477c-a3f4-b117e539fa3e.question: A 46-year-old man presents to the physician with a 6-month history of cough unresponsive to over-the-counter medications and recent episodes of bloody sputum. He reports fatigue after minimal exertion but denies breathlessness. His father died of lung cancer at age 54. Vital signs are within normal limits, and chest auscultation reveals localized rhonchi. A chest radiograph demonstrates a coin-like opacity in the right lung, and subsequent evaluation confirms small cell lung carcinoma. If serum laboratory testing were performed, which protein would most likely be elevated in this patient?

6a70dbad-1df4-44ca-b258-cad1107a45cc.question: A 41-year-old man presents to his primary care provider with episodic abdominal pain localized 1-2 inches above the umbilicus, lasting 20-30 minutes per episode. He reports nausea, symptom improvement with frequent small meals, and temporary relief with ibuprofen. He has a 20 pack-year smoking history, consumes 5-6 beers weekly, and has a positive stool guaiac test. Physical exam reveals epigastric tenderness. Endoscopy with biopsy is performed. Based on the clinical presentation and risk factors, what histologic finding is most likely to be identified in this patient?
6a70dbad-1df4-44ca-b258-cad1107a45cc.correct_answer: Urease-producing organism in the small intestine

40db45d5-8649-4f55-9bad-f6e528d6b90d.question: A 5-year-old female presents to the pediatrician for a routine office visit. The patient is in kindergarten and doing well in school. She is learning to read and is able to write her first name. Her teacher has no concerns. The patient’s mother is concerned that the patient is a picky eater and often returns home from school with most of her packed lunch uneaten. The patient’s past medical history is significant for moderate persistent asthma, which has required three separate week-long courses of prednisone over the last year and recently diagnosed myopia. The patient’s mother is 5’7”, and the patient’s father is 5’10”. The patient’s weight and height are in the 55th and 5th percentile, respectively, which is consistent with her growth curve. On physical exam, the patient has a low hairline and a broad chest. Her lungs are clear with a mild expiratory wheeze. The patient’s abdomen is soft, non-tender, and non-distended. She has Tanner stage I breast development and pubic hair. Based on this presentation, what diagnostic finding is most likely to be observed in this patient?
40db45d5-8649-4f55-9bad-f6e528d6b90d.correct_answer: Absent Barr bodies on buccal smear

c6653289-6050-4975-b89b-838ee5596c3b.question: A 61-year-old man was started on rosuvastatin 40 mg 8 weeks ago and presents for a follow-up visit complaining of leg pain and generalized weakness. Physical examination reveals full range of motion in his extremities with pain on movement. After discontinuation of rosuvastatin, his muscular symptoms resolve. What is the next best course of action to manage his LDL cholesterol control?
c6653289-6050-4975-b89b-838ee5596c3b.correct_answer: Restart rosuvastatin at a lower dose

ed7a0d0c-d177-4e93-9115-735b43b2f9e0.question: An unidentified surgical specimen is received for histopathologic analysis. A portion of the specimen is cut and stained with hematoxylin and eosin. The remainder is analyzed and found to contain type II collagen and chondroitin sulfate. Based on these findings, which anatomical structure is most likely the origin of this surgical specimen?

6a38fd63-13b1-41a4-affb-57499d3e500b.question: A 70-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting lasting 1 day. Computed tomography reveals a small bowel perforation.
