After undergoing emergent exploratory laparotomy with sedation using midazolam, induction with propofol, intubation, and maintenance on nitrous oxide and isoflurane, a terminal ileum perforation is repaired. Postoperatively, she is transferred to the intensive care unit. Ventilator settings include FiO₂ 50%, tidal volume 1000 mL, respiratory rate 12/min, and PEEP 2.5 cm H₂O. Vital signs are temperature 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse 76/min, and blood pressure 111/50 mm Hg. She is responsive to painful stimuli. Lung examination reveals bilateral rales, and the abdomen is distended with intact surgical incisions. Arterial blood gas analysis shows pH 7.44, pO₂ 54 mm Hg, pCO₂ 31 mm Hg, and HCO₃⁻ 22 mm Hg. What is the best next step in the management of this patient?

2d7e10c9-e999-4564-ad68-409ea37b9eb4.question: A 43-year-old man with a history of hepatitis C and current intravenous drug use presents with 5 days of fever, chills, headache, and severe back pain. On physical exam, temperature is 100.6°F (38.1°C), blood pressure is 109/56 mmHg, pulse is 94/min, and respirations are 18/min. He is thin and diaphoretic with pinpoint pupils, poor dentition, and track marks on his arms and legs. A high-pitched systolic murmur is heard, loudest in the left sternal border and with inspiration. He is admitted to the hospital and started on broad-spectrum antibiotics. One of the blood cultures drawn 12 hours ago returns positive for *Staphylococcus aureus*. What is the most appropriate next diagnostic step to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?

57363fef-2080-422b-bf80-303e61b21fb5.question: A 42-year-old man with AIDS presents with intermittent fever, nonproductive cough, malaise, decreased appetite, abdominal pain, and a 3.6-kg (8-lb) weight loss over the past month. He has not received medical care for two years. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F). Abdominal examination reveals mild diffuse tenderness, hepatomegaly, and splenomegaly. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 49/mm³, blood cultures grow acid-fast organisms, and a PPD skin test shows 4 mm of induration. What is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's condition?

158fb0cf-fdc3-4e16-8529-910f6ecfd9f1.question: A 49-year-old woman comes to the physician for a scheduled colposcopy. Two weeks ago, she had a routine Pap smear that showed atypical squamous cells. Colposcopy reveals an area of white discoloration of the cervix after application of acetic acid solution. Biopsy of this area confirms carcinoma-in-situ. What molecular mechanism involving transcription factor activation best explains the pathogenesis of this condition?

ee9b7ef7-0dcf-4061-a674-37da11a0bdd4.question: A research group has developed a low-cost diagnostic retinal imaging device for cytomegalovirus retinitis in a population of HIV-infected patients. In a pilot study of 50 patients, the imaging test detected CMV retinitis in 50% of the cases. An ophthalmologist slit lamp examination, serving as the gold standard, confirmed CMV retinitis in 20 patients who tested positive with the device and 1 patient who tested negative. If the prevalence of CMV retinitis in the population decreases due to increased access to antiretroviral therapy, how will the positive predictive value and negative predictive value of the diagnostic test be affected?

72d36b56-fd4f-49d8-9283-d07ccf42df7a.question: A 35-year-old woman is brought into the clinic by a concerned neighbor who reports that the patient frequently sets up bear traps around her property due to fears of an impending 'invasion of the mole people.' The patient wears a garlic necklace, explaining it masks her scent from the moles tracking her. She has no prior psychiatric history, denies auditory or visual hallucinations, and reports no significant medical issues. She maintains employment at a hardware store, lives alone, and describes limited social interactions despite residing in the same community for years. What is the best initial course of treatment for this patient?

f2fb786b-0f59-47e3-b3f3-4d4d26ee6d88.question: A 71-year-old man presents with urinary hesitancy and increasing nocturia over several months. Digital rectal exam reveals a slightly enlarged prostate without other abnormalities, and his serum PSA is 6 ng/mL. Transabdominal ultrasound findings are consistent with benign prostatic hyperplasia. What medication should be included in the optimal treatment regimen for this patient's condition?

58e0f0f5-e058-4496-a805-e7c12f3cf76b.question: A 30-year-old man presents to his primary care provider complaining of persistent drowsiness at work despite getting sufficient nighttime sleep, waking up rested, and having no history of snoring or apnea per his spouse's observations. His sleep journal confirms adequate sleep duration, and a sleep study demonstrates a mean sleep latency of 6 minutes. What is the most appropriate pharmacological treatment for this patient’s condition?

6e51493d-7133-41c4-a887-6ff6e42b064a.question: A 40-year-old man presents for evaluation of a painless right-sided scrotal swelling noticed several weeks ago, which is intermittent. His medical history includes hypertension treated with enalapril, a family history of paternal seminoma at age 25, and a 20-pack-year smoking history. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination reveals a 10-cm soft, cystic, nontender right scrotal mass that transilluminates. The mass does not enlarge with coughing, normal tissue is palpable above it, bowel sounds are absent within the mass, and it does not reduce in the supine position. Testicular examination is unremarkable. What is the most likely underlying cause of this scrotal mass?
6e51493d-7133-41c4-a887-6ff6e42b064a.correct_answer: Imbalance of fluid secretion and resorption by the tunica vaginalis

6f2f2fe1-f748-43b7-ae60-dd3312ce1cc1.question: A 62-year-old man presents to the physician because of incomplete healing of a chest wound following a triple coronary artery bypass graft performed 3 weeks ago. His medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension for 25 years. Clinical examination reveals wound dehiscence in the lower third of the sternal region with necrotic tissue and pus. Thoracic CT shows a small fluid collection and fat stranding in the perisurgical soft tissues. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?

11cbd3a8-4180-41ec-b5f1-456163bc3beb.question: A patient has a mutation in the Kozak sequence of the Beta-globin gene that decreases translation of Beta-globin mRNA, resulting in thalassemia intermedia. What findings would be expected on the peripheral blood smear?

82e33ec0-b332-4957-9f09-18b885956847.question: A 68-year-old man from California presents for a routine checkup. He reports no complaints and states he has maintained an active lifestyle through jogging and gardening since retiring at age 50, spending mornings in the park and afternoons in his garden. He has no significant medical history, denies smoking, and consumes alcohol occasionally. Physical examination reveals a lesion on his scalp. Based on his history and clinical findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?

9a26b74a-66e9-4c94-b47c-bd1534708724.question: A male neonate had a routine newborn screening test showing a serum phenylalanine concentration of 44 mg/dL (normal < 20 mg/dL). After initiation of a special diet, his hyperphenylalaninemia resolved. At a 4-month well-child visit, he exhibits persistent head lag, blue eyes, pale skin, blonde hair, generalized hypotonia, and a markedly elevated serum prolactin level. Based on these findings, which specific supplementation is most likely to prevent further complications of his condition?

ed70f2c4-652b-4643-96d6-e80df85c7b7a.question: A 36-year-old nursing home worker presents to the clinic with complaints of breathlessness, cough, and night sweats for the past 2 months. She reports potential tuberculosis exposure from a patient under her care. A PPD skin test measures 11 mm at 72 hours, and chest X-ray reveals a cavitary lesion in the right upper lobe. After initiating standard anti-tuberculosis therapy, she returns 3 months later with fatigue, dizziness, weakness, numbness in her feet, conjunctival pallor on exam, hemoglobin of 10 g/dL, and a mean corpuscular volume of 68 fl. What is the most likely pathophysiological mechanism underlying her current hematological findings?

99975c09-1e66-40c0-9cca-410b6324c3bc.question: A 23-year-old woman is referred to a genetic counselor due to her brother’s recent diagnosis of hereditary hemochromatosis. She reports no symptoms, including fever, chills, joint pain, or skin hyperpigmentation. Vital signs and physical examination are normal, as are her serum iron, hemoglobin, ferritin, and liver enzyme levels. Genetic screening via blood specimen is planned. Which gene mutation is most likely being assessed in this patient to evaluate her risk of hereditary hemochromatosis?

d3a90cad-3edc-41bf-8959-824baa3d09aa.question: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with constant abdominal pain over the past 8 hours, localized to the right lower quadrant where it began. She reports no nausea or vomiting and ate a snack 2 hours prior. She experienced a similar self-resolving episode last month. Her menstrual cycles are regular (28–30 days), with her last menses ending 9 days ago. Vital signs are normal. Abdominal examination reveals moderate pain on direct pressure over the RLQ that decreases upon release. Laboratory results show hemoglobin 12.5 mg/dL, leukocyte count 6000/mm³ (55% segmented neutrophils, 39% lymphocytes), platelet count 260,000/mm³, serum C-reactive protein 5 mg/L (normal <8 mg/L), and urine analysis with 1-2 RBCs per high-power field and no WBCs. Based on this presentation, what is the most appropriate next step in management?

dcdcb06e-05ba-4f16-bfca-249296922fd2.question: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a complaint of abdominal pain. The patient states he was at a barbecue around noon where lunch was arranged as a buffet without refrigeration. Within 2 to 3 hours, he developed abdominal pain with three episodes of watery diarrhea. On examination, his vital signs are temperature 99.1°F, heart rate 103 beats/min, blood pressure 110/55 mm Hg, and respiratory rate 14 breaths/min. Abdominal exam reveals pain on deep palpation without rebounding or guarding. Fecal occult blood testing (FOBT) is negative. What is the most likely causative organism responsible for this patient’s presentation?

786f98cc-d452-4c80-ac58-fd33cd8fbc1f.question: A 70-year-old man with a history of major depressive disorder and a prior ischemic stroke presents with worsening confusion, lethargy, and a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. His medications include aspirin and sertraline. Laboratory studies reveal serum sodium of 119 mEq/L and elevated serum antidiuretic hormone. Based on these findings, what are the expected changes in serum osmolality, urine sodium concentration, and serum aldosterone level in this patient?

706c25f1-a9aa-4fdd-b68a-1a1e7618afe2.question: A 35-year-old woman presents with severe fear reactions to seeing dogs after moving into a new suburban neighborhood. She reports a lifelong irrational and excessive fear of dogs but managed to avoid them while living in the city. Upon encountering neighbors walking their dogs, she experiences terror and shortness of breath. She has recently stopped picking up her children from the bus stop and no longer plays outside with them to avoid dogs. What is the best definitive treatment for this patient?

5bcda599-446d-45c5-b2e7-691779840394.question: A 45-year-old man arrives by ambulance to the emergency room after being involved in a severe construction accident with a large metal spike protruding from his abdomen. After surgical removal of the foreign body and bleeding control, he experienced intraoperative hypotension resolved with fluid resuscitation and blood transfusions. On his third day in the ICU, he developed oxygen desaturation to 85% despite mechanical ventilation with 100% oxygen. Auscultation reveals bilateral crackles, and Swan-Ganz catheter readings show CVP 4 mmHg, RVP 20/5 mmHg, PAP 20/5 mmHg, and PCWP 5 mmHg. A chest x-ray is obtained. What is the most likely direct cause of his death?

34530992-d2db-4e58-904a-8a0ee7881534.question: A 76-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents complaining of a 3-week history of cough and progressive dyspnea on exertion, along with a 20-pound weight loss. He has a 60 pack-year smoking history, worked as a shipbuilder 30 years ago, and recently traveled to Ohio to visit family. Chest radiograph reveals increased bronchovascular markings, reticular parenchymal opacities, and multiple pleural plaques. Laboratory studies are unremarkable except for mild anemia. Based on this clinical presentation and imaging findings, what is the most likely chest CT finding?

9fbc5623-c9f1-4049-88e1-6c946d5e49bd.question: A 60-year-old man presents with a 2-day history of increasing difficulty in breathing and a productive cough. He reports chronic shortness of breath over the past 6 months, exacerbated by a recent cold. His medical history includes prediabetes managed with diet and exercise and a 30-pack-year smoking history. Vital signs show blood pressure of 130/85 mmHg, pulse 90/min, temperature 36.9°C (98.5°F), and respiratory rate 18/min. Physical examination reveals diminished breath sounds bilaterally, a barrel-shaped chest, and pursed-lip breathing. Chest X-ray demonstrates a flattened diaphragm without consolidation. Pulmonary function tests show an FEV1/FVC ratio of 60%. What acid-base abnormality is most likely to be observed on this patient’s arterial blood gas analysis?

134c7a64-7c1a-497d-b88a-b15a2c64a3f0.question: A 34-year-old male with inherited hemophilia A and his wife have three unaffected daughters. What is the probability that their second daughter is a carrier of the disease?

61897d8c-75ba-4417-9e46-6f0ced9e5283.question: A 76-year-old man is brought to his physician's office by his wife due to progressively worsening hearing loss. The patient reports noticing decreased hearing approximately 10 years ago. His wife mentions he watches television at an elevated volume and struggles to understand speech, especially with background noise. He experiences constant ear ringing and episodes of unsteadiness. Physical examination shows normal outer ears and unremarkable otoscopic findings. The patient cannot repeat sentences during whisper testing. A vibrating tuning fork placed on the forehead is heard equally in both ears, and air conduction is greater than bone conduction when the fork is placed by the ear versus the mastoid process. What structure is most likely impaired in this patient?

152495ab-be3b-4770-a94d-e0f20bb1e557.question: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 6-hour history of severe eye pain and blurry vision. He wears soft contact lenses and has not removed them for 2 days. Ophthalmologic examination shows a deep corneal ulcer, severe conjunctival injection, and purulent discharge on the right. Treatment with topical ciprofloxacin is initiated. What organism is most likely to be identified in the culture of the ocular discharge?

b8bb9d7e-b7b1-4af1-a960-bddb3be8bffc.question: A 31-year-old female patient complains of numbness and tingling in her left hand, weakness, difficulty with walking, dizziness, and bladder dysfunction. She reports experiencing vision problems a year ago that resolved spontaneously within a few days. Physical examination reveals bilateral internuclear ophthalmoplegia, hyperreflexia in both patella, and bilateral clonus. An MRI study was performed (Figure 1). If a lumbar puncture is conducted, what cerebrospinal fluid finding is most likely to be observed?

3d843c80-1a5a-4f5a-bfee-66ccd0b62ec8.question: A 22-year-old primigravida presents for a regular prenatal visit at 16 weeks gestation. She is concerned about the results of a dipstick test she performed at home, which showed 1+ glucose. She reports increased urinary frequency but is unsure about changes in liquid intake. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated with no significant medical history. Her BMI is 25.6 kg/m², and she has gained 3 kg during the pregnancy. Vital signs and physical examination are within normal limits. Laboratory results include fasting glucose of 97 mg/dL, normal liver function tests, bilirubin, and plasma creatinine. Based on this presentation and test results, what diagnostic tests are indicated to determine the cause of the glucosuria?

280707db-c700-4d41-bb71-b63fa1b0f0f1.question: A 9-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother due to intermittent watery diarrhea lasting several months. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. He was diagnosed with eczematous dermatitis at 3 months old. His height and weight are below the 5th percentile. Immunologic evaluation reveals a defect in activated regulatory T cells, and genetic analysis identifies a mutation in the FOXP3 gene. What condition is this patient at increased risk for?

e700ec30-4ad4-43a6-9efe-7242d33d3d16.question: A 57-year-old man presents with a 3-week history of abdominal bloating and increased stool frequency, characterized as bulky, foul-smelling, and difficult to flush. He reports a 4-month history of recurrent dull upper abdominal pain exacerbated by meals and unresponsive to antacids, along with a 10-kg weight loss. His history includes heavy alcohol use (6–8 beers daily for 12 years) and smoking (1 pack/day for 37 years). Physical examination reveals mild epigastric tenderness without rebound or guarding, and his BMI is 20 kg/m². Vital signs are normal. What is the most appropriate next diagnostic step?

22ecb800-3c68-4798-85ab-e456806bb263.question: A 67-year-old white man presents to his primary care provider for an annual examination. He reports a rapidly developing pink bump on his forehead over the past month and has a history of significant sun exposure with multiple blistering sunburns. Physical examination reveals a 2 cm dome-shaped plaque with a central keratin plug. An excisional biopsy shows an exophytic nodule with central invagination filled with keratin and minimal keratinocyte atypia. What is the most likely diagnosis?

5391d283-4d7f-4215-98a2-1aee6d7e88af.question: A 56-year-old man presents to his primary care doctor with a 2-month history of exertional chest pain that commonly arises after walking 5 or more blocks. The pain is described as dull, burning, non-radiating substernal discomfort. His medical history includes hypercholesterolemia and hypertension, managed with simvastatin and losartan. Vital signs show a blood pressure of 150/85 mmHg, pulse of 88/min, and normal respiratory rate. Physical examination reveals no acute distress, normal heart sounds, and no murmurs. An exercise stress test is ordered to evaluate his symptoms. What substance is released locally to increase coronary blood flow during exertion in this clinical scenario?

3ba6538f-1fd5-44f3-a7ee-54cf603317ac.question: A 69-year-old male with metastatic small cell lung carcinoma undergoing chemotherapy with etoposide and cisplatin presents with diffuse rash and thrombocytopenia (platelet count 20,000/mm³). His oncologist wishes to continue chemotherapy but is concerned about treatment limitations due to his lab results. What recombinant cytokine is most appropriate to address this complication and allow optimal dosing of his regimen?

57e464b2-9572-40ef-bb76-afa97a499ae0.question: A 60-year-old man with a history of osteoarthritis awaiting hip replacement surgery reports persistent pain unrelieved by over-the-counter analgesics during his annual physical. Laboratory evaluation reveals worsened renal function (serum creatinine 2.0 mg/dL) compared to two years prior, with 1+ proteinuria on urinalysis and normal urine microscopy. Renal biopsy demonstrates eosinophilic infiltration and diffuse parenchymal inflammation. What is the most likely cause of this patient's renal deterioration?

92892df6-cd92-4ee5-b463-cd852cdf2075.question: A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath, describing an inability to take a deep breath. His past medical history includes COPD and a 44-pack-year smoking history, with prior admissions for similar presentations. Vital signs show a temperature of 98.7°F (37.1°C), blood pressure of 177/118 mmHg, pulse of 123/min, respirations of 33/min, and oxygen saturation of 80% on room air. Despite treatment with 100% oxygen, albuterol, ipratropium, magnesium, and prednisone, he remains short of breath. Physical exam reveals bilateral wheezes and poor air movement, with oxygen saturation remaining at 80%. What is the best next step in management?

d9a0d02a-9df5-4926-aa05-38f1101e15a8.question: A 76-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife due to 4 weeks of low back pain described as sharp, burning, and radiating to his left side, along with weakness. He reports a 2-month history of occasional cough with blood-streaked sputum and a 3.2-kg weight loss. Over the past 2 weeks, he has developed constipation, difficulty urinating, and inability to walk without assistance. His medical history includes hypertension managed with enalapril, and he has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 60 years. Vital signs show a temperature of 37°C (98.6°F), pulse 75/min, and blood pressure 150/80 mm Hg. Neurologic examination reveals 3/5 strength in the lower extremities, hyperreflexic deep tendon reflexes, bilateral Babinski signs, and decreased pinprick sensation below the T4 dermatome. Chest x-ray demonstrates multiple round opacities of varying sizes in both lungs. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

f6114e06-cb98-4187-badf-ca8309556ee7.question: A 32-year-old man presents to his primary care physician to discuss his long-standing fear of flying, which began after experiencing turbulence and a rough landing during a flight 15 years ago. He has since avoided air travel, missing significant family events and resorting to an 18-hour drive for a work obligation. Two years ago, he developed dizziness and lightheadedness at the airport, preventing him from boarding a planned trip with his fiancée. He acknowledges his fear is irrational but reports significant distress, strained relationships, and potential career repercussions. What is the most appropriate therapeutic intervention for this patient’s condition?

f4825126-557f-4517-9ca9-62e062264df5.question: A 75-year-old man presents to a medical clinic for evaluation of large, tense, pruritic bullae on his inner thighs, abdomen, and lower abdomen. A skin biopsy demonstrates immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibodies and linear immunofluorescence at the epidermal basement membrane. To which specific cell junction are these antibodies most likely binding?

115a2787-acb1-4885-b2aa-de2544f811ac.question: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her father due to concerns about her behavior over the past two years. She has no friends, spends most of her time reading alone, and avoids family dinners and social events with excuses. She reports preferring solitude and feeling more comfortable on her own. Mental status examination reveals an organized, logical thought process and a flat affect. What is the most likely diagnosis?

1677ce7a-7ee0-4e31-91fd-2d9de789f5b4.question: A 15-year-old boy is admitted to the hospital with a high-grade fever lasting 3 days and develops shortness of breath 12 hours after admission. He reports generalized malaise and a productive cough with green sputum during this period. Over the past 10 days, he experienced fever, sore throat, and generalized aches that initially improved but worsened again in the last 5 days. Vital signs show a temperature of 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse 109/min, respirations 27/min, blood pressure 100/70 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation of 93% on room air. Physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds and crackles in the right upper lung field. Laboratory results include hemoglobin 13.3 g/dL, leukocyte count 15,000/mm³, and platelet count 289,000/mm³. Chest x-ray demonstrates a right upper-lobe infiltrate. What is the most likely causative organism responsible for this patient's condition?

b0c472e9-ecb6-4953-9214-4abf8540ff5c.question: An elderly man presents to his physician with complaints of difficulty breathing, easy fatigability, and bilateral leg swelling which began 2 months ago. His breathlessness worsens while walking, climbing the stairs, and lying flat on his back. He also finds it difficult to sleep well at night, as he often wakes up to catch his breath. His pulse is 98/min and blood pressure is 114/90 mm Hg. On examination, he has mild respiratory distress, distended neck veins, and bilateral pitting edema evident on the lower third of his legs. His respiratory rate is 33/min, SpO2 is 93% in room air, and coarse crepitations are heard over the lung bases. On auscultation, the P2 component of his second heart sound is loudest at the second left intercostal space, and an S3 gallop rhythm is heard at the apex. Medication is prescribed for his symptoms, which changes his cardiac physiology as depicted with the dashed line recorded post-medication. What is the mechanism of action of the prescribed medication?

b0443e88-c7a9-4df5-bd6c-527e8f021744.question: A 30-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with complaints of excessive fatigue and weakness for the last several weeks. He also complains of abdominal pain and constipation for the same duration. On further questioning, he reports that he has lost 8 pounds in the last 2 weeks. Past medical history and family history are insignificant. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.2°F), respirations are 21/min, pulse is 63/min, and blood pressure is 99/70 mm Hg. On physical examination, he is a tired-appearing, thin male. He has a bronze discoloration to his skin, but he denies being outside in the sun or any history of using tanning beds. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
b0443e88-c7a9-4df5-bd6c-527e8f021744.correct_answer: Start him on both hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone therapy

0c375582-f103-4ded-a6aa-df8a785a9137.question: A 27-year-old HIV-positive female gave birth to a 7 lb 2 oz (3.2 kg) baby girl. The obstetrician is concerned about possible HIV transmission due to the mother's inconsistent use of antiretroviral medications. Which diagnostic assay would the hospital use to detect the presence of HIV genetic material in the child if infection is suspected?

7742c3b8-5d62-492a-aa6f-c27e2f803a21.question: A 53-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents with worsening symptoms over the past few months, including a persistent cough with copious greenish-yellow sputum, fever (37.8°–39°C), dyspnea, and vital signs showing tachycardia, tachypnea, and a temperature of 38.6°C. Physical examination reveals crackles and wheezes in the lower lung fields, and his FEV1 is 57% of the predicted value. He recently quit smoking after a 30-year history of 2 packs per day and is currently on oxygen and oral prednisone. What additional treatment should be considered for this patient at this time?

a03f95e6-095c-4ffb-81c3-6475ef987db1.question: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of headaches for the past 2 weeks. His headaches tend to occur in the morning and are associated with nausea and vomiting. One month ago, the patient was admitted to the hospital because of fever, irritability, and neck rigidity, and he was successfully treated with antibiotics. His temperature today is 37.5°C (98.5°F). An MRI of the brain shows bilateral ventricular enlargement and enlargement of the subarachnoid space. What is the most likely explanation for this patient’s current condition?
a03f95e6-095c-4ffb-81c3-6475ef987db1.correct_answer: Impaired CSF flow through the arachnoid granulations

f34d13c7-977c-4a3b-b055-8f356e21ffef.question: A previously healthy 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 10-day history of unsteady gait, frequent falls, and twitching of the extremities. Physical examination shows bilateral saccadic eye movement in all directions and brief, involuntary muscle contractions of the trunk and limbs. An ill-defined, nontender mass is palpated in the upper right abdomen. Following surgical resection of the tumor, what histopathologic findings are most likely observed in the mass?
f34d13c7-977c-4a3b-b055-8f356e21ffef.correct_answer: Small blue cells arranged in rosettes around a central neuropil

1e66bf6f-a7da-406f-b3c6-b1ae25dec9f4.question: In a study comparing two statin medications, statin A and statin B, baseline LDL levels were identical between the groups. Over one year, the group receiving statin A showed an average LDL reduction 11 mg/dL greater than the statin B group. Statistical analysis yielded a p-value of 0.052. What does this p-value indicate about the observed difference in LDL reduction between the two groups?
1e66bf6f-a7da-406f-b3c6-b1ae25dec9f4.correct_answer: There is a 5.2% chance that A is more effective than B is due to chance

20cca440-d3fb-4376-a5a3-3f3647268455.question: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a red, painful, cord-like rash on her left calf, along with a history of recurrent similar lesions. Her medical history includes three spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks of gestation, though she has no prior disease diagnoses. Physical examination reveals a tender, thickened, hardened cord-like lesion on the left calf and a lacy mottled violaceous rash on multiple extremities. Based on her clinical presentation and history, which antibody is most likely to be detected in her blood?

d72c679d-2894-4f43-9b31-6e3318f4f388.question: A 28-year-old female visits her physician for workup of a new-onset diastolic murmur found on physical examination. Past medical history is insignificant. Her temperature is 37.0°C, blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg, pulse is 76/min, and respiratory rate is 16/min. The patient denies dyspnea, fatigue, and syncope. Transthoracic echocardiography reveals a large, pedunculated tumor in the left atrium. What complication is this patient most at risk for?

567adceb-47a2-482e-8dad-40086ef44d41.question: An 8-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with respiratory distress, facial edema, and a skin rash after eating a buffet dinner with her family. She has a history of mild allergies to pet dander and ragweed, a severe peanut allergy, and asthma. She forgot her emergency inhaler and EpiPen. Vital signs include blood pressure 112/87 mm Hg, heart rate 111/min, respiratory rate 25/min, and temperature 37.2°C (99.0°F). Physical examination reveals severe facial edema and audible stridor. What is the most appropriate immediate next step in the management of this patient?

4bc7e6cb-daa9-4d87-8b79-cda4d0ab15d5.question: An investigator is studying the cell morphologies of the respiratory tract. He obtains a biopsy from the mainstem bronchus of a patient. On microscopic examination, the biopsy sample shows uniform squamous cells in layers. What histologic term best describes this finding?

6d81fcbd-2fc4-4250-9e19-51b28fc982b0.question: A 32-year-old female presents to her gynecologist with a history of irregular menstrual cycles over several years, severe facial acne, and dense black hairs on her upper lip, anterior hairline, and posterior neck. Ultrasound imaging demonstrates bilaterally enlarged ovaries containing multiple cysts. Based on these findings, what condition is this patient most likely at increased risk of developing?

588efb7f-e3f5-4385-8fe5-0c5ef1d9658a.question: A 52-year-old fisherman presents to the clinic for evaluation of a pigmented lesion on his neck that he first noticed last year and reports has been slowly enlarging. Dermatopathology confirms the lesion contains neoplastic cells of melanocytic origin. What characteristic(s) of this lesion would most likely be observed during physical examination?
588efb7f-e3f5-4385-8fe5-0c5ef1d9658a.correct_answer: Brown-black color in one area of the lesion to red-white in a different area

fe45dab0-7921-4f2f-a9b9-e80bbbbb0977.question: A 77-year-old woman presents with fatigue and headaches two days after hospital admission for a fall resulting in a right-sided subdural hematoma. Her medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia, managed with hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. Vital signs are normal, and physical/neurologic exams are unremarkable. Laboratory studies reveal serum sodium 130 mEq/L, serum osmolality 270 mOsmol/kg H₂O, urine sodium 45 mEq/L, and urine osmolality 326 mOsmol/kg H₂O. A repeat head CT shows no change in the subdural hematoma. Based on these findings, what is the most appropriate next step in management?

4d528039-ec4c-4d5b-9be6-8a76c9bbadad.question: An 18-month-old girl is brought to the pediatrician by her mother for vaginal bleeding. The mother noticed brown discharge with clots in the diaper today and reports the child has had left leg pain and limping since a fall 2 months ago. Physical examination reveals multiple 2-3 cm hyperpigmented trunk patches, bilateral breast enlargement without pubic hair, and a normal vaginal exam. Radiography of the left lower leg shows patchy lytic and sclerotic bone lesions in the femoral metaphysis. What is the most likely diagnosis associated with these findings?

3e4fd825-88bc-478e-b91f-6cc78641c73b.question: A 72-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for treatment of unstable angina. Cardiac catheterization reveals a 50% reduction in the diameter of the left circumflex artery due to occlusion. By what factor has the resistance to blood flow in this vessel increased compared to a vessel with no occlusion?

0b21982f-9d6d-48e8-8ba0-2c18fece2bc4.question: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of an irregular gait 3 days after receiving age-appropriate vaccinations. Examination of the lower extremities shows no redness or swelling. When the child stands on his right leg, his left leg drops and his pelvis tilts towards the left. Sensation to light touch is normal in both legs. Which anatomical location was most likely involved in the vaccine administration that caused these symptoms?
0b21982f-9d6d-48e8-8ba0-2c18fece2bc4.correct_answer: Superomedial quadrant of the right buttock

df9ebc44-f14b-43fe-a185-c3c725c65cff.question: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of decreased appetite and abdominal pain for the last several weeks. Physical examination shows a well-appearing toddler with a palpable left-sided abdominal mass that does not cross the midline. A CT of the abdomen reveals a large, necrotic tumor on the left kidney. Histological examination of the kidney mass shows primitive blastemal cells and immature tubules and glomeruli. Which embryological structure is the origin of this tumor tissue, and what other anatomical structure shares this same embryological derivation?

57e9c45c-bc22-479e-83b9-9ac708b34872.question: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician due to progressive hearing difficulty over several months, requiring increased speech volume for comprehension, and trouble seeing words clearly while reading. His father received a renal transplant in his 20s. Vital signs are normal. Laboratory studies reveal urine with blood 1+, protein 1+, and 15–17 RBCs/hpf. Audiometry demonstrates bilateral high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss, and ophthalmologic examination shows anterior lenticonus. What is the most likely diagnosis explaining these clinical findings?

e1164cde-d612-4b09-a50a-7bff1713faf7.question: A 16-year-old female presents to her primary care physician due to never having experienced menstruation despite breast development starting at age 13 and Tanner IV breast and pubic hair development. She reports recent headaches with photosensitivity and nausea, relieved by ibuprofen. Her family history includes migraines and bipolar disorder. Vital signs and laboratory studies, including FSH and estrogen levels, are within normal ranges. Abdominal ultrasound reveals normal uterine and ovarian anatomy. Pelvic exam is limited but shows no vaginal abnormalities in the visualized portion. What is the most likely diagnosis?

a786e88c-acfd-4304-ab49-690c498ff62d.question: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency room due to shortness of breath that started an hour ago while playing football with friends. He has had similar episodes in the past requiring hospitalization. Physical examination reveals a temperature of 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse rate of 100/min, respiratory rate of 28/min, blood pressure of 110/60 mm Hg, decreased breath sounds bilaterally, a peak expiratory flow rate of 200 L/min, and SpO2 of 89% on room air. After nebulization with an inhaled short-acting β-agonist and oxygen administration via mask, arterial blood gas analysis shows pH 7.48, PaO2 75 mm Hg (increased from 59 mm Hg), PaCO2 26 mm Hg, and HCO3- 26 mEq/L. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

7214afc3-c441-40ad-ba1f-1a9933928f3b.question: A 48-year-old homeless male is brought to the emergency department by police for altered mental status. Past medical records are unavailable. Physical exam on admission reveals scleral icterus and a flapping tremor of the wrists during extension. After admission and initiation of treatment, the patient reports eleven episodes of diarrhea and near-constant flatulence overnight, with improvement in mental status and resolution of the hand tremor. Which medication was most likely administered to this patient following admission?

1cf0b515-405a-4148-ab91-48d3ec21edba.question: A 61-year-old man presents to his primary care provider complaining of abdominal pain and constipation. He reports a 4-day history of steady right lower quadrant pain and has had one small bowel movement in 4 days, compared to his usual once-daily frequency. His medical history includes poorly controlled hypertension, hyperlipidemia, a 40 pack-year smoking history, and daily consumption of 3-4 beers. Medications include enalapril, hydrochlorothiazide, aspirin, and atorvastatin. Vital signs show a temperature of 101.8°F (38.8°C) and blood pressure of 160/95 mmHg. A prior colonoscopy revealed multiple small pedunculated polyps (removed), multiple colonic mucosal outpouchings, and no masses. Which disorder is most strongly associated with this patient’s clinical presentation and colonoscopic findings?

544d2c31-fa0f-4048-9450-436994beb869.question: A 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset of slurred speech and inability to move his arm. His medical history includes hypertension and a prior hemorrhagic stroke treated surgically. After admission, he deteriorates neurologically, loses consciousness, and imaging reveals a subarachnoid hemorrhage requiring surgical intervention. Postoperatively, he remains unresponsive, and repeat imaging shows an enlarging aneurysm in a different cerebral vessel. The patient’s daughter, his primary contact, refuses consent for a non-emergent, life-saving operation due to a history of familial abuse and neglect, stating she wants "to live in peace." The patient has no written advanced directive. What is the most appropriate course of action for the physician to take in this situation?
544d2c31-fa0f-4048-9450-436994beb869.correct_answer: Contact another family member for consent

7fcca200-a8be-4ce5-8a91-b3717b1408f3.question: A 50-year-old man with congestive heart failure (CHF) is started on an experimental analog of atrial natriuretic peptide. What three physiological effects would be expected in this patient as a result of this treatment?
7fcca200-a8be-4ce5-8a91-b3717b1408f3.correct_answer: Increased glomerular filtration rate, restricted aldosterone release, vascular smooth muscle dilation

ebd217af-d7bb-4153-85f4-31f956779eb2.question: A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency room after a motor vehicle accident. The patient’s vitals are as follows: blood pressure 80/40 mm Hg, heart rate 111/min, respiratory rate 39/min, and temperature 37.1°C (98.8℉). On physical examination, the patient is unconscious with a GCS of 9/15 and is cyanotic. There are open fractures of the left femur and left tibia, a likely shoulder dislocation, multiple contusions on the limbs and thorax, and a puncture wound on the left side of his chest. There are no breath sounds on the left side and there is hyperresonance to percussion on the left. Preparations are made for an emergency needle thoracostomy to treat this patient’s likely tension pneumothorax. What is the ethical and legal rationale for proceeding with the procedure without obtaining informed consent in this scenario?
ebd217af-d7bb-4153-85f4-31f956779eb2.correct_answer: Informed consent is not needed in this case

9bf8379b-f564-417c-96d5-555e0c76329e.question: A group of researchers aims to evaluate how frequently human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is associated with high-risk behaviors among female sex workers in their country and assess the relationship between HIV acquisition and specific sociodemographic factors. They collect behavioral and sociodemographic data via interviewer-administered questionnaires and conduct clinical/serological evaluations for HIV and other sexually transmitted infections. What is the main outcome measure of this study?

1abd854c-b9f7-4cd3-862e-ac301de3b6aa.question: A 53-year-old man presents to the physician with a 2-month history of multiple episodes of small amounts of blood in his stools. Examination reveals pale conjunctivae. His hemoglobin concentration is 8.3 g/dL, and his mean corpuscular volume is 72 μm³. Colonoscopy demonstrates a 2.3-cm polypoid mass in the ascending colon. A photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen of the lesion is reviewed. What pathogenic process is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?

bce68f28-d113-4f91-b33c-1009cde5caa6.question: A 68-year-old female presents to her primary care physician with a 7-month history of fatigue and low back pain. Her pain is not improved by over-the-counter analgesics. Laboratory analysis is notable for a calcium level of 11.5 mg/dL, creatinine level of 2.0 mg/dL, and blood urea nitrogen level of 30 mg/dL. Large eosinophilic casts are seen on renal biopsy. What peripheral blood smear finding is most likely associated with this patient’s condition?
bce68f28-d113-4f91-b33c-1009cde5caa6.correct_answer: Linear aggregations of red blood cells

705360af-21af-42ca-84c6-42678aee4566.question: A 95-year-old woman residing in a long-term care facility fell after tripping on a rug, resulting in severe right hip and buttock pain, inability to bear weight on her right leg, and physical findings of a foreshortened right leg in adduction with right buttock swelling. Radiographs confirmed a right posterior hip dislocation without fractures. Upon hospital arrival, she exhibited confusion, including disorientation to time and insistence on leaving immediately to see her family. Her medications include metformin, lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, metoprolol, and oxybutynin. Which medication is most likely contributing to her acute confusion?

00f2b175-f0ed-48fd-8faa-39188f6ed264.question: A 26-year-old woman comes to the clinic for an annual wellness examination. She is healthy with no prior history of significant illness, exercises 3-4 times a week, and eats a plant-based diet with no carbonated drinks. She reports recurring episodes of sneezing, congestion, and itchy eyes for the past year, but denies fever, sick contacts, cough, headaches, chest pain, urinary symptoms, or gastrointestinal issues during these episodes. The clinician recommends a medication to alleviate her symptoms as needed. What is the most likely mechanism of action of the prescribed medication?

df224a76-ea18-49f1-8146-d78b87e195d1.question: A 27-year-old woman presents to a dermatology clinic with episodic discoloration of her fingers progressing from white to red to blue. She reports increasing fatigue, muscle weakness, and weight loss despite no recent changes in her routine. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination shows regular heart and lung sounds. Laboratory testing reveals anti-U1 RNP antibodies and elevated creatinine kinase levels. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

eb14c0d2-9d48-4eef-90b2-0946e8300447.question: A 32-year-old woman presents to the physician with a 3-month history of depressed mood, insomnia, poor appetite, difficulty concentrating, low energy, and loss of interest in playing the guitar. She reports similar depressive episodes during high school, accompanied by recurrent binge eating and purging behaviors that required therapy. There is no current suicidal ideation. Given her medical history, which medication should be physician avoid prescribing for her current symptoms?

78fda6ef-31a9-46c9-85f4-5ed7afdde078.question: A 52-year-old man with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents for an annual physical examination. He reports progressive improvement in his vision over the past 6 months, allowing him to no longer need glasses for driving. His current medications include glyburide, hydrochlorothiazide, and enalapril. Ophthalmic examination reveals 20/20 vision bilaterally, and fundoscopy shows a few retinal microaneurysms. What is the most likely explanation for the improvement in this patient’s vision?

cdb9bfd8-ed5c-4591-a1b0-999624b04626.question: A 21-year-old woman presents to the emergency room with right arm pain and limited range of motion, though she does not recall any trauma to the arm. She also reports diarrhea, nausea, and pain during intercourse. Physical examination reveals vague and diffuse abdominal tenderness in all four quadrants, with no erythema or edema on the right arm. The fecal occult test is negative. Her medical history indicates seven prior emergency room visits in the past year for similar symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis?

36a88d3f-3e1e-4d2c-bdaf-72c6cc64bbcf.question: A 22-year-old man presents to a psychiatrist complaining of mood fluctuations. His mother reports a recent 5-day episode during which he required minimal sleep, exhibited unusually high energy levels, and impulsively spent $2,000 of his parents’ money on a motorcycle down payment. The episode resolved with subsequent feelings of guilt and distress. The patient’s medical history includes recurrent month-long episodes over the past 2 years characterized by sadness, hypersomnia, loss of interest in hobbies, fatigue, and guilt. At age 17, he had severe meningoencephalitis requiring intensive care, during which he experienced visual hallucinations. Current examination reveals a cooperative, well-appearing male with a normal affect who expresses sadness and guilt but denies suicidal ideation. What is the most likely diagnosis?

60c4be9e-2b79-4d3d-a347-4d6a1da20b4e.question: A 32-year-old woman with a known diagnosis of ulcerative colitis presents to the emergency department with a 5-week history of abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea that has acutely worsened over the past 24 hours. She reports poor adherence to her prescribed medication regimen. Vital signs include a temperature of 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse of 120/min, and blood pressure of 92/56 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals a distended, rigid abdomen with hypoactive bowel sounds. After initiating fluid resuscitation and placing the patient on complete bowel rest, what is the most appropriate next step in management?

a626921d-c23f-479a-bdd9-672eb6ba5a8c.question: A 55-year-old man recovering from knee replacement surgery complains of breathlessness in the postoperative ward. He has been confined to bed for the past 5 days and is under observation. He felt a sudden difficulty in breathing and called for the ward nurse. He says that he is unable to take deep breaths and has a sharp pain on the right side of his chest with each inspiration. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.8°F), pulse is 111/min, respirations are 31/min, and blood pressure is 85/55 mm Hg. He experiences pain in his right calf on dorsiflexion. There are no other prominent findings on physical examination. Chest X-ray is unremarkable, and ECG reveals sinus tachycardia. What is the best course of management for this patient at this time?

e8be7c8b-a495-428b-872b-660e1efa84e6.question: A 62-year-old man is brought to his primary care physician by his wife due to frequent falls. Over the past 6 months, she noticed he walks more slowly and has fallen over 6 times in the last month. The patient was previously active as a triathlete until age 60. His family history includes normal pressure hydrocephalus in his mother and Alzheimer dementia in his father. On examination, he has slowed and forced movements, a shuffling gait, and increased tone in all extremities. What histologic finding on brain autopsy is most strongly associated with this patient’s condition?

71efaae6-e977-40f7-b7e3-54d68da58d00.question: A 16-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for a regular check-up. His mother reports that he has not yet begun to walk and is exclusively breastfed. His growth percentiles are 20th for length, 10th for weight, and 50th for head circumference. Physical examination reveals enamel erosion on the lingual surface of the incisors, carious molars, frontal bossing, widened wrists, bowed legs, and rib beading. What is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's clinical findings?

9b72b5f1-7a6d-4bc1-82cc-fbf73e255c9d.question: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with altered mental status. The patient is in acute distress and cannot provide history due to disorientation. Vital signs include a temperature of 38.7°C (101.6°F), blood pressure of 80/50 mm Hg, pulse of 103/min, respiratory rate of 22/min, and BMI of 20 kg/m². Examination reveals icteric sclera and skin, with right upper quadrant tenderness on abdominal palpation. Laboratory results show leukocytosis (16,500/mm³), elevated total bilirubin (2.8 mg/dL), and a dilated common bile duct on abdominal ultrasound. After initial stabilization with intravenous fluids, dopamine, and broad-spectrum antibiotics, the patient’s blood pressure improves to 101/70 mm Hg. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

b025b877-db0f-48f0-b530-06639a0e8242.question: A 31-year-old woman presents to the physician with a 5-month history of intermittent flank pain and a 2-year history of recurrent urinary tract infections (five episodes). Her blood pressure is 150/88 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals bilateral, nontender upper abdominal masses. Serum studies demonstrate a urea nitrogen concentration of 29 mg/dL and a creatinine concentration of 1.4 mg/dL. Renal ultrasonography shows bilaterally enlarged kidneys containing multiple parenchymal anechoic masses. What is the most likely diagnosis?

8e43f05e-4a8e-4284-9c00-e3955a0b9ec3.question: A 39-year-old African-American woman presents to the emergency room with left hip and groin pain that has progressively worsened over the past 2 weeks. She has a history of sarcoidosis diagnosed 6 months ago and is undergoing treatment. Vital signs include a temperature of 98.1°F (36.7°C), blood pressure of 122/78 mm Hg, pulse of 80/min, respirations of 13/min, and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals pain with hip manipulation but no restriction in range of motion. What is the most sensitive test to evaluate her condition?

1ec3dc97-3000-489e-a219-2dd7aa043969.question: A 22-year-old man from Nepal presents to the emergency department complaining of swelling and pain in his right testicle. The patient states that he just arrived in the United States to live with his wife, with whom he is monogamous. The patient denies painful urination or urethral discharge but admits that 10 days ago he “felt like he had a fever” and the right side of his face was swollen and painful. What characteristic feature is associated with the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
1ec3dc97-3000-489e-a219-2dd7aa043969.correct_answer: Preventable by a live attenuated vaccine

703c1cca-beaa-4db4-b93f-2075021413d8.question: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 40 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. She reports severe pelvic pain. Her pregnancy has been complicated by gestational diabetes, though her first pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. Current medications include insulin, folic acid, and a multivitamin. Vital signs are initially within normal limits. Pelvic examination reveals a fully effaced cervix, 10 cm dilation, and the fetal vertex at -1 station. The fetal heart rate is reactive with no decelerations. After epidural anesthesia, her pain improves, but 10 minutes later, she experiences dizziness. Her pulse is 68/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure drops to 90/60 mm Hg. Intravenous fluid resuscitation is initiated. What is the most likely underlying cause of the patient’s hypotension?

fc799edc-3340-4efe-b340-4c4553139eb0.question: A 57-year-old woman with a history of sickle cell disease presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset dysarthria, left-sided facial droop, and garbled speech occurring after returning home from walking her dog. Her medical history includes asthma, and her medications are hydroxyurea, oxycodone as needed, and albuterol inhaler. Vital signs show a blood pressure of 145/72 mmHg, pulse 93/min, and oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. Physical examination confirms left-sided facial droop and dysarthria. What is the most appropriate therapeutic intervention for this patient?

93b75431-f29c-423e-8252-74246bc5204a.question: A 58-year-old male is hospitalized after sustaining multiple fractures in a severe automobile accident. Soon after hospitalization, he develops respiratory distress with crackles present bilaterally on physical examination. The patient does not respond to mechanical ventilation and 100% oxygen and quickly dies due to respiratory insufficiency. Autopsy reveals heavy, red lungs, and histology demonstrates a key pathological finding. What specific histological feature was most likely present in this patient's lungs shortly before death?

f9105ae5-b46f-4716-a542-b7156899e160.question: A 6-year-old African American boy is referred to the hospital with jaundice, normocytic anemia, and severe bone pain. He has a history of recurrent mild bone pain treated with over-the-counter analgesics. Physical examination reveals icterus, swollen and tender hands, and no fever, chest pain, abdominal pain, or hematuria. Lab results show total bilirubin 8.4 mg/dL, hemoglobin 6.5 g/dL, MCV 82.3 fL, reticulocytes 7%, and a peripheral blood smear displaying elongated and curved cell clumps along with erythrocytes containing nuclear remnants. Hemoglobin electrophoresis results are available. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

90e39aa6-24cd-4e8d-b053-fdaf5eed24e6.question: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with nausea, vomiting, palpitations, and dizziness lasting 3 hours. He has a history of heart failure and was recently started on verapamil for migraine prophylaxis while continuing low-dose aspirin and digoxin. His ECG shows paroxysmal atrial tachycardia with block, and his serum digoxin level is elevated at 3.7 ng/mL (therapeutic range: 0.8–2 ng/mL). What mechanism most likely contributed to the development of digitalis toxicity in this patient?

26eadbbc-f97b-4538-ade0-b992ca42e989.question: A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor-vehicle collision in which he was an unrestrained passenger. He has acute myeloid leukemia and is currently receiving chemotherapy. On arrival, his temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 63/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and sluggish. There are multiple bruises over the face, trunk, and right upper and lower extremities. There is a 4-cm (1.6-in) laceration over his right cheek. He does not respond to any commands but does groan. Painful stimuli cause him to open his eyes and withdraw all extremities. There are decreased breath sounds over the right lung base. There is tenderness to palpation over the left chest wall. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and shows diffuse tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. There is swelling of the right elbow and wrist. The right lower extremity is shorter than the left lower extremity. There are 2 lacerations around 2 cm (0.8 in) each on the right leg. The right knee is swollen. What is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?

0f0def74-a915-418c-a7c4-0bca6791ed1b.question: A 51-year-old woman was recently diagnosed with type II diabetes. Due to the cumulative effects of diabetes, various health screenings and vaccinations are routinely recommended. What specific annual screening measure is indicated for this patient?

a31003b7-f6e9-408d-a7a1-da3b3f9f86d0.question: A 23-year-old man presents with sudden loss of consciousness while pitching in a baseball game. There is no history of injury, and consciousness is regained after cardiopulmonary resuscitation. Past medical history is negative for neurological and cardiovascular problems. Physical examination reveals a prominent A wave on the jugular venous pulse and a double apical impulse. There are no audible murmurs, but an S4 is present. What is the most likely diagnosis?

778554ec-6993-4bb1-a5b4-24ce934bc490.question: A 39-year-old man is brought to the emergency department unconscious following 2 episodes of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. According to the attendants, he has complained of recurrent headaches for the past 2 weeks. There is no history of fever, head trauma, or a seizure disorder. The patient does not smoke cigarettes but reportedly drinks 2 glasses of wine daily. He has multiple sexual partners and history regarding contraceptive use is unavailable. The patient’s vitals include: blood pressure 137/88 mm Hg, temperature 37.2°C (99.0°F). On physical examination, he is obtunded. He grimaces on pain and localizes in response to pain in both upper extremities. Pupils are bilateral 3-mm in diameter and equally round and reactive. Laboratory tests are within normal limits. An MRI of the brain with contrast is performed, and a brain biopsy reveals perivascular clusters of lymphocytes. What viral agent is most commonly associated with this patient’s condition?

32b47816-0bd6-4436-b90d-91379277cb10.question: A 22-year-old woman from a rural area who recently discovered she was pregnant is referred for a cardiology consultation due to cyanosis, dyspnea, and a cardiac murmur revealed at the initial prenatal visit. She is gravida 1, para 0 with an estimated gestational age of 19 weeks. She reports the murmur was identified in childhood, but she was lost to follow-up and has not received proper monitoring in years. Currently, she experiences dizziness and worsening dyspnea on exertion during pregnancy, though she was asymptomatic prior to conception. Vital signs include blood pressure 125/60 mm Hg, heart rate 81/min, respiratory rate 13/min, and temperature 36.7°C (98.0°F). Examination reveals acrocyanosis, fixed splitting of S2, and a grade 3/6 midsystolic murmur best heard over the left upper sternal border. Which physiological change of pregnancy is most likely responsible for the exacerbation of her symptoms?

898baafd-870b-4c31-a2b7-c80fa1d80d7f.question: A 25-year-old man with a past medical history of constipation and fibromyalgia presents to the emergency department with generalized malaise and severe diarrhea. The patient states that he has not felt well for the past 24 hours and his symptoms are no longer tolerable. He denies taking any medications or illicit drugs and states he is generally healthy. His temperature is 99.3°F (37.4°C), blood pressure is 122/88 mmHg, pulse is 107/min, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam demonstrates an ill-appearing young man with rhinorrhea, lacrimation, piloerection, and dilated but reactive pupils. During placement of an ultrasound-guided IV, multiple scars are noted in the antecubital fossa, and he begins actively vomiting during the exam. What is an appropriate treatment for this patient’s symptoms?

a1bb0568-ddc9-4c91-92df-e1be474bb3a4.question: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with her husband to discuss her recent problem. They discovered a spider nest while cleaning their new house, after which she blacked out, woke up outside with a bandaged arm, and has since been unable to enter the house due to intense fear of spiders despite multiple attempts. Her husband reports she screamed, broke a window, and cut her arm while fleeing. She expresses a desire to overcome this irrational fear. What is the most effective treatment for her arachnophobia?

5097511a-c90f-48e0-9d0f-455df0627501.question: A 67-year-old man is brought to the physician due to increasing forgetfulness, unsteadiness, and recurrent falls over the past year, with worsening symptoms following each fall. He reports difficulty remembering recent conversations and appointments, repeats questions frequently, and has impaired short-term memory (0/5 objects recalled after 10 minutes). His medical history includes hypertension, coronary artery disease, and hypercholesterolemia. Current medications are aspirin, carvedilol, enalapril, and atorvastatin. Examination reveals a left temple bruise, unsteady gait, orientation to place and person only, left lower extremity muscle weakness, and a left Babinski sign. CT head findings are consistent with chronic changes. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

c77df97d-4cb1-4c6b-877f-e3de802ef372.question: A 28-year-old primigravid woman at 39 weeks gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. On examination, the cervix is 100% effaced and 10 cm dilated. After 5 minutes of pushing, there is a prolonged deceleration of the fetal heart rate to 90/min. An episiotomy is performed to expedite vaginal delivery. The anesthesiologist locates the ischial spines by palpating the posterolateral vaginal sidewall and administers an anesthetic. Three minutes later, pinching the posterior vulva does not provoke pain. Which structure is most likely also supplied by the anesthetized nerve?

115c58ba-e4e0-40a5-9655-f2b85f60235a.question: A 55-year-old woman with a history of HIV presents to the emergency department with progressive dyspnea, fever, and dry cough for the past 4 days. She has not been compliant with antiretroviral or prophylactic medication. On evaluation, the patient is in moderate respiratory distress. Vital signs include a temperature of 38.8°C (102.0°F), blood pressure of 124/82 mm Hg, pulse of 96/min, respiratory rate of 20/min, and pulse oximetry of 92% on 4 L oxygen by nasal cannula. Her CD4 count is 180 cells/μL. IV antibiotics and glucocorticoids are administered. After 30 minutes, the patient develops severe respiratory distress. Repeat vital signs show a temperature of 38.3°C (101.0°F), blood pressure of 80/50 mm Hg, pulse of 104/min, respiratory rate of 32/min, and pulse oximetry of 85% on nasal cannula. Physical examination reveals tracheal deviation to the left, absent breath sounds on the right side, and distended neck veins. Telemetry shows sinus tachycardia. What is the best next step in the management of this patient?

8ecfcf81-de2d-4d37-85ec-78fbd7f2b5c1.question: A 22-year-old woman with polycystic ovarian syndrome comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of left lower abdominal pain that began suddenly while she was running. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation over the left adnexa and rebound tenderness in the left lower quadrant, with no tenderness in the right lower quadrant. Urine pregnancy test is negative. An ultrasound is ordered to confirm the diagnosis of ruptured ovarian cyst. Visualization of fluid in which anatomical location would be most consistent with this diagnosis?

458524a3-fded-4d8c-bf59-a23b4618c523.question: A 47-year-old woman presents for a follow-up examination, reporting a 5-month history of hand tremors that occur only when reaching for objects or answering the phone. She has a history of major depressive disorder but has been off medications for 3 years. Her father had Parkinson's disease, and she consumes one glass of wine daily. On examination, she appears anxious, with a low-frequency tremor that worsens during purposeful movements, consistent overshooting of targets, and no tremor when her arms are outstretched. Neurological assessment reveals increased tone in the lower extremities and bilateral Babinski's sign. What is the most likely underlying cause of her symptoms?

de874ca3-2c11-4839-ba05-5a35767157bd.question: A 52-year-old man presents to the physician with generalized pruritus and raised, erythematous plaques on his hands, chest, and legs for 6 hours, along with clear nasal discharge and sneezing. His symptoms began abruptly 30 minutes after dining at a seafood restaurant, and he reports similar past episodes. He has a history of narrow-angle glaucoma four months prior and takes no medications. Nasal examination reveals clear serous secretions with edematous, erythematous mucosa and turbinates, and non-tender paranasal sinuses. What is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?

552b3b5a-d5d8-4418-9309-3238943c8402.question: A 19-year-old man in a 3-month relationship with a woman experiences frequent sexual fantasies about male coworkers. He lives in a conservative community and does not know any openly gay men. Two days ago, he joined a local group considered by many organizations to be a hate group. Together with the other members, he attacked a gay couple on their way home from dinner. Which psychological defense mechanism is most likely being demonstrated by this individual?

e504a396-850c-4e78-b07a-955f4960c818.question: A 66-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider with several days of left flank pain radiating to the abdomen and groin, along with pink-tinged urine. She reports months of fatigue and constipation but no fevers. Her medical history includes mild untreated hypertension. Vital signs are within normal limits. Workup reveals calcium oxalate nephrolithiasis with hypercalciuria, hypercalcemia, and elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH). What is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?

271d7562-5c50-49c9-bbbe-8595a9a4e382.question: A 23-year-old woman presents to her psychiatrist concerned about her mood, reporting persistent fatigue, anhedonia, psychomotor slowing, insomnia lasting several days at a time, and functional impairment. After initiating first-line therapy, she returns one week later with no symptom improvement and requests further intervention due to worsening work and academic performance. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

db046b2c-6ab5-4f38-bf13-59a5dad88b2e.question: A 16-year-old patient presents to the physician’s office with a 6-month history of amenorrhea following intentional dietary carbohydrate restriction, intensive exercise, and a weight loss of 18.0 kg over the past year and a half. She had menarche at age 12 with previously normal menstruation. Vital signs include blood pressure 100/60 mm Hg, heart rate 55/min, respiratory rate 12/min, and temperature 35.9°C. Physical examination demonstrates well-developed musculature, decreased adiposity, and a bone scan revealing reduced calcium mineral deposits. How does decreased adiposity contribute to the hormonal changes observed in this patient’s condition?
db046b2c-6ab5-4f38-bf13-59a5dad88b2e.correct_answer: Decreased adiposity contributes to hypoestrogenemia in this patient

db0b653b-5bc7-47e6-a981-2ff867ce8246.question: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with a 10-day history of fever and sore throat that acutely worsened over the past 2 days. Her sore throat is worse on the right side, and she has difficulty swallowing and opening her mouth due to pain. She reports a change in her voice over the last day. Vital signs show a temperature of 38.2°C (100.8°F), and physical examination reveals cervical lymphadenopathy, erythematous tonsils, swelling of the right tonsillar pillar, and leftward deviation of the uvula. Laboratory studies are within normal ranges except for a leukocyte count of 12,000/mm³. Based on this presentation, what is the most appropriate next step in management?
db0b653b-5bc7-47e6-a981-2ff867ce8246.correct_answer: Incision and drainage with intravenous ampicillin-sulbactam therapy

0f71428a-1f11-4013-8d88-49ec0e5072f1.question: A 26-year-old nurse presents with a 2-month history of fatigue, lower abdominal pain, and persistent belief that she has cancer despite negative diagnostic evaluations. She has been on sick leave due to work-related stress and requests diagnostic laparoscopy. Her medical history includes peptic ulcer disease treated with omeprazole. Physical examination reveals pallor, tachycardia, hypotension, dry mucous membranes, crusted lesions along left arm veins, a systolic ejection murmur, and proximal muscle weakness. Laboratory results show normocytic anemia (Hb 7.5 g/dL, MCV 89 μm³) with elevated reticulocytes (13.3%), normal electrolytes, and negative stool occult blood. Abdominal ultrasonography is unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis?

6e33f837-b1a1-44d1-9930-cfe90389ff9e.question: A 43-year-old woman developed low-grade fever, vomiting, and abdominal pain five days after undergoing an emergency appendectomy under general inhalational anesthesia in Haiti, during which she received a transfusion of 1 unit of packed red blood cells. She returned to the United States three days post-surgery with no prior serious medical history or medications. On examination, she has jaundice, hepatic tenderness, and hepatomegaly. Laboratory studies reveal elevated liver enzymes (AST 760 U/L), hyperbilirubinemia (total 3.8 mg/dL, direct 3.1 mg/dL), eosinophilia (13%), and thrombocytopenia (160,000/mm³). Serologic testing is negative for acute HAV, HBV, and HCV. Liver biopsy demonstrates massive centrilobular necrosis. What is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s condition?

c5fd03f1-8ec3-4db4-94f6-2c15662e3365.question: A 56-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of fatigue and painless bruising over her arms and trunk. She has also had several episodes of nosebleeds that resolved with compression after a few minutes. She recently completed treatment for a urinary tract infection. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Her last menstrual cycle was 5 years ago. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Home medications include metformin, amlodipine, and enalapril. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows pale conjunctivae, ecchymoses, and petechiae over the upper extremities, chest, and back. Laboratory studies reveal hemoglobin 8.7 g/dL, leukocyte count 1100/mm³, platelet count 54,000/mm³, reticulocyte count 0.1%, mean corpuscular volume 93 μm³, total bilirubin 1.1 mg/dL, and LDH 80 U/L. What diagnostic procedure is most likely to confirm the underlying cause of her condition?

2c88e783-e410-4c3e-b1b4-d0db7440b88d.question: A 35-year-old man returns to the clinic to follow up for his chronic stomach pain. At the last visit a few months ago, he reported persistent upper abdominal discomfort without hematemesis, significant weight loss, or risk factors such as medication use, smoking, or family history of gastric cancer. He was empirically started on a proton pump inhibitor (PPI), but his symptoms have not improved. The physician now orders a urease breath test. What is the most likely cause of this patient’s chronic stomach pain?

cc048c7a-f0ec-4857-98df-383a0953e55e.question: A 32-year-old G1P1 patient presents to her obstetrician after having a positive pregnancy test at home. She reports that she and her husband had been trying to have a child for the past three months. She has no history of sexually transmitted disease, intravenous drug use, or blood transfusions, and she has never traveled outside of the United States. She was up-to-date on all immunizations before her pregnancy. Ultrasound is consistent with an 8-week gestational sac. The patient requests as few tests as possible but does not want to compromise the health of her fetus. Which screening tests should be performed for all pregnant women in this scenario?

f825ee67-7508-40ec-a80b-945d4ad687fb.question: A 29-year-old man is referred by his marriage counselor to the outpatient psychiatry clinic. The patient’s wife reports that he is constantly complaining and critical of others, blames his recent job loss on his boss's jealousy, distrusts his neighbors, doubts her fidelity, and suspects the marriage counselor is biased. Which psychiatric disorder also belongs to the same cluster as this patient's condition?

202661a4-f32b-4d8f-bdea-55bbb29f1031.question: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by the police after being found unconscious and covered in bruises outside a local bar. His past medical history includes polysubstance abuse, depression, multiple suicide attempts, neuropathic pain, and schizophrenia. Initial workup reveals a normal head CT and arterial blood gas results as follows: pH 7.29, PaCO₂ 95 mm Hg, PaO₂ 70 mm Hg, and bicarbonate 24 mEq/L. What is the most likely etiology of this patient’s current presentation?

ad7f1ecf-c11a-4980-9bb2-2545f714118c.question: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents for an acute arm injury. The mother reports that they were walking in the park and the patient’s dad was swinging her in the air by her arms. The dad heard a click, after which the patient immediately began to cry. On examination, the patient is holding her right forearm in a pronated position with the elbow slightly flexed. Pain is localized to the lateral aspect of the elbow, and she refuses to use the affected limb. Passive flexion and extension of the elbow show full range of motion, but supination is limited and causes pain. What is the next step in management for this patient?

d73cd450-20e6-4b49-a434-63c9c99b548c.question: A 40-year-old male presents to your office complaining that he is too weak to climb stairs or brush his hair. He denies any headaches or change in vision. A muscle biopsy reveals CD8+ lymphocyte infiltration in the endomysium. What is the most likely diagnosis?

4a8f4d95-a230-4c3e-8ad2-41988daa958f.question: A 6-month-old boy presents to his pediatrician for a wellness examination. The mother reports that her child has difficulty rolling from his back to his front and sitting unsupported. The patient is able to smile and furrow his brow normally, but she has noticed that he has a weak cry and suck. He was born at 38 weeks gestation via a spontaneous vaginal delivery without complications and appeared "normal" until the past few weeks. On physical exam, extraocular muscle movements are intact, and a symmetric smile is seen. He has symmetric flaccid weakness of both upper and lower extremities, a bell-shaped chest, and diminished deep tendon reflexes. What is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

924aeaa5-c4cf-42ec-bf28-e5e5887c4982.question: A 6-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician because he has become increasingly irritable and restless over the past 2 days. During this period, he has had 12 bowel movements. He feeds 10 to 12 times a day. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation and weighed 1800 g (3 lb 15 oz); he currently weighs 1700 g (3 lb 12 oz). His mother has Graves' disease and received propylthiouracil during the last trimester of pregnancy. She has a history of intravenous heroin use. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 180/min, and respirations are 50/min. Examination shows mild diaphoresis and a firm 2-cm midline neck swelling. The lungs are clear to auscultation. What is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?

e3e5a917-4dbb-483a-a001-27c20485b6c1.question: A previously healthy 29-year-old man presents to the emergency department with burning on urination for several days, right ankle pain lasting 3 days, and left knee pain and swelling for 1 day. Two weeks ago, he experienced fever and bloody diarrhea treated with antibiotics. Examination reveals a small left knee effusion and bilateral conjunctival injection. What is the most likely additional physical examination finding in this patient?
e3e5a917-4dbb-483a-a001-27c20485b6c1.correct_answer: Tenderness at the insertion of the Achilles tendon

6c6ee915-bbbb-4c68-94e8-2fc1af14066d.question: A 36-year-old woman presents to the physician with a 3-month history of a painless neck lump that has gradually enlarged. Physical examination reveals a 2.5-cm firm, irregular left-sided neck mass that moves with swallowing, along with painless cervical lymphadenopathy. Neck ultrasound demonstrates a solitary left thyroid lobe lesion with increased vascularity and hyperechogenic punctate regions. A fine needle aspiration biopsy is planned. What is the most likely diagnosis?

c2b341b6-3556-4361-ac7a-b69fc4ea65a1.question: A 34-year-old man currently staying at an addiction center presents to the staff psychiatrist with diarrhea, painful muscle cramps, and pain over his abdomen, knees, and shoulder. He has been discontinuing heroin over the last month as part of his treatment plan. His medical history includes HIV, hepatitis B (HBV), and recent treatment for a Streptococcus pneumoniae infection. What is the most appropriate therapy to comprehensively manage his current symptoms?

820a236c-a082-4d0c-8a96-cd1de8674738.question: A 26-year-old man presents to his physician with a history of diarrhea and vomiting for the past 24 hours. On physical examination, his temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse rate is 110/min, blood pressure is 102/74 mm Hg, and respiratory rate is 16/min. A resident working under the physician plots a Darrow-Yannet diagram for the patient, which indicates a shift in fluid status represented by a green dotted line. What hormone is most likely to show increased secretion in this patient?

0687532d-dfb3-46ad-b968-30a046d73708.question: A 28-year-old female presents with episodic chest pain described as squeezing and tightness occurring every few days for 3 months, with no association to food or exercise. She can climb four flights of stairs daily without issues. Her medical history includes migraines. Vital signs and physical exam are unremarkable, and office EKG is normal. However, 24-hour ECG monitoring reveals transient ST elevations during pain episodes that resolve completely. The underlying mechanism of her chest pain is most similar to the pathophysiology of which clinical condition?

6a4ea87a-bdac-422b-ac61-0099fc2b7435.question: A 22-year-old gravida 1 presents to her physician at 15 weeks gestation for a prenatal appointment. She complains of a rash involving her chest, face, and arms, a watery nasal discharge, and mild bilateral knee pain lasting approximately 5 days. She reports contact with her younger sister, who was diagnosed with rubella 10 days ago. Her vaccination history is uncertain. Vital signs include a temperature of 37.6℃ (99.7℉). Examination reveals a maculopapular lacy rash on the trunk, extremities, and face.
