Serology results from one year ago and current testing both show negative rubella IgM, decreasing rubella IgG titers (1:128 to 1:64), and persistently high rubella IgG avidity. What is the appropriate next step in managing this patient?
6a4ea87a-bdac-422b-ac61-0099fc2b7435.correct_answer: Recommend additional serologic testing for parvovirus B19

3d38cf34-ad04-46a5-942e-324f932cfdeb.question: A 20-year-old woman presents with vaginal discharge, pruritus, and painful micturition for the past 5 days. She is sexually active with multiple partners and admits to using barrier protection inconsistently. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. The patient denies fever, chills, abdominal pain, menorrhagia, or flank pain. She is afebrile with normal vital signs. Speculum examination reveals vaginal erythema with a profuse, greenish-yellow, purulent, malodorous discharge. The vaginal pH is 5.5. Vaginal swab and urine samples are obtained for microscopy and culture, with results pending. What is the most likely diagnosis based on this clinical presentation?

5b3f77f8-cba7-4c3c-a510-aefba2cc118c.question: A 47-year-old female undergoes a thyroidectomy for treatment of Graves' disease. Post-operatively, she reports a hoarse voice and difficulty speaking. The suspected complication is due to nerve damage from the surgery. What is the embryologic origin of the nerve most likely responsible for this patient's hoarseness?

6e801e26-95f6-471f-af82-c70d8392f554.question: A 15-year-old boy with poorly controlled asthma presents to the emergency room complaining of severe shortness of breath. His mother reports that he had trouble breathing soon after he started playing soccer with some friends and was unable to use his inhaler as it was empty. His family history is notable for emphysema in his paternal uncle and cirrhosis in his maternal grandfather. The child’s temperature is 99.0°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg, pulse is 130/min, respirations are 28/min, and oxygen saturation is 91% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates wheezing bilaterally in all lung fields. The child is started on supplemental oxygen and a nebulized bronchodilator. What downstream effect of the nebulized bronchodilator contributes to its therapeutic action in this patient?

a4eef183-6d1a-4466-b8e2-58ece883b088.question: A 55-year-old man presents with a 2-month history of an increasing sensation of fullness in the upper left side of his abdomen, along with fatigue and dyspnea. His medical history is unremarkable, and he takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits except for a pulse of 90/min. Physical examination reveals pale conjunctivae and a spleen palpable 8 cm below the costal margin. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin 8 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume 90 μm³, leukocyte count 3,000/mm³, platelet count 85,000/mm³, and a peripheral blood smear demonstrating small lymphocytes with cell membrane projections. Bone marrow aspiration is unsuccessful, but immunophenotyping is positive for CD25. Based on this clinical presentation and diagnostic findings, what is the most effective pharmacotherapy for this patient at this time?

f489082e-1e51-4344-ba59-6b8813cc64c1.question: A 57-year-old man presents to the emergency department with confusion. His symptoms started a few days ago and have been gradually worsening. Initially, the patient had a fever and a cough which has progressed to abdominal pain, diarrhea, and confusion. His temperature is 102°F (38.9°C), blood pressure is 127/68 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Physical exam is notable for localized crackles and decreased breath sounds in the left lower lung field. The patient is confused and is answering questions inappropriately. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin of 12 g/dL, hematocrit of 36%, leukocyte count of 16,500/mm³ with normal differential, platelet count of 190,000/mm³, serum sodium of 130 mEq/L, chloride of 100 mEq/L, potassium of 4.3 mEq/L, bicarbonate of 25 mEq/L, BUN of 20 mg/dL, glucose of 99 mg/dL, creatinine of 1.1 mg/dL, and calcium of 10.2 mg/dL. What is the best diagnostic test to guide current therapy in this patient?

f05e3f31-7eb5-454a-b01e-23a2a9298f6f.question: A 45-year-old man presents to the physician because of a 1-day history of progressive pain and blurry vision in his right eye, with difficulty opening the eye due to discomfort. His left eye is unaffected. He wears contact lenses and has bronchial asthma managed with inhaled salbutamol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination reveals a visual acuity of 20/25 in the left eye and the ability to count fingers at 3 feet in the right eye. A photograph of the right eye is provided. What is the most likely diagnosis?

e8f10566-0826-40b7-be89-fdcd63c17ee0.question: A 50-year-old man presents to his physician with a 2-month history of chronic cough, aching joints in the hips and lower back, and malaise. He reports a hiking trip in the desert near Phoenix, Arizona, 4 months ago. His vital signs include a temperature of 38.6°C (101.4°F) and tachycardia. Imaging reveals right-sided lung consolidation, a subpleural opacity, pleural effusion, and hilar adenopathy. A lung biopsy shows necrotic granulomatous inflammation with multinucleated giant cells and spherules containing endospores. Laboratory tests are positive for Periodic acid-Schiff and silver methenamine stains but negative for acid-fast bacilli. What is the most likely diagnosis?

b59427c4-ab92-47d8-bbdc-35da4e46cf85.question: A 22-year-old man with sickle cell disease is brought to the emergency room for acute onset facial asymmetry and severe pain. He was in school when his teacher noted a drooping of his left face. His temperature is 99.9°F (37.7°C), blood pressure is 122/89 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for facial asymmetry and 4/5 strength in the patient's upper and lower extremity. A CT scan of the head does not demonstrate an intracranial bleed. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

ae80cc16-8192-4c75-9817-40549ec94866.question: A 3-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of a productive cough for 5 days. Over the past month, she has had several episodes of watery stools. She is exclusively breastfed every 3–4 hours for 15–20 minutes. She was delivered vaginally at 38 weeks' gestation at home and has not yet been evaluated by a physician. The mother reports that her child is not gaining weight. The mother had no prenatal care. The infant is at the 5th percentile for height and weight. The infant has not received any immunizations. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 155/min, respirations are 45/min, and blood pressure is 88/50 mm Hg. Oral examination shows white plaques covering the tongue and the palate. Rales are heard bilaterally on cardiopulmonary examination. Cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy is present. What diagnostic test is most likely to confirm the underlying condition in this patient?
ae80cc16-8192-4c75-9817-40549ec94866.correct_answer: Polymerase chain reaction for viral genes

e87e4721-7e4c-4755-867c-38c42abd344e.question: A 30-year-old primigravid woman at 22 weeks' gestation is brought to the emergency department by her husband for lethargy, nausea, and vomiting for 4 days. This morning she became drowsy. She returned from a business trip to Sudan 3 weeks ago. She denies eating any seafood while traveling. Medications include iron supplements and a multivitamin. Her immunizations are up-to-date and she has never received blood products. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 122/76 mm Hg. She is oriented to person and place. Examination shows jaundice and mild asterixis. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 22-week gestation. Laboratory studies reveal hemoglobin 11.2 g/dL, prothrombin time 18 sec (INR=2.0), total bilirubin 4.4 mg/dL, alkaline phosphatase 398 U/L, AST 4,702 U/L, ALT 3,551 U/L, lactate dehydrogenase 3,412 U/L, negative anti-nuclear antibody, anti-smooth muscle antibody, anti-CMV antibody, anti-EBV nuclear antigen antibody, and a negative HIV ELISA. What laboratory test is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

949a384e-749d-4a12-a71b-a00f9d6f65bc.question: A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to multiple episodes of nonbilious emesis for 3 days, including dark brown vomitus. He reports early satiety, progressive severe episodic epigastric pain partially relieved by food or antacids (worsening at night and several hours postprandially), and a 2 kg weight gain. His history includes heavy smoking, alcohol use, and a family history of colon cancer. Vital signs show tachycardia and hypotension. Physical examination reveals dry mucous membranes, left upper quadrant tenderness, a tympanitic epigastric mass, succussion splash, reduced bowel sounds, and positive occult blood in stool. Labs show hypokalemia, elevated urea nitrogen, and mild creatinine elevation. What is the underlying pathophysiological cause of this patient’s vomiting?

e32c050c-da59-4a78-a0ba-098a4de40c74.question: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of worsening shortness of breath for 6 hours. For the past 5 days, he has had intermittent stabbing pain in the middle of his chest that worsens with lying down or taking deep breaths. He has also had a runny nose and a dry cough for the past 2 weeks. He has hypercholesterolemia and hypertension. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 34 years. His current medications include atorvastatin, enalapril, and hydrochlorothiazide. He appears pale and sweaty. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 105/min, and respirations are 25/min. Blood pressure is 107/72 mm Hg during expiration and 86/65 mm Hg during inspiration. Examination shows jugular venous distention and pitting edema below the knees. What is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
e32c050c-da59-4a78-a0ba-098a4de40c74.correct_answer: Accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space

49618143-1089-4785-b446-034921f38206.question: A 70-year-old obese male presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset shortness of breath and cough that began while he was sleeping. His medical history includes type II diabetes, and his current medications are lisinopril, metformin, insulin, and fish oil. Physical examination reveals bipedal edema and jugular venous distention. Laboratory results show hypokalemia (3.2 mEq/L), elevated bicarbonate (31 mEq/L), and hypercalcemia (10.9 mg/dL). After treatment with BIPAP and medical therapy, his symptoms improve. What is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's clinical and laboratory findings?

1de80b82-a617-47d0-b69d-9cf8a1907461.question: A 23-year-old woman is seen by her primary care physician for fatigue. She reports always feeling slightly short of breath compared to her friends but did not consider it abnormal until starting a new exercise regimen. Physical examination reveals mild conjunctival pallor. A peripheral blood smear shows echinocytes without intracellular accumulations. She mentions several relatives with similar fatigue and pallor. What is the regulatory effect of protein kinase A on the rate-limiting enzyme of the biochemical pathway implicated in this patient's most likely condition?
1de80b82-a617-47d0-b69d-9cf8a1907461.correct_answer: It is inhibited by protein kinase A activity

8c0a94f6-c2a0-4f09-90ec-331dec4e4a8a.question: A 32-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of depressed mood, insomnia, poor appetite, low concentration, low energy, and loss of interest in playing the guitar. She reports similar episodes during high school accompanied by binge eating and purging behaviors, for which she received therapy. There is no evidence of suicidal ideation. The physician plans to prescribe medication for her current symptoms. Considering her medical history, which medication should be avoided in this patient?

e874c49d-cd6b-4059-b8d7-682e21fee0e3.question: A 5-month-old boy is brought to the physician with a 3-day history of fever and cough. His mother reports that he has had multiple episodes of loose stools over the past 3 months. He has been treated for otitis media 4 times and bronchiolitis 3 times since birth. He was born at 37 weeks' gestation, and the neonatal period was uncomplicated. He is at the 10th percentile for height and 3rd percentile for weight. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 126/min, and respirations are 35/min. Examination shows an erythematous scaly rash over his trunk and extremities. The white patches on the tongue and buccal mucosa bleed when scraped. Inspiratory crackles are heard in the right lung base. An X-ray of the chest shows an infiltrate in the right lower lobe and an absent thymic shadow. What is the most likely definitive treatment for this patient’s condition?

b78cedf4-575a-4479-8955-a01ce156976d.question: A 68-year-old woman presents six days after aortic valve replacement surgery with bluish discolorations around peripheral intravenous catheter sites, severe right leg pain, and physical findings of tender, erythematous calf swelling. Her history includes hypertension, major depressive disorder, daily alcohol use, and current medications of hydrochlorothiazide, aspirin, prophylactic unfractionated heparin, and fluoxetine. Laboratory studies reveal thrombocytopenia (platelet count 48,000/mm³) with normal prothrombin time and elevated activated partial thromboplastin time. What is the most likely underlying pathophysiological mechanism responsible for this patient's clinical presentation?

be642b4c-a20f-4627-bf9f-2d5aae7be569.question: A 55-year-old man with chronic hepatitis B virus infection presents with generalized fatigue and a 5.4 kg (12 lb) weight loss over the past 4 months. Physical examination reveals hepatomegaly. Laboratory studies show an α-fetoprotein concentration of 380 ng/mL (N < 10 ng/mL). Abdominal CT scan with contrast demonstrates a solitary mass in the left lobe of the liver that enhances during the arterial phase. What is the most likely underlying pathogenesis of this patient's condition?
be642b4c-a20f-4627-bf9f-2d5aae7be569.correct_answer:
Integration of foreign DNA into host genome
"

9547977d-c086-4ae7-9d4c-ce08a282e9ed.question: A 28-year-old woman with no significant past medical history presents to her primary care physician with increased menstrual bleeding over the past three months. She also notes easy bruising and bleeding from her gums when brushing her teeth. She is sexually active with multiple partners and has no history of intravenous drug use. Physical exam reveals petechiae and scattered ecchymoses on her bilateral upper and lower extremities. Urine beta-HCG is negative. Laboratory results show Hgb 13.0 g/dL, WBCs 6,000/mL, platelets 95,000/mL, PT 13.2s, aPTT 30s, and a peripheral blood smear with normocytic, normochromic red blood cells and few platelets without morphologic abnormalities. What diagnostic studies should be performed next?

bddc0f55-5464-4a09-8570-48dbeba7dd8d.question: A 6-year-old boy with a history of recurrent respiratory infections due to a chromosome 7 gene defect causing transmembrane protein dysfunction presents with persistent fever, cough, and thick purulent sputum. The pediatrician notes that mucus accumulation in his respiratory tract predisposes him to future infections. Based on his underlying condition and clinical course, what pathogen is most likely to infect this patient in adulthood?

7c94b54c-abbd-4290-82cd-aa5f8d812895.question: An 8-week-old male presents with his mother to the pediatrician for a well visit. The patient has been breastfed since birth, feeding for 30 minutes every 2-3 hours. His mother is concerned about insufficient milk production and reports he began regurgitating breastmilk through his nose and mouth after some feeds two weeks ago, appearing mildly upset during episodes but settling quickly and becoming hungry again. Limiting feed volume reduced regurgitation frequency. There is no diarrhea, hematochezia, or family history of food allergies, though her older son had similar vomiting that resolved by 12 months. Four weeks prior, his height and weight percentiles were 40th and 34th, now 37th and 36th. Physical exam reveals a responsive infant with normal abdominal findings and age-appropriate motor development. What is the best next step in management?

a8a6ad1f-922a-417f-8687-e08097386138.question: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a stab wound to the back. He reports pain at the injury site and left leg weakness. Physical examination reveals 2/5 strength in the left lower extremity, with deficits in vibration sense and light touch on the left lower extremity, and loss of pain and temperature sensation in the right lower extremity. What type of spinal cord lesion is most consistent with these findings?

27c2b7fa-c17e-409c-a5f2-b590e77de398.question: A 58-year-old African American man presents for his yearly wellness visit. He reports difficulty losing weight and desires assistance. His last normal colonoscopy was performed 8 years ago. Past medical history includes obstructive sleep apnea (managed with CPAP) and hypertension, treated with isosorbide dinitrate/hydralazine and aspirin 81 mg daily. He denies smoking or recreational drug use, consumes 1-2 beers weekly, and has a family history of prostate cancer in his father and hypertension with type 2 diabetes in his mother. Vital signs show a pulse of 97/min and blood pressure 120/75 mm Hg, with a BMI of 30 kg/m². Physical exam and fasting glucose (90 mg/dL) are unremarkable. Based on current guidelines, what preventative screening test is most appropriate to recommend for this patient at this time?

9c95ec41-16e6-450e-8075-4ba32c025263.question: A 34-year-old patient is brought to the emergency room after a motor vehicle accident. An EKG shows sinus tachycardia, and a chest radiograph reveals an enlarged cardiac silhouette. While observing sinus tachycardia on the patient's telemetry, you note that the radial pulse cannot be palpated during inspiration. What should be the next step in the management of this patient?

86749f47-0fc2-40a3-b949-f8997a66c4b9.question: A previously healthy 60-year-old man presents with progressively worsening shortness of breath over the past 2 months, occurring only during exertion, and occasional dry cough. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history. Vital signs show mild tachycardia and tachypnea. Lung examination reveals a prolonged expiratory phase and end-expiratory wheezing. Spirometry demonstrates an FEV1:FVC ratio of 62%, FEV1 at 60% of predicted, total lung capacity of 125% of predicted, and decreased DLCO. What is the most likely diagnosis?

b44b0482-a67d-4531-a15e-b203c1a0e03e.question: A 29-year-old G1P0 woman delivers a male infant at 38 weeks gestation via vaginal delivery. Immediately after birth, the newborn is noted to have loops of intestine protruding from the right side of the abdomen. APGAR scores are 7 at 1 minute and 9 at 5 minutes, with a heart rate of 125/min and respirations of 45/min. Physical examination reveals normal reflexes and no other visible defects. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
b44b0482-a67d-4531-a15e-b203c1a0e03e.correct_answer: Wrap the intestines in a sterile bowel bag

8f870e92-5e24-4fdc-b48d-e792cd02f4e2.question: A 54-year-old woman presents with fatigue, malaise, and shortness of breath over the past 5 months. Past medical history includes rheumatoid arthritis diagnosed 23 years ago, managed with naproxen as needed. Vital signs show a temperature of 36.9°C (98.4°F), blood pressure 135/88 mm Hg, and pulse 92/min. Physical examination reveals conjunctival pallor and bilateral ulnar deviation of the metacarpophalangeal joints. Laboratory results include hemoglobin 9.2 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume 76 fL, leukocyte count 7,000/mm³, platelet count 220,000/mm³, serum ferritin 310 ng/mL, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate 85 mm/h. What pathophysiological mechanism is most likely contributing to this patient's anemia?

ff64f3df-c7db-4dcd-9503-820847a3a8be.question: A six-year-old boy with a history of asthma and allergic rhinitis uses an albuterol inhaler as needed. His mother reports increased albuterol use to four times per week over the past month, nocturnal awakenings due to symptoms three times this month, and activity limitation during play. Vital signs are within normal limits, and lung auscultation reveals bilateral late expiratory wheezes. Based on current asthma management guidelines, what adjustment to his treatment regimen is most appropriate?

81a47440-0d43-4a15-adb1-776aa4e10de8.question: A 25-year-old woman presents with pelvic pain, unexplained weight loss despite increased appetite, chest palpitations, frequent diarrhea, and heat intolerance over several weeks. Physical examination reveals an unremarkable thyroid, but laboratory testing shows a TSH of 0.21 mIU/L. Pelvic ultrasound identifies a complex right ovarian structure. What is the most likely diagnosis explaining this patient's clinical presentation?

fb9a72e2-d305-4247-a165-5878d585ef25.question: An otherwise healthy 15-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with extreme fatigue and shortness of breath. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg, and pulse is 100/min. Past medical history is noncontributory, and he takes no medication. His father and aunt both suffer from mild anemia. On examination, he is very pale with an enlarged spleen. His hemoglobin is 5 g/dL, and platelet count is slightly reduced. A peripheral blood smear is obtained. Over the next 2 weeks, the patient recovers, and his hemoglobin rises to 11 g/dL. What is the most likely pattern of inheritance for the underlying disorder in this patient?

5d8e4a18-d9f6-4498-8073-ed932ae2bf42.question: A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department with dyspnea. He is alert and oriented. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals a pH of 7.33, pCO2 of 70 mmHg, and HCO3 of 33 mEq/L. Based on these findings, what is the most likely underlying condition causing this patient’s presentation?

74054cab-b0c8-4ce2-92d2-05116f304f73.question: A 23-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with fever, chest discomfort, tachypnea, pain, needle-like sensations in the upper extremities, and profuse sweating. He also complains of a gradual decrease in vision over the past 3 months. He is a bodybuilding competitor preparing for an upcoming competition and reports that his symptoms began abruptly 30 minutes after taking two foreign-manufactured fat-burning pills instead of his usual single dose. Vital signs include blood pressure 140/90 mm Hg, heart rate 137/min, respiratory rate 26/min, and temperature 39.9°C (103.8°F). Physical examination reveals a reddish maculopapular rash on the trunk, diminished lung and heart sounds, abdominal tenderness, rotational bilateral nystagmus with an alternating gaze-dependent fast component, and bilateral cataracts on ophthalmologic exam. Laboratory results show mild leukopenia and normal platelet count. What is the most likely underlying pathogenic mechanism responsible for this patient’s clinical presentation?
74054cab-b0c8-4ce2-92d2-05116f304f73.correct_answer: The drug caused uncoupling of the electron transport chain and oxidative phosphorylation.

b0efc99b-102c-44bd-b187-525adb0c5002.question: A 23-year-old woman presents with progressive fatigue and painful swelling of her right knee for 3 weeks. She is a professional ballet dancer with a BMI of 17 kg/m². Physical examination reveals knee tenderness, limited range of motion, swollen bleeding gums, diffuse petechiae on her abdomen and thighs, and laboratory findings including normal coagulation times but prolonged bleeding time. Arthrocentesis demonstrates bloody synovial fluid. Which cellular structure is most likely associated with the defective reaction underlying this patient's condition?

627d86db-250e-4c04-801a-ed194a0e46ca.question: A 24-year-old woman presents to the physician after having unprotected intercourse the previous day. She reports regular menstrual cycles since menarche at age 12, with her last menstrual period occurring 3 weeks ago. She has no significant medical history but has allergies to certain jewelry and metal alloys. A urine pregnancy test is negative, and she wishes to avoid pregnancy until completing college in six months. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

0339a8e1-8873-4541-b701-f48966a35793.question: A 27-year-old woman with a history of bipolar disorder presents for a 3-month follow-up after starting treatment with lithium. She reports compliance with her medication but no clinical improvement. She has no other medical history, takes no other medications, and has no known allergies. Vital signs and physical examination are unremarkable. After switching to a new medication, she returns 2 weeks later with an acute-onset rash on her torso characterized by targetoid lesions with vesicular centers, which developed 2 days prior and has worsened. She also reports a 1-week history of fever, lethargy, myalgia, and chills that resolved 3 days before the rash appeared. Which medication is most likely responsible for this patient’s current presentation?

1bb43cd2-99bc-4d39-82c5-f5f67845eb8a.question: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 6-month history of mild episodic abdominal pain. The episodes occur every 1–2 months and last for a few hours. The pain is located in the epigastrium, radiates to his back, and is occasionally associated with mild nausea. His mother is concerned about a hereditary component due to his older sister’s congenital heart disease diagnosis. He is otherwise healthy, has met all developmental milestones, and is at the 75th percentile for height and 65th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows no abdominal distention, guarding, or rebound tenderness. What congenital condition is most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?

96d7ce20-6980-405f-bf39-bf97b7a490b2.question: A healthy, full-term 1-day-old female is being evaluated after birth and is noted to have a cleft palate and a systolic ejection murmur at the second left intercostal space. A chest radiograph reveals a boot-shaped heart and absence of a thymus. An echocardiogram shows pulmonary stenosis with a hypertrophic right ventricular wall, ventricular septal defect, and overriding of the aorta. What additional clinical feature is most likely to be present in this patient?

c9466829-352f-470c-9cf7-2c050c2bef6c.question: A 58-year-old male with a history of obesity and hypertension presents to his primary care physician for a follow-up visit. He reports feeling well with no complaints and is currently taking hydrochlorothiazide. His vital signs are within normal limits, with a BMI of 31 kg/m². Lipid panel results show a total cholesterol of 280 mg/dl, triglycerides of 110 mg/dl, HDL cholesterol of 40 mg/dl, and LDL cholesterol of 195 mg/dl. The physician considers initiating atorvastatin therapy. Which biochemical substance is most likely to decrease following the initiation of this medication?

85e845aa-1689-4db4-9f18-88c256ec0d7b.question: A 54-year-old man presents with the acute onset of seizures and hallucinations. The patient’s wife reports that he had been on a camping trip a few months earlier to study bats but otherwise has not traveled recently. Past medical history includes hypertension, managed with hydralazine and enalapril. The patient’s condition rapidly deteriorates, resulting in death. An autopsy is performed, and a histologic stained section of the brain is analyzed. Which specific type of receptor is targeted by the pathogen most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?

1a015302-3219-424f-8eed-a64abe62eb6c.question: A 60-year-old female patient with a history of hypertension presents to an outpatient office for a regular check-up and is found to have hypertriglyceridemia. Her physician prescribes high-dose niacin and recommends taking the medication along with aspirin. The physician is trying to avoid a specific side effect of niacin therapy. What is the proposed mechanism underlying this side effect that aspirin helps prevent?

daf7ca1f-70ad-4919-9edc-dab42b89bbdb.question: A 42-year-old man comes to the physician after elevated liver function tests were found during routine screening. He has had occasional headaches over the past year but otherwise feels well. The patient reports a severe car accident 30 years ago. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit intravenous drugs, takes no medications, and has no known allergies. His father had a history of alcoholism and died of liver cancer. Vital signs show a temperature of 37.8°C (100°F), pulse of 100/min, and blood pressure of 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory studies reveal hepatitis C antibody positivity, HCV RNA positivity, and genotype 1. A liver biopsy demonstrates mononuclear infiltrates limited to portal tracts and periportal hepatocyte necrosis. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

a6cb8c00-a384-463e-8840-fb6bf966427f.question: A 44-year-old woman with hypothyroidism presents with a 1-month history of tingling in her feet, poor balance, conjunctival pallor, and ataxic gait. She has decreased proprioception and vibration sense in her toes, macrocytic anemia, normal thyroid hormone levels, and endoscopic findings of gastric body and fundus atrophy with normal antral mucosa. Which specific gastric structure is most likely targeted by autoantibodies in this patient?

6218e3ef-cbce-4797-8c31-90efe440995c.question: A 26-year-old female presents with frequent, large-volume urination and increased thirst, which disrupt her sleep. She has a history of bipolar disorder treated with lithium for 3 years. Laboratory results show a serum osmolality of 425 mOsm/kg and urine osmolality of 176 mOsm/kg. What pathophysiological mechanism best explains the observed serum and urine osmolality findings in this patient?
6218e3ef-cbce-4797-8c31-90efe440995c.correct_answer: ADH resistance in the renal collecting ducts

4cbe7a07-f170-427b-8484-c507569996fc.question: An 8-year-old girl presents to her pediatrician with intensely pruritic lesions over her buttocks, which occur intermittently but have worsened over time. Her medical history includes iron deficiency treated with ferrous sulfate and intermittent episodes of diarrhea previously diagnosed as lactose intolerance. Her height is at the 30th percentile and weight at the 25th percentile for her age and sex. An immunoglobulin A (IgA) tissue transglutaminase titer is 5 times the upper limit of normal. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

08ae6f23-64e7-4a5b-bd99-52a7e8652fc7.question: A 64-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of lower back pain, fever, and chills, accompanied by nausea. His medical history includes hypertension, chronic kidney disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and a left third toe amputation 3 months prior due to a non-healing ulcer. He reports smoking one pack of cigarettes daily for 48 years. Current medications are hydrochlorothiazide, metoprolol, and insulin. Vital signs show a temperature of 39.4°C (102.9°F), pulse 102/min, blood pressure 150/94 mm Hg, and respirations 18/min. Physical examination reveals a 1-cm round ulcer on the right foot sole and left-sided costovertebral angle tenderness. Laboratory results include hemoglobin 11.5 g/dL, leukocyte count 19,000/mm³, serum creatinine 2.4 mg/dL, glucose 240 mg/dL, and urinalysis showing 1+ blood, 1+ protein, 100 WBC/hpf, 2+ nitrites, and numerous WBC casts. Urine and blood cultures are pending. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

f9424632-95fa-4a10-a17d-1540d50c5ddf.question: A 56-year-old man with a history of pancreatic cancer presents to the surgical intensive care unit following a pancreaticoduodenectomy. Over the next 3 days, the patient's drainage output exceeds 1 liter per day. On postoperative day 4, he is difficult to arouse, with a temperature of 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure of 107/88 mmHg, pulse of 120/min, respiratory rate of 17/min, and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. Physical exam reveals dry skin and mucous membranes. Laboratory results include serum Na+ 154 mEq/L, Cl- 100 mEq/L, K+ 4.3 mEq/L, HCO3- 27 mEq/L, BUN 20 mg/dL, glucose 99 mg/dL, and creatinine 1.1 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?

b3a0f154-5fd2-42e7-b98a-f873ff02be3b.question: A 46-year-old woman presents with a 3-day history of diarrhea, moderate abdominal pain, and weakness. Her symptoms began after eating an in-flight meal during her return from a 2-week yoga retreat in India, where she stayed at a resort. She reports mild nausea before boarding the flight, followed by watery diarrhea occurring up to five times daily. Her medical history includes gastroesophageal reflux disease and a shellfish allergy, and she takes ranitidine. Vital signs show a temperature of 37°C (98.6°F), pulse 70/min, and blood pressure 115/72 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals lethargy, diffuse abdominal tenderness without guarding or rebound, and hyperactive bowel sounds. What is the most likely pathogen responsible for this patient's condition?

43ac13a6-057d-417c-9cbf-43dbded1c647.question: A research group has created a novel screening test for a rare disorder. A robust clinical trial is performed in a group of 100 subjects comparing the new screening test against the gold standard. The results are as follows: 45 true positives, 5 false negatives, 15 false positives, and 35 true negatives. How does a decrease in the sensitivity of this screening test affect its statistical power?
43ac13a6-057d-417c-9cbf-43dbded1c647.correct_answer: If the sensitivity of this screening test were decreased, the statistical power would decrease.

0fbd7538-760c-4358-bb0d-fa9c6520adeb.question: A 25-year-old woman presents to her new family physician for a follow-up appointment. She previously presented with itching, frequent urination, and dysuria. A vaginal swab revealed diplococci on Gram stain and growth on Thayer-Martin agar. The patient reports practicing safe sex and has a history of meningitis and Streptococcus pneumoniae infection. The physician attributes these infections to a defect in the innate immune system. What function of the deficient innate immune component is most likely responsible for this patient’s susceptibility to these infections?
0fbd7538-760c-4358-bb0d-fa9c6520adeb.correct_answer: Creates pores in the cell membrane

8382c1a8-5ffa-4bb6-b8fe-5c9a332c3ade.question: A 55-year-old woman with papillary thyroid carcinoma underwent total thyroidectomy. On postoperative day 1, she developed perioral numbness, tingling in the hands and feet, anxiety, confusion, and latent tetany in the right arm demonstrated by carpal spasm after sphygmomanometer cuff inflation. Laboratory results show serum calcium of 6.7 mg/dL and magnesium of 1.1 mEq/L. What is the most likely cause of this patient's clinical presentation?
8382c1a8-5ffa-4bb6-b8fe-5c9a332c3ade.correct_answer: Inadvertent surgical removal of parathyroid glands

8434bf05-137e-4513-b876-583edd376dea.question: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for evaluation of fatigue lasting several weeks. The parents report their son quit sports due to low energy, and his academic performance has declined. He spends most of his time playing video games and eating cereal. His mother has Hashimoto's thyroiditis, and his father has major depressive disorder. Vital signs are normal. Examination reveals conjunctival pallor, angular cheilitis, and koilonychia. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin 11.5 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume 76 μm³, red cell distribution width 18%, and normal leukocyte and platelet counts. What is the most appropriate initial step in treatment?

c1768291-f07a-4489-a426-f5bdf7e68031.question: A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to a 1-day history of painful enlarging bruises and skin ulceration over his thighs and external genitalia. His medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus, mitral regurgitation, and atrial fibrillation. He was started on warfarin therapy three days ago, with metformin and lisinopril as his only other medications. Vital signs show a temperature of 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse of 108/min (irregularly irregular), and blood pressure of 155/89 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals large purpura, hemorrhagic bullae, and areas of skin necrosis on his anterior legs, gluteal region, and penis. What treatment is most likely to benefit this patient?

4fb33981-e085-41d8-bf53-63bb23266ff6.question: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of a learning disability. His teachers report hyperactivity during class, difficulties with social interaction, and poor scores on reading and writing assessments. Molecular analysis reveals an increased number of CGG trinucleotide repeats. What physical examination findings are most likely present in this patient?
4fb33981-e085-41d8-bf53-63bb23266ff6.correct_answer: Long face and large everted ears

16b79068-5bc6-4bae-a598-5278b3b92097.question: A 65-year-old woman presented to the emergency room due to progressive dyspnea. She is a known hypertensive but is poorly compliant with medications. The patient reports orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, and easy fatigability. On physical examination, her blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg, with prominent neck vein distention, an S3 gallop, bibasilar crackles, and grade 3 bipedal edema. A 2D echocardiogram revealed a decreased ejection fraction of 32%. Which medication is contraindicated in this patient's current clinical presentation?

cde4291d-ea00-428d-91b2-20f1f484bce6.question: A 49-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with progressive dyspnea and cough that developed approximately 8 hours ago. Two weeks ago, she underwent a prophylactic ovariectomy due to a family history of ovarian cancer. Her medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus, stage 1 hypertension (untreated), opioid abuse, and a 22-pack-year smoking history. Current medications are metformin 1000 mg and aspirin 81 mg. Vital signs show blood pressure 155/80 mm Hg, heart rate 101/min, respiratory rate 31/min, temperature 37.9°C (100.2°F), and oxygen saturation 89% on room air. Physical examination reveals dyspnea, acrocyanosis, bilateral lower lobe rales, S2 accentuation, and an S3 gallop. Arterial blood gas analysis demonstrates pH 7.49, PaO₂ 58 mm Hg, PaCO₂ 30 mm Hg, and HCO₃⁻ 22 mEq/L. What is the most likely pathophysiological mechanism underlying this patient’s respiratory failure?
cde4291d-ea00-428d-91b2-20f1f484bce6.correct_answer: Increased alveolar dead space due to absent perfusion of certain alveoli

251cc0ec-c9b3-4f15-a1b4-52042fc1aa01.question: A 27-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with acute onset bloody diarrhea. She reports a lifelong history of severe abdominal pain with occasional bloody stools, recent unintentional weight loss of 7 pounds, and generalized malaise for the past 2 days. Her medical history includes generalized seizures, with the most recent episode 5 days ago, and treatment for impetigo one month prior. She admits to cocaine use and binge drinking. Vital signs show tachycardia (127/min) and mild hypotension (107/58 mmHg). Physical exam reveals diffuse abdominal tenderness and guaiac-positive stools. Laboratory results demonstrate anemia (Hb 9 g/dL), elevated creatinine (1.8 mg/dL), mildly increased AST/ALT, and proteinuria. Urine drug screen is positive for cocaine and marijuana. What is the most likely underlying pathophysiological process responsible for this patient's laboratory findings?

15fd6f19-df39-4b4e-94fd-8b700a689ae9.question: A 45-year-old Caucasian male presents to a gastroenterologist complaining of heartburn and difficulty swallowing. He has a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) diagnosed by his primary care physician. The gastroenterologist performs an upper endoscopy with biopsy. What endoscopic finding would be consistent with Barrett's esophagus in this patient?
15fd6f19-df39-4b4e-94fd-8b700a689ae9.correct_answer: A small region of red, velvet-like mucosa in the lower esophagus

fa1758c5-2020-4fb7-b274-a2bd997c7c8c.question: A 16-year-old female patient with a history of intellectual disability presents to your clinic with her mother. The mother requests bilateral tubal ligation for her daughter after discovering her viewing pornographic materials, expressing concerns about her daughter's inability to understand the consequences of sexual intercourse or raising a child. During discussions, the patient demonstrates no comprehension of the link between sexual activity and pregnancy. What should be the next step in managing this case, and which ethical principle guides this decision?
fa1758c5-2020-4fb7-b274-a2bd997c7c8c.correct_answer: Refuse the procedure because it violates the ethical principle of autonomy

2a28aac5-4b92-4126-a3b2-57461f1318d2.question: A 51-year-old man presents to his primary care provider complaining of malaise. He returned from a research trip to Madagascar 2 weeks ago and has since developed a worsening fever with a maximum temperature of 102.2°F (39°C). He also reports swelling around his neck and groin. He works as a zoologist and was in rural Madagascar studying a rare species of lemur. His past medical history includes hypertension and gout, and he takes lisinopril and allopurinol. His temperature is 101.9°F (38.3°C), blood pressure is 145/85 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 22/min. Physical examination reveals painful erythematous cervical, axillary, and inguinal lymphadenopathy, as well as black hemorrhagic eschars on his fingertips bilaterally. What is the primary function of the virulence factor produced by the pathogen responsible for this patient’s condition?

b3cf9eb1-8214-428a-9672-72e52cd9fcdb.question: A 45-year-old African-American male with diabetes is prescribed miglitol, which his physician instructs him to take with the first bite of each meal. What type of chemical bond cleavage is inhibited by miglitol in this patient's treatment?

db1c7cef-4015-45a5-8cd5-5d129674c027.question: A previously healthy 24-year-old man presents with a 1-day history of burning pain, swelling, and multiple blisters over the left index finger. He works as a dental assistant and recently returned from a hunting trip where he encountered poison oak. His vital signs are normal, and physical examination reveals erythema, swelling, and 3-mm vesicles in the pulp space of the affected finger. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 12,000 cells/mm³. Given this clinical presentation, what is the most appropriate next step in management after initiating supportive therapy?

b2560316-962d-444f-8d9c-79b0c6808c74.question: A 63-year-old man presents to the ambulatory medical clinic with symptoms of dysphagia and heartburn that have worsened over the past year. His medical history includes hypertension and GERD, with inadequate response to multiple therapies. Physical examination reveals upper abdominal tenderness, and a barium swallow demonstrates a subdiaphragmatic gastroesophageal junction with herniation of the gastric fundus into the left hemithorax. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient's underlying condition?

09051ad4-0e17-4595-97c1-a7f208bf0bca.question: A 63-year-old man is admitted to the intensive care unit for hemodynamic instability. Several days prior, he had been swimming in the Gulf coast when he stepped on a sharp rock and cut his right foot. Three days ago, he presented to the emergency room after noticing painful redness spreading along his skin from his right foot and was subsequently admitted for antibiotic treatment. Currently, his temperature is 101.8°F (38.8°C), blood pressure is 84/46 mmHg with a mean arterial pressure of 59 mmHg, pulse is 104/min, and respirations are 14/min. Telemetry shows sinus tachycardia. Blood cultures are pending, but Gram stain demonstrated gram-negative bacilli. What type of shock is this patient most likely experiencing, and what skin findings would be expected in this condition?

95cafe93-d770-48cc-a60b-fabff12617de.question: A 24-year-old female presents to the emergency department with an inability to urinate, preceded by transient speech and vision disturbances that resolved a month ago. She reports severe facial pain two days ago exacerbated by brushing her teeth and plucking facial hairs. Her history includes recent sexual abuse, and physical exam reveals leftward gaze limited to the ipsilateral eye. Vital signs are normal. What is the best initial diagnostic test for this patient's presentation?

3bdf1624-a10d-4611-941a-d757a333c9f2.question: A 54-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her brother for confusion and agitation. She is unable to personally give a history. Her brother reports a history of alcohol use disorder and found an empty vodka bottle at her home. She appears disheveled. Vital signs include a temperature of 37°C (98.6°F), pulse 85/min, and blood pressure 140/95 mm Hg. Mental status examination reveals confusion with orientation only to person, 0/3 word recall after 5 minutes, inability to perform serial sevens, and failure to repeat seven digits forward or five in reverse. Neurologic examination demonstrates horizontal nystagmus on lateral gaze and gait instability requiring assistance. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin 11 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume 110 μm³, and platelet count 280,000/mm³. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?

2a518452-1124-43ea-be39-6106563feb7d.question: An 18-year-old woman presents for her first gynecologic examination and reports a 1-week history of yellow-green, malodorous vaginal discharge with mild pelvic and abdominal pain. She had sexual debut 3 weeks prior. Pelvic examination reveals cervical motion tenderness, a pink inflamed nulliparous cervix with small red punctate spots, and frothy white discharge in the vaginal vault. A wet mount shows numerous squamous cells and motile organisms. What is the most likely causative organism of this sexually transmitted infection?

68a5d70b-afc8-4d2a-b1e8-975b8bbe427b.question: A 70-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter due to progressive forgetfulness over the past 3 years, including forgetting family members' names and failing to complete routine tasks. Over the past year, he has become disoriented in familiar locations, neglected care responsibilities, and withdrawn socially. He exhibits indifference to his memory deficits and is oriented only to person during mental status examination, with significant short- and long-term memory impairment. What neurotransmitter system should be targeted by the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy for this patient?

93f9fc7f-1d49-4739-b1ae-e12e64ed3459.question: A 45-year-old mechanic presents to the emergency department complaining of acute-onset shortness of breath while repairing a plowing tractor for his neighbor. The patient denies having any history of asthma or respiratory symptoms and does not smoke. His temperature is 99.8°F (37.7°C), pulse is 65/min, blood pressure is 126/86 mmHg, and respirations are 20/min. His oxygen saturation is 97%. On exam, he is pale and diaphoretic. His pupils are contracted. Diffuse wheezes are noted in all lung fields. What is the best treatment for this patient's condition?

2402a3d9-155d-4df7-9646-fa9759051d88.question: A 3-year-old male is brought to his pediatrician by his mother due to concerns about inadequate growth. Physical examination reveals frontal bossing, shortened upper and lower extremities, and a normal axial skeleton. His height is at the 7th percentile, while his head circumference is at the 95th percentile. He exhibits normal intelligence, speaks in three-word sentences, first sat without support at twelve months, and began walking at 24 months. Genetic testing identifies an activating mutation in a growth factor receptor. Which physiologic process is most likely disrupted in this patient's condition?

91142f3b-ab6b-4f20-9d4f-a666e8c7d569.question: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician 2 weeks after noticing a lump in her left breast. Examination of the left breast shows a firm, nontender mass close to the nipple. Mammography reveals an irregular calcified mass. A core needle biopsy confirms invasive ductal carcinoma. Which gene is most likely overexpressed in the genetic analysis of this patient's cancer cells?

b39d39e8-9532-4f70-a4f5-113964d9800f.question: A 45-year-old man comes to his primary-care doctor with his wife for a 4-week history of constipation. The patient reports that his bowel habits have changed from every day to every 3 or 4 days, and he now has to strain to pass stool. His wife notes he has seemed fatigued, with little interest in their usual afternoon walks. His medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia, both managed medically. Physical examination is unremarkable. What cellular target of the patient’s current medication is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
b39d39e8-9532-4f70-a4f5-113964d9800f.correct_answer: Na+/Cl- cotransporter in the membranes of epithelial cells in the distal convoluted tubule

9eea8eb9-3f9e-4266-9c87-5ed0bc847e5a.question: A 23-year-old man presents to the office with a circular, itchy rash on his abdomen that has progressively worsened over the past 2 weeks. His medical history includes chronic dermatitis and chronic sinusitis, managed with topical hydrocortisone and fexofenadine. Physical examination reveals a 2 x 2 cm erythematous, annular plaque on the abdomen, and a KOH preparation from skin scrapings confirms the presence of hyphae. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

afd88121-b937-4b0d-a111-9947ce2c7ea7.question: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of persistent bleeding from his nose over the past hour. The bleeding started spontaneously, and he has no history of similar episodes, takes no medications, and reports no family history of abnormal bleeding. Vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, he is pressing a gauze against his left nostril while hyperextending his head. The gauze is stained with blood, and upon withdrawal, blood slowly drips out of his left nostril. The right nostril shows no bleeding, and the remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. What is the most appropriate initial therapy for this patient?
afd88121-b937-4b0d-a111-9947ce2c7ea7.correct_answer: Squeezing the nostrils manually for 10 minutes with the head elevated

359fdbdb-65b2-4aab-80e8-45b01aee126a.question: A 40-year-old female presents to the office complaining of a tender neck and general lethargy. She reports decreased appetite, fatigue, constipation, and jaw pain. Her pulse is 60 bpm, and blood pressure is 130/110 mm Hg. A thyroid biopsy reveals granulomatous inflammation and multinucleate giant cells surrounding fragmented colloid. What is the most likely precipitating factor for this patient’s condition?

a9dbe0e7-5b16-4cd3-8a96-90213c87bf3b.question: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency room by the police after a fall. The patient smells of alcohol and is slurring his words. He was recently fired from his job as a salesperson for months of tardiness and poor performance. The police report that his girlfriend mentioned he has struggled with alcohol use for at least a year. During physical examination, the patient becomes agitated, yells, and accuses his ex-boss of being a cocaine addict, stating he couldn’t maintain sales percentages compared to someone using cocaine. Which psychiatric defense mechanism is this patient most likely exhibiting?

84204482-4719-4b9c-aa0e-57d5328003e7.question: A 65-year-old woman presents to a physician with painful ankles for 2 days. Her symptoms began 1 week ago with a severe fever (40°C (104°F)) for 3 days. When the fever subsided, she developed a maculopapular rash over the trunk and extremities with painful wrists and fingers. She also reports abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and headaches. Last week she returned from a trip to Africa where she spent several weeks in rural areas. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F); pulse is 75/min; respiratory rate is 13/min; blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals a maculopapular rash over the trunk and limbs, swollen and painful ankles on motion, and a soft abdomen without organomegaly. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin 11.4 g/dL, leukocyte count 4,500/mm³, and absence of ring-form trophozoites on peripheral blood smear. What is the most likely causative organism of this patient’s illness?

e2e1db17-0a6d-413d-92d3-fb12c11eb56e.question: A 61-year-old man complaining of unexplained bleeding from the mouth is escorted to the emergency department by corrections officers. Upon examination, the patient states he feels nauseated and begins to retch violently, vomiting bright red blood. His past medical history includes cirrhosis secondary to alcohol abuse and untreated hepatitis C. His current blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg, heart rate is 128/min, and oxygen saturation in room air is 88%. He expresses fear of dying and insists that "everything be done" to save his life. IV fluids are initiated, packed RBCs are ordered, and lab results reveal elevated beta-hydroxybutyrate, ammonia, and lactate. What is the most appropriate action for the physician to take in response to the patient’s expressed wishes?
e2e1db17-0a6d-413d-92d3-fb12c11eb56e.correct_answer: Accept the patient's wishes and ensure he receives appropriate care.

e9b591fa-a3f0-4ea5-9080-1c96f99a25b0.question: A 43-year-old woman presents with swelling of her right leg three days after undergoing a laparoscopic Whipple's procedure. She reports nausea but no pain or vomiting. Her medical history includes pancreatic cancer diagnosed one month ago. She has been using an incentive spirometer regularly and previously took a multivitamin and herbal weight-loss supplement. Vital signs show a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F), pulse 90/min, and blood pressure 118/78 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals mild right thigh-to-ankle swelling without erythema, pitting edema, or a positive Homan's sign. The abdomen is diffusely tender but soft, with clean laparoscopic incisions. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

7f1a1d9f-866c-474a-bca9-dc80461012ed.question: A 36-year-old man presents to a physician after experiencing a transient loss of consciousness while resting after dinner the previous night, his third such episode. He reports recent nightmares and a family history of sudden cardiac death in his father at age 45. Physical examination is normal, but a 12-lead ECG shows ST-segment elevations in V1-V3 and incomplete right bundle branch block. Following a diagnosis of Brugada syndrome, he is prescribed a class I anti-arrhythmic drug that slows phase 0 depolarization via sodium channel blockade, blocks potassium channels to prolong action potential duration without shortening phase 3 repolarization, and has mild anticholinergic and alpha-blocking activity. What are the most likely side effects of this medication when taken in high doses?

88d30b3b-ba94-441c-84ca-62c118bc3515.question: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for recurrent vomiting that began 5 hours ago. He describes the vomitus as bloody and containing black specks. He drinks 10–12 beers daily and has not seen a physician in 15 years. He appears pale. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 122/min, and blood pressure is 85/59 mm Hg. Physical examination shows decreased radial pulses, delayed capillary refill, multiple spider angiomata, and a distended abdomen. He is oriented to person but not to place or time. Which physiological parameter is most likely decreased in this patient compared to a healthy adult?

3c4640d3-a173-464b-9499-a82eb14aa6bb.question: A 69-year-old male with a longstanding history of hypertension and high cholesterol presents with abdominal pain and bruising on his feet, symptoms that began a week ago and have progressively worsened. He describes dull, deep umbilical region pain and reports decreased appetite and early satiety. His medical history includes two transient ischemic attacks six months prior. He has a 30-pack-year smoking history and heavy alcohol use. Vital signs show a blood pressure of 155/89 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass in the lower umbilical region and a right carotid bruit. Imaging confirms a small, unruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (4.1 cm diameter). High-flow oxygen, fluids, morphine, and metoprolol have been administered. What is the best course of treatment for this patient?

d9fdccb7-01f7-47fd-a54c-44b9383c45f7.question: A 38-year-old woman undergoes a partial thyroidectomy for an enlarged thyroid gland compressing the trachea. During surgery, a young surgeon ligates the inferior thyroid arteries as close to the poles as possible to prevent intraoperative hemorrhage. Two weeks later, the patient presents to the outpatient clinic with hoarseness. What is the most likely cause of her hoarseness?

3f2a2270-8f42-4767-b23a-a484afe44cdf.question: A 17-year-old man presents to his family physician for evaluation of his penis size, expressing anxiety due to its smaller appearance compared to peers during physical education class. Physical examination reveals Tanner stage 1 development, with a weight of 60 kg (132 lb) and height of 175 cm (5 ft 9 in). His cardiopulmonary examination is normal, but he cannot identify coffee grounds by smell. What pathophysiological mechanism underlies this patient’s condition?

9dbbc7b0-96f6-4d9c-b1e8-2b0b7419b6f0.question: A 63-year-old man with a 45-year smoking history seeks to improve his health through diet, daily walking, and smoking cessation. He reports consistent cramping calf pain after walking one mile, leading to a diagnosis of peripheral artery disease with intermittent claudication. His physician prescribes cilostazol to alleviate symptoms. What is the mechanism of action of cilostazol in this patient's treatment?

6082e899-c111-403d-991a-34b599947b14.question: A 37-year-old man comes to the emergency department with the chief complaint of a high fever for several days. In addition to the fever, he has had malaise, chest pain, and a dry cough. He recently went on vacation to South America but has returned to his job delivering packages. He has several friends who recently had influenza. His temperature is 102.8°F (39.3°C), blood pressure is 137/80 mmHg, pulse is 104/min, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation is 98%. Chest exam reveals a deep noise found bilaterally in the lung bases. Chest radiograph reveals a widened area of opacity near the heart and bilateral lung infiltrates. What characteristic is most likely associated with the organism responsible for this patient’s symptoms?

cedfe689-2b47-404a-a986-bc2126859cc4.question: A 34-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 4-day history of headache, fever, chills, cough, shortness of breath, and chest pain. He reports smoking 2 packs of cigarettes daily and consuming 2–3 beers daily, with no significant medical history except occasional seasonal allergies treated with diphenhydramine. Vital signs show a temperature of 40.0°C (104.0°F), blood pressure 140/80 mm Hg, heart rate 98/min, and respiratory rate 28/min. Physical examination reveals a thin, poorly groomed man with dirty clothing, small scars in the antecubital regions of both arms, bilateral crackles on lung auscultation, a systolic murmur radiating to the left axilla, and palatal and palmar petechiae. Chest X-ray and blood cultures are ordered. What is the most likely causative organism responsible for this patient's condition?

95e859e3-d5a6-43e7-a6fb-79fb2d126f0a.question: A 62-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for vision changes. About 90 minutes ago, she suddenly noticed an inability to see the television screen normally and experienced mild dizziness. Her neurologic exam reveals loss of vision in the right visual field of both eyes with macular sparing, though extraocular movements remain intact. A head CT scan shows no acute intracranial abnormalities. Based on this clinical presentation, which cerebral vessel is most likely affected, as would be demonstrated by angiography?

beafb19c-8625-4b0f-b515-cdbcf6db6fe9.question: A three-day-old, full-term infant born by uncomplicated vaginal delivery is brought to a pediatrician by his mother, who notes that her son's skin appears yellow. She reports that the child cries several times per day but sleeps 7-8 hours at night uninterrupted. The mother has been breastfeeding the infant but describes a poor latch and uncertainty about milk intake despite lactation consultation, where inadequate latch persisted despite proper instruction. The infant is currently passing stools twice daily. What is the most likely etiology of this patient's jaundice?

25b37c75-a535-4220-ac29-115881ee4883.question: A 59-year-old man with a history of liver cirrhosis and alcoholism presents to the emergency department with black, tarry stools, confusion, jaundice, lethargy, asterixis, and guaiac-positive stool. Laboratory findings include hypoalbuminemia, prolonged prothrombin time, elevated bilirubin, and elevated AST/ALT ratio. What is a key diagnostic feature of this patient's condition?
25b37c75-a535-4220-ac29-115881ee4883.correct_answer: It is a diagnosis of exclusion

e3a0a52d-2898-4f5a-a981-48b5182435b7.question: A 20-year-old healthy man is running on a treadmill for the last 30 minutes. He is in good shape and exercises 3 times per week. He takes no medications and denies smoking cigarettes, drinking alcohol, and illicit drug use. Prior to starting his run, his heart rate was 70/min, and the blood pressure was 114/74 mm Hg. Immediately after stopping his run, the heart rate is 130/min, and the blood pressure is 145/75 mm Hg. What physiological mechanism is most likely responsible for the observed changes in heart rate and blood pressure immediately after stopping his run?

ee210064-854c-4bcb-991a-8b76a5469904.question: A 14-year-old obese boy presents with severe right hip and knee pain, acutely worsening after three weeks of mild limping. He denies trauma, recent illness, or prior similar symptoms. Physical examination reveals external rotation of the right leg, limited hip range of motion, and 4/5 strength at the right hip. Radiographs demonstrate inferoposterior displacement of the right femoral head from the femoral neck. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
ee210064-854c-4bcb-991a-8b76a5469904.correct_answer: Surgical pinning of the right hip

40580009-a7c9-465f-9b1f-dd8f7210bf7a.question: A 32-year-old man presents with progressive development of tender breast tissue over the past 18 months. He discontinued cycling after a left testicular injury 3 months ago and reports a 5 kg weight gain. He consumes 1-2 beers daily, occasionally more on weekends. Physical examination reveals bilaterally symmetrical gynecomastia and a nontender 1.5-cm left testicular mass with negative transillumination. His BMI is 30 kg/m², and vital signs are normal. What is the most likely underlying cause of these clinical findings?

a8bd6973-00c0-4db7-b483-524bfbdd8fba.question: A 58-year-old man presents to the physician with an 8-month history of inability to achieve erections during sexual intercourse, which began after becoming sexually active with a new girlfriend following a 3-year period of inactivity due to his wife's death. His medical history includes hyperlipidemia, major depressive disorder, and current use of simvastatin and citalopram. He reports significant recent stress but has a good relationship with his girlfriend. Physical exam reveals a BMI of 30 kg/m², faint pedal pulses, and otherwise normal findings. What is the most appropriate next diagnostic step in evaluating the etiology of his erectile dysfunction?

a21e6e70-c35a-4829-a1e6-a8e22b1b102c.question: A 5-year-old male presents to the pediatrician with a 10-day history of cough that is worse at night. The patient has a history of mild intermittent asthma and has been using his albuterol inhaler without relief. He has also been complaining of headache and sore throat, and his mother has noticed worsening rhinorrhea. The patient’s past medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and he has no known drug allergies. In the office, his temperature is 101.8°F (38.8°C), blood pressure is 88/65 mmHg, pulse is 132/min, and respirations are 16/min. The patient has purulent mucus draining from the nares, and his face is tender to palpation over the maxillary sinuses. His pharynx is erythematous with symmetric swelling of the tonsils. On lung exam, he has moderate bilateral expiratory wheezing. What is the best next step in management for this patient?

6f2caef1-cde6-4826-9fa3-280352ca23e3.question: A 65-year-old man with a 3-year history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to the emergency department with a 1-day history of cough, dyspnea, and increased sputum production. He reports no fever and is currently on inhaled salmeterol and fluticasone propionate. He quit smoking 2 years ago after a long history of tobacco use. Vital signs include a temperature of 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse 88/min, blood pressure 128/86 mm Hg, and respiratory rate 30/min. Physical examination reveals accessory muscle use, oxygen saturation of 87%, and bilateral rhonchi with diminished breath sounds. Which medication, if administered for the next 2 weeks, is most likely to reduce the risk of future COPD exacerbations over the subsequent 6 months?

8905b142-ff9d-442f-bc4e-30853ec03364.question: A 22-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain, contractions, and bloody vaginal discharge at 10 weeks gestation. She has a history of constipation, anxiety, and substance abuse. Vital signs are stable, and physical exam reveals an open cervix with vaginal bleeding. Initially grateful for care, she becomes hostile and accusatory toward staff after learning of her spontaneous abortion. Later, she is found with self-inflicted wrist lacerations and damaged medical equipment. What is the most likely diagnosis?

619fb62d-16ab-4484-ad04-aa0a101b5c41.question: A 45-year-old female presents to the emergency department with gross hematuria and acute, colicky flank pain. She denies any previous episodes of hematuria and reports taking high doses of acetaminophen and aspirin over several weeks for persistent upper back pain. Her blood pressure and temperature are normal, but she has proteinuria. Physical examination reveals no palpable flank masses. What is the most likely diagnosis?

77e4bca5-6fb2-41cc-b163-88ffc7c75817.question: A 40-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of increased bilateral knee pain that developed gradually and now limits his mobility. The pain worsens by the end of the day, though he experiences brief morning stiffness lasting approximately 20 minutes. Over-the-counter NSAIDs previously helped but are no longer effective. He has taken metformin for 2 years, has a BMI of 41 kg/m², and reports excessive daytime fatigue, unintentional dozing at work, and unrefreshing sleep. Physical examination reveals crepitus in the knees without tenderness or erythema. His family history includes rheumatoid arthritis in his mother. What underlying factor is responsible for this patient’s knee pain and associated symptoms?

615f169a-3f3b-4dd6-a73c-56acf78c241e.question: A 40-year-old man presents with a 4-week history of shortness of breath, double vision, and fatigue. He has no significant medical history or medication use. Physical examination reveals bilateral ptosis and an inability to maintain arm elevation beyond 3 minutes. A chest CT scan demonstrates an anterior mediastinal mass with smooth borders, and a photomicrograph of the mass specimen is provided. Which immunologic process typically occurs in the thymic region indicated by the arrow in the histologic specimen?

7d270a65-0f0c-4099-9baa-f07af2090c13.question: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his parents after being found barely responsive with slurred speech. A bottle of oxycodone missing 15 pills was found at his bedside. On examination, he is drowsy, lethargic, minimally responsive, with a respiratory rate of 8/min, blood pressure of 130/90 mm Hg, pulse of 60/min, and pinpoint pupils. After receiving a drug to improve his symptoms, what is the mechanism of action of the most likely administered medication?
7d270a65-0f0c-4099-9baa-f07af2090c13.correct_answer: μ, κ, and ẟ receptor antagonist

4d5f710f-315c-46fe-b1e1-52dd85c0ac4d.question: A 27-year-old woman presents with a 2-month history of increasing shortness of breath, non-productive cough, malaise, and bilateral ankle pain. Her symptoms began after returning from a vacation to Arizona, and she works as a research assistant in a university geology laboratory. She is originally from Nigeria and visited family there 3 months ago. Vital signs include a temperature of 37.8°C (100°F), pulse of 100/min, respirations of 24/min, and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. Physical examination reveals ciliary injection and photophobia in the left eye, with clear lung auscultation and no palpable lymphadenopathy. Laboratory results, including a complete blood count, are within normal limits. A chest x-ray is obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis?

cd12f8a5-96ea-41bc-b188-8e8658f2e07e.question: A 75-year-old man presents to his physician with a 1-year history of dysphagia for solids that has progressed to include liquids. He reports no difficulty initiating swallowing but occasionally feels food stuck in his throat, without pain. He has experienced minor unintentional weight loss and denies speech-related pain or nasal regurgitation. Physical examination reveals an ill-appearing, malnourished, slightly pale patient with no jaundice or cyanosis. A swallowing study demonstrates a small outpouching in the posterior neck. Which cranial nerve is most likely implicated in the pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

04369dbd-251e-4aaf-a2d3-35e974264523.question: A 48-year-old female presents with a 2-week history of anterior neck enlargement causing difficulty swallowing, accompanied by 6 weeks of constipation, fatigue, heavy menstrual bleeding, and cold intolerance. She has well-controlled asthma and seasonal allergies. Physical examination reveals a stony hard, tender, asymmetrically enlarged thyroid with pain on swallowing. Laboratory studies demonstrate a serum T4 of 4.4 μg/dL and TSH of 6.3 mU/L. Radionuclide thyroid scanning shows low radioactive iodine uptake in the nodule. What is the most likely diagnosis?

3315d87a-6cd2-4a34-8ff6-12ca14f9cd04.question: A researcher is testing an unknown compound, X, to determine its effect on renal function. After applying compound X to kidney cells, the urinary concentration of sodium and pH decrease, while urinary potassium increases. What are the specific kidney cells targeted by compound X, and what is the most likely identity of compound X?

46a72fbe-d9df-42a8-8249-66d57e31f4b0.question: A 5-year-old male is brought to the pediatrician with complaints of a painful mouth and gums, vesicular lesions on the lips and buccal mucosa for the past 4 days, and difficulty eating or drinking due to pain. He has been irritable and reports muscle aches. Vital signs include a temperature of 39.1°C, heart rate of 110/min, blood pressure of 90/62 mm Hg, respiratory rate of 18/min, and SpO2 of 99%. Physical examination reveals vesicular lesions on the tongue, gingiva, and lips, some ruptured and ulcerated, along with palpable cervical and submandibular lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely causative organism responsible for this patient's presentation?

60e2077d-8eac-42fe-9442-6abfe6550248.question: A patient is unresponsive in the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. The patient's written advance directive states that he does not wish to be resuscitated in the event of a cardiac arrest. The patient's wife arrives and demands that "everything" be done to keep him alive because she "can't go on living without him." The patient's adult son is on his way to the hospital. If the patient arrests, what action should the healthcare team take and why?
60e2077d-8eac-42fe-9442-6abfe6550248.correct_answer: Respect the patient's prior wishes and do not resuscitate

47615d5e-bcf8-405c-8823-eea01bd4eb7e.question: A 63-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department with retrosternal chest pain rated 7/10 in intensity. His medications include aspirin, simvastatin, metformin, and enalapril, and he has a 33-pack-year smoking history. Vital signs on arrival are pulse 136/min (irregular), respirations 20/min, and blood pressure 85/55 mm Hg. Lung auscultation is clear, and cardiac examination reveals no abnormalities. An ECG is obtained. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

29f3b6ea-d9d9-4873-b7b5-f8a759194297.question: A 14-year-old boy presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain and is found on ultrasound to have a gallstone. Based on clinical suspicion, a CBC, Coombs test, and bilirubin panel are obtained, revealing mild normocytic anemia with reticulocytosis, increased RDW, indirect hyperbilirubinemia, and a negative Coombs test. An osmotic fragility test shows increased fragility in hypotonic solution. What blood smear findings would most likely be anticipated in this patient?

fa0677a3-c1f1-4705-8c26-64d7920d2ae1.question: A 32-year-old man presents to the physician with a 2-day history of tingling in his right forearm following heavy weightlifting. Physical examination reveals sensory loss over the lateral forearm but intact sensation of the thumb. Neck range of motion is normal, and symptoms do not worsen with cervical compression or distraction. Which specific motor function is most likely to demonstrate weakness in this patient?

d0794353-51fe-4d03-8059-22bdf46e7834.question: A 30-year-old woman presents to your office with decreased appetite, malaise, and fever. Serologic tests reveal positive Anti-HBsAg and Anti-HAV IgM antibodies. What is the most likely source of infection responsible for this patient's clinical presentation?

71446f4a-ebb7-4d6f-8f59-7208e20918df.question: A 63-year-old patient presents to the emergency department because of severe left leg pain and tingling that began suddenly 30 minutes ago. He has a 10-year history of hypertension managed with bisoprolol and does not smoke or drink alcohol. Vital signs show a temperature of 37.1°C (98.7°F), blood pressure of 130/80 mm Hg, and an irregular pulse of 100/min. Physical examination reveals severe pain, a pale and cool left leg, and a weaker popliteal pulse on the left compared to the right. What is the most common cause of this patient's condition?

987d43fd-0516-44ae-8fd4-e153c7e58dfd.question: A 17-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician by her father for evaluation due to concerns about delayed puberty, as she has not undergone pubertal development while her peers have. The patient reports feeling well overall. Vital signs show a blood pressure of 137/92 mmHg. Examination reveals undeveloped breasts (Tanner I) and normal female genitalia. Her BMI is normal, and she is in the 40th percentile for height. What is the most likely laboratory abnormality present in this patient?

798054a8-c40f-40ab-a84d-02ff47e4d71b.question: Current recommendations state that a single hemoglobin A1c value of greater than 6.5% is diagnostic of diabetes mellitus. If this 6.5% cutoff is increased to 7.0%, what effect does this change have on the rate of false negative test results?
798054a8-c40f-40ab-a84d-02ff47e4d71b.correct_answer: Increase in false negative test results

d6d0bfad-8e6d-43a0-b89c-42e597479373.question: Patients with sickle cell anemia produce hemoglobin S (HgbS), which causes red blood cells to sickle under hypoxic conditions. Hydroxyurea is a commonly used treatment for this condition. What is the direct physiological effect of hydroxyurea on hemoglobin in these patients?

6dc3d83b-b4e2-4db6-88ab-a29ec1897691.question: A 40-year-old man with a history of cirrhosis due to alcoholism presents to the emergency department with progressively worsening confusion over several days. Vital signs are temperature 98.8°F (37.1°C), blood pressure 134/90 mmHg, pulse 83/min, respirations 15/min, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. Physical exam reveals a non-tender distended abdomen, asterixis, and altered mental status. Laboratory results include serum sodium 139 mEq/L, chloride 100 mEq/L, potassium 3.3 mEq/L, bicarbonate 22 mEq/L, BUN 20 mg/dL, glucose 59 mg/dL, creatinine 1.1 mg/dL, and calcium 10.2 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?

d655d013-6e75-4d43-864e-ab8e1d5d5371.question: A previously healthy 4-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents due to inconsolable crying for the past 5 hours and refusal to eat. There is no history of trauma, and she was born at term via uncomplicated vaginal delivery. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination reveals a reddened and swollen second toe on the left foot. What is the most likely diagnosis?

b6487d3a-6d57-4973-9a83-d1addd3c7ea8.question: A 35-year-old woman presents to the physician because of episodes of difficulty swallowing solid food for the past 3 months, with no issues consuming liquids. She reports occasional heartburn over the past year and has a history of asthma and eczema. Endoscopic evaluation reveals eosinophilic infiltration on mucosal biopsy. Based on this presentation, what is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy to initiate at this time?

052775ad-68d9-4636-b06c-8db35372a094.question: A 2-year-old boy in respiratory distress is brought to the emergency department by his parents. They report hearing a "hacking" cough approximately one hour after putting him to sleep, followed by a high-pitched noise during breathing. The child had a runny nose for the past few days but is otherwise healthy, with no access to small objects or toys. Physical examination confirms respiratory distress. Based on this presentation, what is the appropriate management for this patient?
052775ad-68d9-4636-b06c-8db35372a094.correct_answer: Dexamethasome, racemic epinephrine and observation for 4 hours; discharge if stridor remits

cdafd044-0c02-4c34-895a-765fd96de6a2.question: A 70-year-old woman with no significant medical history developed memory loss, personality changes, and rapid mental deterioration over several months. She later exhibited sudden jerking movements in response to being startled, gait disturbances, and ultimately progressed to coma and death eight months after symptom onset. What pathological process most likely caused her condition?
cdafd044-0c02-4c34-895a-765fd96de6a2.correct_answer: Conversion of a protein from an a-helix to a ß-pleated form, which resists degradation.

1135af96-aeb5-4d41-a0b8-7b92baf422cc.question: A 38-year-old woman presents with eye dryness and a foreign body sensation in the eyes.
