Vital signs include a temperature of 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse of 130/min, respirations of 24/min, and blood pressure of 130/84 mm Hg. Abdominal examination reveals right upper quadrant tenderness with an inspiratory pause on palpation. Bedside ultrasonography demonstrates a dilated common bile duct but no stones in the common bile duct or gallbladder. Laboratory results show leukocytosis with neutrophilia, elevated alkaline phosphatase, and mild hyperbilirubinemia. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

bc98a668-7a1e-4f85-ac26-87a9a6d1be5c.question: A 22-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by police after being found undressing himself outside in 110°F weather. He refuses to answer questions, suspects his care team is spying on him, and has a history of polysubstance intoxication. After attempting to assault a nurse, he is restrained and administered diphenhydramine and haloperidol. Upon examination, he is somnolent, non-responsive, and exhibits rigidity preventing free manipulation of his extremities. Vital signs include a temperature of 104°F (40°C), blood pressure of 147/98 mmHg, pulse of 120/min, and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. His mucous membranes are dry. What is the most likely diagnosis?

c2fe6c51-ebd7-4721-b0d6-0ce9f0ed92bc.question: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain and vaginal discharge three days after delivering a healthy baby boy. She reports progressive worsening of symptoms since childbirth. Vital signs include a temperature of 100.7°F (38.1°C), blood pressure of 115/78 mmHg, pulse of 105/min, and respirations of 14/min. Physical examination reveals uterine tenderness and abdominal discomfort, with laboratory results showing an elevated white blood cell count and numerous plasma cells. What characteristic morphology and hemolytic pattern are most likely associated with the causative organism of this patient's condition?

e7654b0b-3de4-4a72-9c0c-9a6789ab6208.question: An 18-month-old boy is brought to his pediatrician because his mother is concerned about his walking. The boy was born at 37 weeks’ gestation and spent 1 night in the neonatal intensive care unit for respiratory distress. He otherwise has been healthy and started walking independently at 12 months. However, his mother reports that he has stopped walking and appears weaker than he was a few months ago. He also has started having brief convulsive episodes over the past week. His parents are both healthy with no medical conditions. On exam, the child demonstrates muscle rigidity and diffuse muscle wasting. He is unable to stand or sit up straight. His patellar, Achilles, and brachioradialis reflexes are absent. Fundoscopic examination is unremarkable. A urine sample demonstrates metachromic granules. What enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?

408ead24-4cdb-4458-94e1-4f3aadfd1d44.question: A 45-year-old man presents to his primary care provider with a two-week history of low-grade fever and sore throat. Further history reveals unprotected sexual activity with multiple male and female partners, averaging 3-5 partners per month. Laboratory evaluation demonstrates an HIV viral load of 15,000 copies/mL and a CD4+ count of 170 cells/mm³. Medical therapy is initiated. What specific medication should be included in his regimen to prevent treatment-related complications?

d983c3cf-64ec-4ede-98d0-a60c2a3ab201.question: A 71-year-old woman presents for evaluation of a pigmented lesion on her left foot, accompanied by decreased appetite and a 6-kg weight loss over 2 months. Physical examination reveals a 2-cm reddish-black nodule with a verrucous surface on the left medial ankle. Biopsy shows S100-protein-positive epithelioid cells, and CT imaging confirms hepatic metastases, leading to a diagnosis of metastatic melanoma. Chemotherapy with aldesleukin is initiated. What is the mechanism of action of aldesleukin in this patient's treatment?
d983c3cf-64ec-4ede-98d0-a60c2a3ab201.correct_answer: Activating natural killer cells and cytotoxic T cells

1a5e9b83-cd05-4d07-bfb1-1087f4c1cc65.question: A 27-year-old female presents to her physician with a palpable thyroid nodule. Iodine uptake testing reveals decreased uptake in the nodule compared to the rest of the thyroid gland. Following a fine-needle aspiration, the physician informs the patient that she has a thyroid neoplasm. What is the most likely diagnosis?

c799cd62-62c0-4557-a6bf-e5210cac9c1e.question: A 58-year-old male presents with an acutely elevated blood pressure of 220/140 mmHg. He complains of headache, chest pain, and vomiting over several hours. Physical exam reveals papilledema and a depressed level of consciousness. He is started on an intravenous medication for hypertensive emergency that releases nitric oxide as a metabolite, activating guanylate cyclase and increasing cGMP production in vascular smooth muscle. What clinical effect would most likely result from administering this medication?

bcf2e7d1-385c-46b5-8f47-da982a48ae42.question: A 24-year-old woman delivers a baby at term with Apgar scores of 9 and 10 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Thirty minutes postpartum, her blood pressure drops to 80/60 mm Hg, pulse increases to 124/min, and physical examination reveals cold, clammy extremities and a boggy uterus. After aggressive fluid resuscitation with 4 units of IV fluids and 4 units of whole blood, her vital signs stabilize. The next morning, she reports inability to lactate when attempting to breastfeed. What is the most likely cause of her failure to lactate?

bcc6c8fb-685b-4b13-a85c-fd1a0f58798a.question: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 3-day history of fatigue and yellow discoloration of his skin. One week ago, he had an upper respiratory tract infection. Examination shows jaundice of the skin and conjunctivae. The spleen tip is palpated 2 cm below the left costal margin. His hemoglobin concentration is 9.4 g/dl and his mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration is 39% Hb/cell. A Coombs test is negative. A peripheral blood smear is performed. Based on this presentation and findings, which complication is this patient at greatest risk for?

a5e7e35e-039e-4086-9c3e-0648d90c3df5.question: A 27-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for a general checkup. She has a history of well-controlled asthma with albuterol, is sexually active using birth control, and reports no current complaints. Her family history includes paternal colon cancer at age 68 and maternal breast cancer at age 65. Vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 147/108 mmHg, with other parameters within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?
a5e7e35e-039e-4086-9c3e-0648d90c3df5.correct_answer: Discontinue birth control and place an intrauterine device

9e7f2e88-bff5-44bd-ac24-d7acd00c4f41.question: A 25-year-old woman presents with generalized abdominal pain and vomiting for the past hour, along with watery diarrhea for several days without blood or pus in the stools. She reports taking an unspecified over-the-counter anti-diarrheal medication and oral rehydration solution. Her past medical history includes appendectomy 10 years ago and ulna fracture 4 years ago. Vital signs show tachycardia (pulse 104/min), normal blood pressure (120/80 mm Hg), shallow respirations (14/min), and afebrile status (36.7°C). Physical examination reveals constricted pupils, pale and cold extremities, a soft but diffusely tender abdomen with a palpable bladder, and no rebound or guarding. Fingerstick glucose is 124 mg/dL, and imaging is unremarkable. What is the next best step in managing this patient?

5dcf9860-e0e7-44c7-a2aa-331642a4b6b9.question: A 26-year-old man with no significant past medical history presents to the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. Vital signs on arrival are temperature 99.0°F, blood pressure 100/60 mmHg, heart rate 125 bpm, respiratory rate 16/min, and SpO₂ 98% on room air. He reports extreme abdominal pain localized to the left upper quadrant that has worsened over the past 30 minutes. Physical examination reveals abdominal wall rigidity, involuntary guarding, and tenderness on light percussion. Bedside sonography demonstrates hemoperitoneum. Despite administration of additional intravenous fluids, repeat vital signs show temperature 98.9°F, blood pressure 82/50 mmHg, heart rate 180 bpm, respiratory rate 20/min, and SpO₂ 97% on room air. What is the best next step in management?

87f70334-99b5-4afc-a008-6233d02e5dee.question: A 74-year-old man undergoes an open cholecystectomy under general anesthesia with endotracheal intubation. Postoperatively, he is extubated after showing signs of alertness but becomes unresponsive five minutes later. His medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease with prior right coronary artery stenting, hypertension, a 40-pack-year smoking history (quit 2 weeks ago), and daily alcohol use. Medications include metformin, enalapril, aspirin, atorvastatin, and a multivitamin. Vital signs post-extubation show a pulse of 102/min, respirations 20/min, blood pressure 130/80 mm Hg, and pulse oximetry oxygen saturation of 73% on a 100% FiO₂ non-rebreather mask. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals pH 7.32, PCO₂ 33 mm Hg, PO₂ 73 mm Hg, HCO₃ 22 mEq/L, and O₂ saturation 73%. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?

07382c56-dbe8-402e-a7f8-e3e890c01ab8.question: An 11-month-old male infant is brought to his pediatrician by his mother due to his inability to stand and a right leg injury after minor trauma. The infant was born vaginally at 39 weeks following an uncomplicated pregnancy and has met all developmental milestones. His mother reports he could previously stand and walk briefly but developed edema, bruising, and inability to bear weight after hitting his leg on a chair two days prior. Physical examination reveals blue-gray sclerae, joint hypermobility, generalized hypotonia, and a tender, deformed right calf. X-ray demonstrates an incomplete tibial diaphysis fracture. What is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s clinical presentation?

4fcaea7e-d28e-457f-8f24-3074e5ca3442.question: A 21-year-old man presents to the emergency room with acute-onset swelling and severe pain in his left lower leg. He has a family history of pulmonary embolism, a smoking habit of one pack daily for three years, and a BMI of 30.7 kg/m². Physical examination reveals tenderness, mild swelling in the left calf, and positive Homans' sign. Laboratory studies show normal platelet count, PT, and aPTT at presentation, with positive fibrin split products. Doppler ultrasound demonstrates popliteal vein incompressibility, a hyperechoic mass, and absent blood flow. After receiving a 5000 IU heparin bolus followed by continuous infusion, his aPTT six hours later remains subtherapeutic at 30 seconds. What underlying condition is most likely responsible for the inadequate response to heparin therapy?

5ed0d195-3f33-45e4-b00a-89da742cee8d.question: An 80-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of fatigue and lightheadedness. He does not have chest pain, palpitations, or difficulty breathing. He has a history of hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, osteoarthritis, and asthma. Current medications include simvastatin, metformin, lisinopril, albuterol, and ibuprofen. His pulse is 48/min and blood pressure is 89/50 mm Hg. He responds slowly to questions but is oriented to person, place, and time. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. His lungs are clear to auscultation and bowel sounds are positive with no pulsatile masses or bruits. Pedal pulses are nonpalpable, distal extremities are cold, and capillary refill time is 4 seconds. An ECG shows left axis deviation, a Q wave in lead III, a constant PR interval of 0.15 seconds with every third P wave that is nonconducted, and a QRS interval of 0.09 seconds. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

44110ac2-f7b3-4055-bd69-e300ed1abaf4.question: In a small town with a population of 10,000 people, the prevalence of alcohol use is estimated to be 30%. A study investigates the association between alcohol use and gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Among 200 individuals who consume alcohol, 30 developed GERD, while 30 out of 400 non-alcoholics developed GERD. Based on this data, what fraction of GERD cases in the general population could theoretically be prevented if alcohol consumption is entirely eliminated?

ec55ece4-3234-418d-8615-7383a7fecdcf.question: A 41-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of abdominal discomfort and cramping for the past 4 months. He reports grossly bloody stool and frequent urgency to defecate. He has a history of bulimia with laxative abuse several years ago and has lost approximately 5 lb in the past month. His vital signs include a temperature of 37°C (98.6°F), respiratory rate of 15/min, pulse of 77/min, and blood pressure of 105/86 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals mild conjunctival pallor and a rectum that is erythematous, indurated, and tender. Colonoscopy shows continuous mucosal lesions extending from the rectum to the hepatic flexure of the colon. What is the most likely diagnosis?

2eda930c-1081-4531-82ec-15de59232970.question: A 45-year-old man presents to your office with a 2-year history of moderate-to-severe pelvic pain, irritative voiding urinary symptoms (frequency and dysuria), and occasional frank blood in his semen with painful ejaculation. He has been evaluated by several practitioners, who prescribed antimicrobial therapy, including ciprofloxacin, with no improvement and subsequent emotional distress and sleep disturbances. Physical examination reveals a mildly tender prostate without masses or nodules, and no testicular masses, hernias, or hemorrhoids. The patient also has a history of recurrent abdominal pain, alternating constipation and diarrhea, and fatigability, though all prior test results have been normal. Recent tests show negative white cells and culture in mid-stream urine, but positive white cells with negative culture in expressed prostatic secretions. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

d3b1c288-4d16-4cf0-9709-148941a050b1.question: An 18-year-old male presents to the emergency department trauma bay with a gunshot wound to the abdomen. During exploratory laparotomy, the splenic artery is ligated at its origin from the celiac trunk due to damage. Which artery will now be hypoperfused as a result of this surgical intervention?

1e305fc1-5a0b-43cf-a885-69338195eee6.question: A 2-hour-old, 3.2 kg (7.0 lb) newborn boy born by cesarean delivery is being evaluated by the resident on-call. The child was born to a gravida 2, para 0 mother with known hepatitis B. The mother attended all prenatal appointments and took the recommended dose of folic acid since conception. She quit smoking upon discovering her pregnancy. The infant’s vital signs are within normal ranges, APGAR scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, and physical examination reveals no abnormalities. Maternal hepatitis B serology shows HBsAg positivity, HBeAg positivity, HBV DNA greater than 1 million IU/mL, and normal alanine transferase. What is the best immediate management for this newborn?
1e305fc1-5a0b-43cf-a885-69338195eee6.correct_answer: Administer hepatitis B vaccine and HBIG

40e5492e-a9ba-4e9b-9987-ed3705b71b1d.question: A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a persistent cough. He reports having a fever, chills, and cough two weeks ago, which were managed with acetaminophen, ibuprofen, and rest. His fever and systemic symptoms have resolved, but he continues to have a chronic cough with occasional clear sputum tinged with blood. He denies chest pain, shortness of breath, fever, or recurrent chills. His medical history is unremarkable except for current use of metformin and albuterol. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination reveals clear breath sounds bilaterally, no lymphadenopathy, and a normal oropharynx. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

26565fc1-1595-44be-8fc9-a15388ea5154.question: A 64-year-old man with multiple sclerosis presents with a 4-month history of sudden urinary urgency and incontinence, often unable to reach the bathroom in time. He denies incontinence with coughing or laughing. Digital rectal examination is unremarkable, and post-void residual volume on ultrasonography is normal. What is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's urinary incontinence?

6d9eeb89-484a-40ea-bf4f-3945aece0139.question: A 42-year-old woman with a history of depression and headaches presents to the emergency room with severe, pulsating pain around the crown of her head that began 12 hours ago. She took ibuprofen 2 hours ago without relief and reports nausea and inability to get out of bed, currently lying in the dark. She stopped sertraline 2 months ago and takes no other medications. What is the best treatment for her acute symptoms?

0d017dae-aba3-4cc8-8215-7bbf47527aa4.question:
A pulmonologist is analyzing the vital signs of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) who presented to an emergency room with respiratory distress and subsequently required intubation. The respiratory rates of 7 patients with COPD during their initial visit to the emergency room are as follows:  
Patient 1: 22 breaths per minute  
Patient 2: 32 breaths per minute  
Patient 3: 23 breaths per minute  
Patient 4: 30 breaths per minute  
Patient 5: 32 breaths per minute  
Patient 6: 32 breaths per minute  
Patient 7: 23 breaths per minute  
What is the mode of these respiratory rates?

f437f591-89c0-4553-b2dc-ad77e0e01e97.question: A 17-year-old high school student accidentally sawed off his pointer finger in shop class and fainted upon realizing the injury. The teacher transported him to the emergency department within 20 minutes, leaving the amputated finger in the classroom, with the principal planning to bring it to the hospital. The patient has a history of asthma managed with an albuterol inhaler, and his current blood pressure is 122/78 mmHg. Analgesics have been administered. What is the correct method for transporting the amputated finger to optimize its viability for potential reattachment?
f437f591-89c0-4553-b2dc-ad77e0e01e97.correct_answer: Wrap finger in moist gauze, put in a plastic bag, and place on ice

1f51d31a-a854-458b-8e6b-b50ae59646a5.question: A 15-year-old girl presents to the physician with a 3-month absence of menstrual bleeding after previously having irregular cycles every 15–45 days with moderate to heavy flow since menarche at age 14. She reports initiating sexual activity 3 months ago and has a history of risperidone treatment for a manic episode 6 months ago. Family history includes maternal PCOS and paternal diabetes mellitus. She is weight-conscious, with a BMI of 27.02 kg/m². Physical examination reveals normal vital signs and unremarkable pelvic findings. Lab results show a negative pregnancy test, progesterone level of 0.8 ng/mL (follicular phase normal <3 ng/mL), and normal testosterone, prolactin, TSH, FSH, and LH levels. What is the most likely cause of her amenorrhea?

7731a933-b6ee-4037-b19b-a816df100dac.question: A 21-year-old woman presents with sudden onset of high blood pressure. She reports episodes of facial redness noticed by colleagues and uses blankets to cover her feet despite warm ambient temperatures, though her hands feel warm. She maintains a healthy diet and exercise regimen with no family history of hypertension or metabolic syndromes. Vital signs show blood pressure of 145/92 mm Hg, respirations 19/min, pulse 64/min, and temperature 36.7°C (98.0°F). An echocardiogram is ordered for further evaluation. What genetic condition is most likely associated with this patient's clinical presentation?

69a9988b-69b7-49bc-a111-177dd6e64dbf.question: A 52-year-old man presents to the physician with a 6-month history of shortness of breath and nonproductive cough. He was recently diagnosed with stage 3 embryonal carcinoma testicular cancer and underwent orchiectomy followed by chemotherapy. Cardiopulmonary examination reveals bilateral fine inspiratory crackles and clubbing of the fingers. Pulmonary function tests show an FVC of 78% of predicted and an FEV1/FVC ratio of 92%. A CT scan of the chest demonstrates interstitial lung changes. Which chemotherapeutic agent is most likely responsible for this patient's pulmonary manifestations?

bb8b14f4-59d5-4ef9-ae34-3a94125192e5.question: A 72-year-old man develops reduced urine output and a serum creatinine concentration of 2.9 mg/dL three days after being hospitalized for acute diverticulitis. On admission, a complete blood count showed a hemoglobin concentration of 15.5 g/dL and a leukocyte count of 14,000/mm³. Urinalysis showed 2+ proteinuria, and serum studies revealed a blood glucose of 145 mg/dL and a creatinine concentration of 1.2 mg/dL. A CT scan of the abdomen confirmed the diagnosis. Therapy with intravenous ketoprofen, piperacillin, and tazobactam was initiated, and the patient was placed on bowel rest. He has a history of hypertension, chronic constipation, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Prior medications included insulin, metoprolol, and losartan. Current vital signs are temperature 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse 97/min, respirations 12/min, and blood pressure 135/87 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals a soft abdomen with left lower quadrant tenderness. What is the most likely cause of this patient’s current renal findings?

be68370a-5f65-4f14-b4b1-8679a820ecb5.question: An immunology expert is delivering a talk on innate immunity and describes the inflammasome activation process: cellular stress products are detected by NLRP3 (containing NOD-, LRR-, and pyrin domains), which interacts with apoptosis-associated speck-like protein containing CARD (ASC) via the pyrin domain, forming multimers of ASC dimers (protein speck). What enzyme is activated as the next step in this process?

a040deac-8020-4872-93aa-c6c3f1f11abf.question: In protein-secreting cells, which cellular structure contains the ribosomes that are essential for synthesizing proteins destined for secretion?

0360de34-40dc-49bf-bd1f-bfa300ff28bd.question: A patient presents to the emergency department with severe head pain that began 1 hour after rugby practice. She reports taking two doses of her usual headache medication without improvement. Her current medications include sumatriptan and naproxen. She has a recent history of hospital admissions for panic attacks and suicide attempts. Vital signs are temperature 99.2°F (37.3°C), blood pressure 129/65 mmHg, pulse 90/min, respirations 15/min, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. After receiving dihydroergotamine, IV fluids, and 100% oxygen, she develops slurred speech, left-sided mouth drooping, and 2/5 strength in her left upper extremity two hours later. A head CT is ordered. What is the most likely cause of this patient's neurological deficits?

bb7d4484-e412-44b5-9638-c8b1c6863b68.question: A 24-year-old woman presents for a routine gynecological examination and birth control refill. She is sexually active with one male partner, has regular menstrual cycles, and had a normal Pap smear at age 22. Her family history includes a father who died of colon cancer at 75 and a mother diagnosed with breast cancer at 40. She plans a backpacking trip in two months and is up-to-date on routine immunizations. Pelvic and speculum exams are unremarkable. What is the most appropriate screening recommendation for this patient at this visit?
bb7d4484-e412-44b5-9638-c8b1c6863b68.correct_answer: Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis screening

a5255186-37f1-4b1a-b390-79ebe750af90.question: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. The patient has a past medical history of asthma and cocaine use. His current medications include albuterol and ibuprofen. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 70/35 mmHg, pulse is 150/min, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On initial trauma evaluation, his airway is intact and he is breathing spontaneously. The patient's dorsalis pedis and radial pulses are palpable bilaterally. His Glasgow Coma Scale is 9. Head-to-toe examination reveals instability of the pelvis when downward force is applied. The patient is started on IV fluids and norepinephrine, and a pelvic binder is placed. The patient's vitals are measured again, showing a temperature of 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure of 100/55 mmHg, pulse of 150/min, respirations of 17/min, and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. A blood transfusion is initiated, and the patient is administered hydromorphone. He subsequently develops acute shortness of breath with bilateral wheezing and poor air movement, accompanied by a blood pressure of 60/35 mmHg and pulse of 160/min. After appropriate treatment, intubation, and stabilization, he is transferred to the surgical intensive care unit. Based on this presentation, which two findings are most likely present in this patient's medical history?

a6e53860-f15f-4ffd-9a39-fd944273f8f5.question: An academic obstetrician conducted a retrospective cohort study evaluating the risk of placenta accreta across statewide medical centers. Chart review revealed a statistically significant association between prior cesarean birth and placenta accreta, with a relative risk of 1.23 and a p-value of 0.03. In the context of confidence intervals and hypothesis testing, how should the relationship between the reported p-value and the 99% confidence interval for this association be interpreted?
a6e53860-f15f-4ffd-9a39-fd944273f8f5.correct_answer: The 99% confidence interval includes the null hypothesis.

728cdfe0-8bd5-4abf-8e85-9796436e4f33.question: A 23-year-old man presents to his primary care physician after bleeding from his gums while brushing his teeth for the past week. Although he has had gum bleeding in the past, it has never been this severe. He has no family history available as he was adopted and no significant past medical history. Physical exam is within normal limits. Screening lab work reveals: platelet count 330,000/mm³, bleeding time 6 minutes, prothrombin time 12 seconds, activated partial thromboplastin time 42 seconds, decreased Factor VIII activity, and decreased ristocetin cofactor assay. Which aspect of coagulation is most likely affected in this patient?

6f634c88-0fc8-4bd5-8adc-08cc1157249e.question: A 51-year-old Caucasian woman presents to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has a history of a Colles' fracture 2 years ago, a sedentary lifestyle, 30-pack-year smoking history, moderate alcohol use, and a maternal history of wrist fracture in her late 60s. Physical examination is unremarkable. A DEXA scan reveals a hip T-score of -3.2 SD. After receiving education on fall prevention, exercise recommendations, smoking cessation support, dietary advice, and calcium/vitamin D supplementation, what pharmacologic intervention should be initiated next?

4b8ff39c-f4e9-45e4-81bf-787a79cc5ba1.question: A 33-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 26 weeks' gestation presents to the emergency department with frequent contractions lasting 40 seconds, occurring every 2 minutes, and increasing in intensity. She has a history of recurrent vulvar ulcers (currently absent) and a prior lower segment transverse cesarean section for non-reassuring fetal heart rate. Her current medications include acyclovir, folic acid, and a multivitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cervical examination reveals 5 cm dilation, 70% effacement, and fetal head at station -2. Fetal ultrasound shows no abnormalities. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

ad12eaf4-76ff-48b9-bbbb-c95c719d426c.question: A 55-year-old man presents with complaints of exertional dyspnea and dry cough. He reports using extra pillows at night to sleep and two nighttime awakenings to catch his breath in the last month. The patient lives in a homeless shelter and has not seen a doctor in the last 20 years. He has been drinking 5-8 alcoholic drinks per day for the last 20 years. Family history is non-significant, and the patient does not take any medications. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), blood pressure is 135/115 mm Hg, pulse is 85/min, and respiratory rate is 24/min. Physical examination reveals 2+ bilateral pitting edema. Chest auscultation shows bibasilar crackles. What pathophysiological mechanism is most closely associated with this patient’s clinical presentation?

5fd65181-0307-4be3-a76a-97f74bad410c.question: A 22-year-old man presents to the medical clinic after being bitten in the hand by a stray dog 2 days ago. He has no past medical history, takes no prescription medications, and denies alcohol use or smoking. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination reveals 2 clean puncture wounds with localized cellulitis, capillary refill of 2 seconds, and intact sensorimotor function in the hand. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

43d2f1d1-9e45-4f2b-84de-3cf79e183fde.question: A 3-year-old refugee child with a history of displacement and inadequate nutrition presents with increasing pitting edema, abdominal swelling, ascites, hepatomegaly, irritability, drowsiness, and multiple missing teeth over the past 2 months. What is the most likely diagnosis to explain these clinical findings?

1eb15af8-c184-4c08-9d9f-1e5ab2a77c5f.question: A 2-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician by his parents for a routine visit. Since his 18-month checkup, his parents have expressed concerns about delayed speech development, noting his vocabulary remains limited to fewer than 10 words and he uses only single words to communicate. Motor milestones are reportedly unaffected, as he is physically active and can run and kick a ball. The parents describe hyperactivity and difficulty redirecting his behavior. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical exam reveals an abnormally long and narrow facial structure. The patient is referred to a geneticist for suspected trinucleotide repeat disorder. What is the most likely inheritance pattern of this disorder?

d410fb3a-1d46-42f5-8185-23709517e31a.question: A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his mother due to personality changes over the past 7 months, including social withdrawal, avoidance of family and friends, and a belief that aliens are monitoring him and "stealing his thoughts." He reports no alcohol use and discontinued marijuana use one year prior. Vital signs and physical examination are unremarkable. Mental status examination reveals disorganized thought processes, anxiety, and flat affect. What is the most likely diagnosis?

7330181e-d52a-4c95-8c29-0326ad2a43f8.question: A 37-year-old woman with a history of systemic lupus erythematosus presents with progressive bilateral leg swelling over 6 weeks, difficulty walking, and pitting edema to the knees. Her medications include ibuprofen and hydroxychloroquine. Vital signs show elevated blood pressure (153/86 mmHg), and urinalysis reveals proteinuria. After starting an immunosuppressant, she develops hematuria with cystoscopic findings of diffuse bladder mucosal oozing and neovascularization. What medication could have prevented the development of hematuria in this patient following the initiation of immunosuppressant therapy?

46f03df5-e61d-4656-85ac-ab1f9991f4c5.question: A 38-year-old woman presents to the office for a routine examination. She has no complaints and offers very little information voluntarily, answering questions with soft, short sentences while avoiding eye contact. She appears timid and anxious, admitting she rarely leaves the house and has avoided social gatherings for years despite desiring a relationship. She works remotely as a web graphic designer and has minimal social interactions. Her medical history includes essential hypertension managed with hydrochlorothiazide and a daily vitamin. Vital signs and physical examination are unremarkable. What is the most likely psychiatric diagnosis consistent with this patient's behavior?

842a11d4-4239-4ba8-a465-542162f7adf1.question: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room by his mother after she found him somnolent at home next to multiple open pill bottles containing aspirin, metoprolol, acetaminophen, levothyroxine, and lorazepam. The boy is lethargic but responsive, with vomiting, ear-grasping behavior, and ataxia when attempting to walk. His vital signs include a temperature of 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure of 110/65 mmHg, pulse of 85/min, and respirations of 28/min. Based on the clinical presentation and potential toxic ingestions, what arterial blood gas findings are most likely present in this patient?
842a11d4-4239-4ba8-a465-542162f7adf1.correct_answer: pH 7.36, PCO2 22 mmHg, and HCO3- 16 mEq/L

f47a89ab-fad2-4ee6-bed8-64df7a49b6f5.question: A 38-year-old man presents with progressive tiredness and shortness of breath on exertion. His past medical history includes peptic ulcer disease diagnosed 2 years ago, with poor medication compliance. He has a 10-pack-year smoking history and occasional alcohol use. Vital signs are temperature 37.1°C (98.7°F), blood pressure 142/91 mm Hg, and pulse 98/min. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory findings reveal hemoglobin 9.7 g/dL, hematocrit 29.1%, red cell count 3.7 million/mm³, MCV 71 μm³, MCH 21.3 pg/cell, MCHC 28.4 Hb/cell, reticulocyte count 0.2%, RDW 17.8%, WBC 8100/mm³, platelets 420,000/mm³, TIBC 620 μg/dL, and transferrin saturation 9%. What bone marrow biopsy finding is most likely present in this patient?

2fe7b76c-0b69-46e8-9cec-da1ac3c1674a.question: A 27-year-old G3P1010 presents to her gynecologist with profuse vaginal bleeding that began two days ago. She is 13 weeks pregnant by last menstrual period and reports dizziness, weakness, and inability to perform daily tasks. Initial light spotting progressed to heavy bleeding requiring six sanitary pads. Vital signs show blood pressure 90/60 mm Hg, pulse 125/min, temperature 37.8°C (100°F), and respiratory rate 14/min. Pelvic examination reveals blood in the vagina, an open cervical os, cervical motion tenderness, and adnexal tenderness. Ultrasound demonstrates an intrauterine gestational sac low in the uterine cavity without fetal movement or cardiac activity. Repeat ultrasound after rest shows slight downward migration of the gestational sac with unchanged fetal status. What is the next appropriate step in management?

c66b2279-1b3f-49a3-a143-89c72c48accd.question: An otherwise healthy 25-year-old woman presents with a 2-day history of pain and swelling in her right knee joint and left wrist. She reports camping with her new boyfriend 3 weeks ago but denies recalling any tick bites. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F). Examination reveals swelling, warmth, and tenderness on passive movement of the right knee, as well as a tender pustule on the sole of her left foot. Arthrocentesis of the right knee yields 8 mL of cloudy fluid with a leukocyte count of 45,000/mm³ (90% segmented neutrophils with intracellular organisms). What is the strongest risk factor for this patient's condition?

e914310d-6535-4baa-b459-4f29775740b8.question: A 54-year-old man comes to the clinic for management of his gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). He is currently on cimetidine for his condition and reports that his GERD initially improved. However, following his recent move to Michigan, he is experiencing more frequent episodes of chest pain (4-5 times a week). The pain is described as burning in quality and is concentrated around his epigastric region following food ingestion. It does not radiate anywhere and is alleviated when he takes antacids. A physical examination demonstrates a healthy male with unremarkable findings. He is subsequently prescribed a new medication for control of his symptoms. What is the most likely mechanism of action of this new medication?
e914310d-6535-4baa-b459-4f29775740b8.correct_answer: Irreversible inhibition of H+/K+-ATPase at parietal cells

99d8cfd0-52af-4bd4-b18e-8b20f5680a9a.question: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for evaluation of progressively worsening swelling around the eyes. He has no history of major medical illness. He had a sore throat and cough 2 weeks ago that resolved spontaneously. Physical examination shows moderate periorbital edema and 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities bilaterally. A kidney biopsy specimen shows effacement of the podocytes on electron microscopy. What urinalysis findings are most likely present in this patient?

a0cd497b-5126-4f93-ba2e-d711e69348b1.question: In a multicenter trial comparing initial imaging methods for suspected nephrolithiasis, ultrasonography groups showed lower cumulative radiation exposure than CT, with no significant differences in clinical outcomes. If the study’s conclusion was attributed to earlier detection of nephrolithiasis by point-of-care ultrasound influencing subsequent management, what type of bias would this scenario represent?

bb6aa743-2031-43be-8bc1-3cc9666302f9.question: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with intermittent chest pain, palpitations, dyspnea on exertion, and a 4.5-kg weight loss over 2 months despite normal appetite. She has no significant medical history. Cardiac examination reveals an irregularly irregular rhythm and a grade 3/6 low-pitched, rumbling mid-diastolic murmur best heard at the apex. Lung auscultation demonstrates diffuse wheezing and bilateral basilar rales. Transthoracic echocardiography shows a left-ventricular ejection fraction of 40% and a left atrial mass. What histopathological finding is most likely seen on biopsy of this mass?

65012028-fb24-4a5c-8249-27fc22620ac9.question: A 58-year-old woman presents with intermittent retrosternal dullness triggered by exertion or cold exposure, accompanied by shortness of breath and palpitations that resolve with rest. She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and uses crutches due to a below-knee amputation. Her ECG and cardiac markers are normal. What is the most appropriate diagnostic test to perform next?
65012028-fb24-4a5c-8249-27fc22620ac9.correct_answer: Myocardial perfusion scan under pharmacological stress

7820e9c0-de78-4322-9549-40611c33f6ff.question: A 24-year-old primigravida at 20 weeks gestation, previously treated with amoxicillin for asymptomatic bacteriuria two weeks ago, presents for follow-up. She remains asymptomatic with normal vital signs and physical examination. What is the most appropriate next step in her management?
7820e9c0-de78-4322-9549-40611c33f6ff.correct_answer: Urine culture should be performed in this patient again.

839319b4-7121-42b5-9e28-b71ca1966e3d.question: A 36-year-old G3P2 woman with no significant past medical history delivers a 3.7 kg (8 lb, 3 oz) baby boy following an uncomplicated pregnancy. On physical examination in the delivery room, the pediatrician notes that the baby has upslanting palpebral fissures, epicanthal folds, a flat facial profile, small ears, a single palmar crease, and hypotonia. When discussing the diagnosis with the parents, what congenital anomaly is this baby at an increased risk for?

89cd0ee2-04af-4c7e-91cc-53af7f6ee436.question: A 52-year-old woman presents with a 10-day history of diffuse, dull, moderate-intensity headache that worsens in the morning, accompanied by occasional nausea. She has no fever, photophobia, or phonophobia. Her blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg, pulse 60/min, and BMI is 33.5 kg/m². Neurological examination shows mild bilateral papilledema but normal extraocular movements. Brain MRI reveals a solitary hemorrhagic lesion in the left temporal region. What primary malignancy is most strongly associated with this type of brain lesion?

de36ccd0-c171-4b8e-9d78-55f92dd73c2b.question: A previously healthy 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of depressed mood and fatigue. During this time, she has had a 5-kg (11-lb) weight gain. She reports trouble concentrating at her job as a preschool teacher and has missed work several times in recent weeks due to generalized fatigue. She has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 10 years and is actively trying to quit smoking. A drug is prescribed that will treat the patient's mood disturbance and support smoking cessation. What potential side effect of this medication should the patient be counseled about?

2bda6949-3b89-415f-b1b6-ef8837794a4a.question: A 37-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician after returning from her honeymoon in Cancun. A few days ago, she began to notice an eruption of small red bumps that cover her torso, back, and buttocks. The patient first thought she had acne but became worried when the rash continued to itch. The patient denies other symptoms. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical exam is notable for red papules and pustules scattered across the trunk, abdomen, back, and buttocks, while sparing the limbs. Closer examination indicates inflammation of the hair follicles. Culture yields motile, gram-negative rods that are non-lactose fermenting and oxidase positive. What other characteristic finding is typically observed in the culture of the causative organism?

c0399a75-2281-4dbb-8ce7-4fb2c3217228.question: A 30-year-old female presents to her primary care provider complaining of 4 days of fever, malaise, dyspnea, productive cough, and recent-onset pleuritic chest pain. Her past medical history includes asthma managed with as-needed albuterol. She reports no smoking but social alcohol use. Family history includes cystic fibrosis in her paternal uncle and interstitial lung disease in her paternal grandfather. Vital signs show temperature 101°F (38.3°C), blood pressure 115/75 mmHg, pulse 110/min, and respirations 21/min. Physical examination reveals rales in the right lower lung, and chest radiograph demonstrates focal consolidation in the right lower lobe. During a study of immune responses to lung infections following treatment initiation, a serum protein with elevated levels is identified. A fluorescently labeled carboxy-terminal amino acid sequence of this protein binds strongly to a protein isolated from the patient’s neutrophils and macrophages in a gel assay. What immunological process normally occurs in immunocompetent individuals to enable this type of protein interaction?

a72a375f-a407-41d2-a9f0-938b93197ee7.question: A 27-year-old graduate student was bitten by a coral snake while hiking alone and died 2 hours later from respiratory failure. His body, discovered 7 hours post-mortem, was found cold and stiff by authorities. What physiological process is responsible for the rigidity observed in his muscles at the time of discovery?

fba623b6-7f21-4748-b080-d4c7dcf05592.question: A 28-year-old G1P0 woman at 12 weeks estimated gestational age presents with malaise, joint pain, fever, and chills for the past 3 days. Physical examination reveals a mild lace-like rash and arthritis. The patient mentions her friend, a medical student, suggested her symptoms may indicate parvovirus B19 infection, which could affect her baby. What is a potential adverse fetal outcome associated with parvovirus B19 infection during pregnancy, and what is its underlying mechanism?
fba623b6-7f21-4748-b080-d4c7dcf05592.correct_answer: It can lead to hydrops fetalis secondary to fetal anemia.

f4865244-501f-45ac-97f6-6bc9a49a0ff5.question: A 52-year-old man with hypertension and hyperlipidemia comes to the emergency department 30 minutes after the sudden onset of substernal chest pain while sitting in a chair at home. He reports drinking 2 glasses of whiskey earlier that day, after a stressful day at work. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. His pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 135/88 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows normal heart sounds. An ECG obtained on arrival shows ST-segment elevations in the anterior leads. Fifteen minutes later, the chest pain resolves, and a repeat ECG shows no abnormalities. What is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient’s chest pain?

d71e9bce-0807-42f5-ae34-e37afc708797.question: A 5-year-old boy with a history of asthma and multiple hospitalizations is brought to the emergency department due to sudden loss of consciousness. His mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus. He presents with somnolence and diaphoresis. Initial serum studies reveal a glucose concentration of 22 mg/dL and potassium of 2.4 mEq/L. Dextrose infusion normalizes his glucose and resolves symptoms, but he experiences another episode of decreased consciousness overnight. During this episode, serum studies show glucose of 19 mg/dL, insulin of 108 mIU/L (N=2.6–24.9), and C-peptide of 0.3 ng/mL (N=0.8–3.1). What is the most likely diagnosis?

4399d044-c824-4b7f-ac73-24ee2169ceda.question: A 66-year-old woman presents with urinary incontinence, difficulty urinating, incomplete voiding, and dull suprapubic pain. She has not urinated for two days, with urine leakage occurring day and night unrelated to exertion. Her history includes hypertension, poorly controlled type 2 diabetes for 8 years, and depression. Medications are amlodipine, valsartan, atorvastatin, metformin, and amitriptyline. Vital signs: BP 120/80 mmHg, HR 91/min, RR 13/min, temp 36.4°C. Physical exam reveals suprapubic tenderness, distended bladder, decreased Achilles reflexes, diminished fine touch and vibratory sensation, and posterior vaginal wall bulging. Ultrasound shows an overdistended bladder without structural abnormalities. What is the next step in managing this patient?

a90756f5-fbf0-4e38-b012-33a0b4b25ff7.question: A 69-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with hip and back pain that began suddenly while lifting a heavy object during a barbecue. He describes the pain as "electrical," localized to his buttocks with radiation down his leg. His medical history includes obesity, diabetes, depression, anxiety, diverticulosis, constipation, and prior ACL repair. Current medications are metformin, insulin, lisinopril, fluoxetine, and sodium docusate. What physical examination maneuver is most likely to help confirm the diagnosis?

fe1a1b81-d89b-489b-a10e-cdbda8f5bc11.question: A 61-year-old woman presents to an outpatient clinic with fatigue, mild neck pain, and difficulty swallowing for a month. She reports an unintentional weight loss of 5–10 pounds over several months. Physical examination reveals flat fingernails and mild conjunctival pallor. An upper barium esophagram demonstrates an upper esophageal web. Laboratory results show hemoglobin of 10 gm/dL, a normal white blood cell count with typical differential, and an ESR of 10 mm/hr. What is the most likely diagnosis?

8b745f7f-ceaa-4a1a-a847-e8cc9c946d68.question: A 65-year-old female patient comes to the physician’s office for her annual check-up. She reports progressively blurry vision over the past year and has a 20-year history of diabetes mellitus, along with osteoarthritis. Her current medications include metformin, glimepiride, and ibuprofen as needed. Fundoscopic examination demonstrates narrowing of retinal arteries and microaneurysms. These clinical findings are most likely caused by tissue-specific differences in the expression of which enzyme?

fdbbb8e9-7353-4ca1-9dc8-e3b92e575f4d.question: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of recurrent skin lesions that began at 2 months of age and have persisted despite multiple treatments. He has experienced several respiratory tract infections, recurrent fevers, and enlarged lymph nodes since birth. He attends daycare, and his older brother has asthma. His immunizations are up-to-date. Growth parameters are at the 5th percentile for length and 10th percentile for weight. Vital signs include a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F), pulse of 100/min, and blood pressure of 100/60 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals raised, erythematous lesions of varying sizes on the face, neck, groin, and extremities, some with purulent discharge, and bilateral enlargement of cervical and axillary lymph nodes. What is the most likely diagnosis?

662dbdb7-6476-4400-8daa-4a5ab3b9e22d.question: A 53-year-old man presents to clinic with a six-month history of shoulder pain that is especially bothersome at night. After straining his shoulder during a pick-up basketball game, he reports acute worsening of pain. On exam, there is tenderness to palpation just below the acromion. A supraspinatus tear is suspected. What specific functional maneuver would most likely demonstrate a deficit on physical examination in this patient?

0a907e23-14c9-4fd4-80d5-305c242adce1.question: A 58-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of left knee pain and morning stiffness lasting 10–15 minutes, worsened by prolonged standing and stair climbing. She has a history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and obesity (BMI 31.8 kg/m²). Physical examination reveals left knee tenderness, crepitus, and pain with flexion/extension. Serum uric acid is elevated at 8.0 mg/dL, and ESR is normal. What imaging findings are most likely to be observed in her left knee?
0a907e23-14c9-4fd4-80d5-305c242adce1.correct_answer: Osteophytes with joint-space narrowing on x-ray

dbfcfa71-18d6-4f16-8bd5-c1167bdc81c2.question: A 6-month-old boy presents to a pediatrician for evaluation of recurrent bacterial infections since birth. Physical examination reveals light-colored skin with silver-colored hair. Neutrophil studies show large cytoplasmic vacuoles, and genetic testing identifies a mutation in the LYST gene. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

e25389a0-0bc1-426c-adf3-bd4031fd26dd.question: A 48-year-old man with type II diabetes mellitus complicated by peripheral neuropathy presented to the emergency department with a foot wound, which led to a diagnosis of osteomyelitis requiring partial amputation of his right foot. After discharge on antibiotics, he returns one week later with difficulty breathing, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypoxemia, and a nontender erythematous foot stump. Vital signs include a temperature of 98°F (37°C), blood pressure of 100/70 mmHg, pulse of 130/min, respirations of 27/min, and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. An electrocardiogram shows sinus tachycardia. What is the next best step in managing this patient?
e25389a0-0bc1-426c-adf3-bd4031fd26dd.correct_answer: CT angiography of the chest and give oxygen

93efc639-bdce-4e23-bfd1-337aaac551ec.question: A 56-year-old man presents with a 1-day history of sudden severe pain in his right great toe. He reports a similar episode in his left knee four months ago that resolved with over-the-counter analgesics. His medical history includes hypertension managed with hydrochlorothiazide and nephrolithiasis. Physical examination reveals erythema, swelling, warmth, and tenderness of the right metatarsophalangeal joint with limited range of motion due to pain. Serum uric acid level is 12 mg/dL. Arthrocentesis yields cloudy synovial fluid with a leukocyte count of 18,500/mm³ (80% segmented neutrophils), and polarized light microscopy shows needle-shaped crystals. What is the mechanism of action of the most appropriate long-term pharmacotherapy for this patient's condition?

5ed6a3fc-851c-463e-844a-cbf13c5a3ca4.question: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe dyspnea, wheezing, and palpitations approximately 20 minutes after a bee sting on the left arm. His medical history includes hypertension treated with labetalol. During evaluation, he becomes obtunded. Vital signs show temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure 85/55 mm Hg, pulse 110/min, respiratory rate 31/min, and oxygen saturation 90% on room air. Physical examination reveals severe edema and erythema on the left forearm and marked facial/neck angioedema. After intubation, aggressive fluid resuscitation, and intramuscular epinephrine, his repeat blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg. What is the next best step in managing this patient?

29380bdc-f1a8-4869-ad16-6d0a39b989fb.question: A 74-year-old man with prostate cancer has been treated for 6 months with an experimental drug (Drug X) that reduces testosterone action by blocking the androgen receptor, resulting in slowed tumor growth. He reports excessive sweating and has bilateral enlargement of tissue around the nipples on physical examination. Drug X is excreted by the kidneys at his current dose. What is the name of a drug that belongs to the same pharmacological class as Drug X?

b47cfeb1-f535-4216-b98f-0f5196917478.question: A 74-year-old man with a history of alcoholism was admitted to the hospital after falling down several stairs. He received IV fluids and had a negative head CT scan. After an unremarkable work-up, he was scheduled for discharge but suddenly developed paralysis of the arms and legs, difficulty chewing, swallowing, moving his face, and speaking. Which electrolyte imbalance was most likely corrected too aggressively, resulting in these neurological manifestations?

c8d1b720-470e-4a1b-96ea-c7b6a28afa65.question: A previously healthy 67-year-old man comes to the physician for routine health maintenance evaluation. He works at a community center and volunteers at a local homeless shelter. A tuberculin skin test shows an induration of 14 mm. An x-ray of the chest is normal. Treatment with an antimycobacterial drug is initiated. Two months later, he has numbness and burning over both feet and an unsteady gait. Physical examination shows decreased sensation to light touch extending from the soles of the feet to the mid-shin bilaterally. What is the most likely cause of this patient’s current symptoms?

826df637-3c36-4ab7-83c7-2ae55a0b1507.question: A 64-year-old male presents to his primary care physician with a complaint of bilateral knee pain that has been present for the past several years but has worsened recently. He reports pain with climbing stairs and with extended walks of greater than 100 yards. The pain worsens with activity throughout the day and is alleviated by periods of rest. He states that he has minimal morning stiffness, lasting approximately 5-10 minutes after waking up most days. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation of the bony structures on the medial aspect of the bilateral knees as well as crepitus and a decreased range of motion, limited at the extremes of flexion and extension. Both knee joints are cool to touch and exhibit bony enlargement upon palpation of the medial joint line. What diagnostic studies, if any, are indicated for further work-up of this patient's presenting condition?

a9719b63-78a9-495c-91de-23acd90dc227.question: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of pallor and rash for 2 days. She had a 4-day history of diarrhea and vomiting that subsided two days ago. One month ago, she had a 3-day episode of high fever, followed by a rash with bright red discoloration over her cheeks for two days before subsiding without treatment. Her vaccinations are up-to-date. She appears pale and irritable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows petechiae on her trunk and extremities. Abdominal examination reveals diffuse tenderness with hyperactive bowel sounds. Laboratory studies demonstrate hemoglobin 8 g/dL, platelet count 49,000/mm³, schistocytes on peripheral blood smear, elevated lactate dehydrogenase (300 U/L), elevated serum urea nitrogen (42 mg/dL), and creatinine (1.4 mg/dL). Urinalysis shows blood and protein. What is the most likely underlying cause of these clinical and laboratory findings?

cb3ada37-b96b-40dd-9a38-cc7ecc11d64a.question: A 76-year-old man presents to the physician due to dyspepsia and weight loss over the past 6 months. Diagnostic workup including endoscopy and biopsy confirms gastric adenocarcinoma. The patient declines all life-prolonging treatments but requests palliative care with minimal financial burden. What is the most appropriate next step to determine his eligibility for hospice care?

62c7317e-d3d1-4adb-9388-2daf29e1027b.question: A 29-year-old female presents to the clinic for a regular check-up. She has no specific complaints. Vital signs include: blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, heart rate is 76/min, respiratory rate is 15/min, and temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F). Her physical examination is within normal limits. The woman’s complete blood count shows an absolute increase in a specific type of cell. What occurs when these cells migrate to peripheral tissues?
62c7317e-d3d1-4adb-9388-2daf29e1027b.correct_answer: These cells transform to macrophages when they migrate to peripheral tissues.

59484673-570d-4d32-9f37-407dc58ea484.question: A 23-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain. She reports pain in the right side of her abdomen that began yesterday and has been worsening, accompanied by several episodes of vomiting and diarrhea. Her past medical history includes constipation managed with fiber supplements. Vital signs show a temperature of 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure 110/68 mmHg, pulse 110/min, respirations 17/min, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals a young woman in apparent pain. The cardiopulmonary exam is normal, but the abdominal exam demonstrates right lower quadrant tenderness that is reproduced upon palpation of the left lower quadrant. After administering morphine for pain relief, what is the next appropriate step in management?

5d0ab5f3-1e6a-4e20-a5ff-ae1dc7d8ada8.question: A 24-year-old Asian woman is admitted to the hospital at 30 weeks gestation with nausea, vomiting, and right upper quadrant pain. She is gravida 2 para 0 with a history of the same complaints in her last pregnancy, which ended with a stillbirth at 31 weeks. Her older sister had preeclampsia in both pregnancies. Current assessment reveals lethargy, blood pressure of 150/90 mm Hg, jaundice, right upper quadrant tenderness, 2+ pitting edema, and elevated liver enzymes with hyperbilirubinemia. Based on her medical history, what factor is a significant risk factor for her current condition?

1d77f9d9-78a2-4469-9a0b-d940c3c85e79.question: A 44-year-old obese African-American male presents to clinic with complaints of 3 days of fatigue and dark urine. He has had several similar episodes since birth, all of which resolved spontaneously. He has a 5-year history of poorly controlled type II diabetes mellitus and was started on glipizide one week ago. Prior to the episode, he felt well without any upper respiratory or gastrointestinal symptoms. He predominantly eats fast food, although he tried a new Lebanese restaurant about one month ago. What is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

de3f9a1c-9952-470f-a4f8-e2658a3781f9.question: A 32-year-old woman presents with fatigue and joint pain lasting 4 months. Physical examination reveals erythema with scaling on both cheeks sparing the nasolabial folds and two 1-cm oral ulcers. What laboratory finding is most likely to be observed upon further evaluation of this patient?

bb05ad93-2329-41f6-8605-d6a6a8a9af1f.question: A 66-year-old male with a history of myocardial infarction presents to a primary care office with complaints of dyspnea on exertion and swollen feet and ankles. On examination, there is an elevated jugular venous pressure and 2+ pitting edema of the bilateral lower extremities. What is the most likely pathophysiological mechanism underlying this patient's lower extremity edema?

b6ce45d8-7455-4c5a-b1fa-f7f6f2b797d2.question: A 49-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well and has no history of serious illness. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years and drinks two to three glasses of wine weekly. Which condition should this patient be counseled about as having an increased risk based on his history?

dd2bf58a-d98f-4fa0-96bf-8f0da2b6aade.question: A 40-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of difficulty sleeping, fatigue, irregular menstrual cycles, unintentional weight gain, decreased libido, and increased facial and arm hair growth. Her vital signs show elevated blood pressure, and physical examination reveals central obesity, hirsutism, purple abdominal striae, a dorsocervical fat pad, and proximal muscle weakness. Laboratory results demonstrate hypernatremia, hypokalemia, hyperglycemia, and a low ACTH level. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

76a1088e-e4b1-48e9-a371-d5536a486893.question: A scientist observes a myocyte beating in cell culture. What process is the most directly necessary component of relaxation for this cell?

93702d45-3fbc-4647-bd30-96e9c6f823e6.question: A 35-year-old man with acute myelogenous leukemia develops nausea, vomiting, fatigue, and muscle cramps two days after hospital admission. His history includes diet-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus, smoking, and occasional marijuana use. Vital signs show a temperature of 38.7°C (101.1°F) and blood pressure of 110/65 mm Hg. Laboratory results reveal hyperkalemia (K⁺ 5.9 mEq/L), hyperphosphatemia (8.9 mg/dL), hypocalcemia (Ca²⁺ 6.8 mg/dL), elevated uric acid (11.2 mg/dL), and increased creatinine (2.2 mg/dL). What intervention would have been most effective in preventing this patient's current symptoms?

71e94a12-0ee6-4ba1-9094-bfdc52de16f7.question: A 23-year-old sexually active woman presents with a 4-week overdue menses and undergoes an ultrasound examination. The image reveals a structure marked by a green arrow. What is the primary function of this structure in early pregnancy?

471bba37-ad75-40aa-9f0d-d2f3a5724a20.question: A 49-year-old man presents with multiple falls and episodes of dizziness over the past 6 weeks. He reports daily consumption of one pint of rum and works in a factory producing industrial solvents. Physical examination reveals a wide-based gait, inability to stand with feet together without support, coarse hand tremor during purposeful movements, and impaired rapid alternating hand motions. Neurological assessment shows intact sensation, normal muscle strength/tone, and no mental status abnormalities. What is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's clinical presentation?

59ca90d1-3178-4907-ab14-5d9bd243be7d.question: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for a well-child examination. The mother reports that the child had her first menstrual period 1 week ago. She has no history of serious illness, and immunizations are up-to-date. Physical examination reveals Tanner stage 3 breast development and pubic hair. Without treatment, what condition is this patient at greatest risk for as an adult?

12c0c3db-61e7-420b-b4fe-2161394d8f29.question: A 67-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for a follow-up appointment. He was discharged from the hospital 1 week ago after management of an ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) but has not filled his prescriptions or attended scheduled follow-up. His medical history includes hypertension and peripheral vascular disease. Vital signs show a blood pressure of 167/118 mmHg, pulse of 90/min, and oxygen saturation of 99% on room air. Physical exam reveals jugular venous distention and bilateral lower extremity pitting edema. Echocardiography demonstrates an ejection fraction of 55%. Which medication will provide the greatest mortality benefit for this patient?

bc34f919-838e-4818-b355-b1ee3b3f0ddd.question: A 61-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of productive cough and worsening shortness of breath, along with frequent productive cough episodes over the past 3 years. He has a 30-year history of smoking 2 packs of cigarettes daily but quit 1 year ago. On examination, he appears distressed, with an oxygen saturation of 91% on room air, diffuse wheezes, and coarse crackles on chest auscultation. Chest x-ray reveals bilateral increased lung lucency and flattened diaphragms. What is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy for this patient?

058ae01e-8558-4757-bd9d-f4caf1963e52.question: An investigator is studying cellular regeneration of epithelial cells. She has obtained a tissue sample from a normal thyroid gland for histopathologic examination, which shows follicles lined by a single layer of cube-like cells with large central nuclei. Which part of the female reproductive tract is also lined by this type of epithelium?

05a60446-ac4a-4dbc-8f8b-c50e57acbe56.question: A 22-year-old woman presents for a routine health examination and requests smoking cessation advice. She reports smoking one pack of cigarettes daily for 7 years, with multiple unsuccessful quit attempts accompanied by severe nervousness and weight gain. Previous use of nicotine lozenges caused headaches and insomnia. Her medical history includes bulimia nervosa, and her physical/neurologic examinations are unremarkable. Considering her failed nicotine replacement therapy and comorbidities, what is the most appropriate next pharmacologic intervention for smoking cessation in this patient?

8f59d98b-cb7d-42e8-9199-22ab48562409.question: A 34-year-old man with newly diagnosed celiac disease confirmed by serology and duodenal biopsy presents with severe diarrhea and bloating persisting for 1 month. He has no significant medical history, takes no medications, and reports no recent travel. Following discharge with instructions for a strict gluten-free diet, what additional dietary modification should be temporarily implemented to manage his gastrointestinal symptoms?

84597f7d-c0c0-4fa1-afc5-6822eabc9af6.question: A 70-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department after 3 days of shortness of breath, orthopnea, and lower limb edema. His medical history includes a myocardial infarction 6 years ago requiring revascularization and hypertension. Current medications are simvastatin and lisinopril. In the ED, his vital signs are blood pressure 100/80 mm Hg, pulse 88/min, respiratory rate 28/min, and temperature 36.5°C (97.7°F). Physical examination reveals jugular vein distention, displaced point of maximal impulse, S4 gallop, holosystolic murmur, and 2+ pitting edema up to the mid-calf. He is treated with furosemide, carvedilol, and oxygen. After 6 hours, his blood pressure remains low, and serum creatinine is 1.9 mg/dL. Which diagnostic test is most useful to differentiate between prerenal and intrinsic kidney disease in this patient?

7eb0c3ea-2ef4-4ae8-8001-63d1be2780e7.question: A 26-year-old Caucasian woman is admitted to the emergency department after 4 days of fever, malaise, vomiting, and nausea for which she has been taking ibuprofen and diclofenac. She has also noticed a decrease in urination. Her family and past medical history are unremarkable. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.7°F), blood pressure is 118/76 mm Hg, heart rate is 74/min, and respiratory rate is 15/min. Upon physical examination, her mucous membranes are moist and she has no abdominal tenderness. Four hours after admission, she has a urinary output < 0.3 mL/kg/h, and laboratory tests are significant for elevated serum creatinine (1.9 mg/dL), blood urea nitrogen (25 mg/dL), hyperkalemia (5.4 mEq/L), and urine analysis showing WBC casts. Her eosinophil count is 0.9 x 10⁹/L. What skin manifestation would you also expect to find in this patient?

840d5504-84aa-41c1-a903-2c955919d621.question: A 59-year-old woman presents to the outpatient clinic for worsening symptoms of congestive heart failure. She reports that while she previously could tolerate short walks, she is now unable to do so. Even routine activities like getting ready in the morning have become exhausting, though resting alleviates her symptoms. Her blood pressure is 136/92 mm Hg, heart rate is 76/min, and physical examination reveals 1+ pitting edema in both lower extremities. Based on her symptoms and functional limitations, what is her New York Heart Association Functional Classification?
840d5504-84aa-41c1-a903-2c955919d621.correct_answer: New York Heart Association Class III

ff062fd1-b98f-42ff-b186-800366946f1d.question: A 36-year-old woman presents with intermittent stabbing bilateral facial pain triggered by touch or brushing her teeth, occurring in brief episodes. She reports a prior episode of right arm weakness lasting one week four months ago. Her family history includes migrainous headaches in close relatives. Physical examination reveals decreased sensation in the bilateral V2 and V3 dermatomes, left upper extremity weakness (3/5), and lower extremity spasticity with sustained clonus. What finding is most likely to be identified on further evaluation of this patient?

d018e786-d660-42e7-9d1d-69e87cebf0f5.question: A 23-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 28 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal examination. Her previous pregnancy was uncomplicated, resulting in the birth of a healthy boy. Her blood group is A, Rh-negative, and the father's blood group is B, Rh-positive. What is the most appropriate medication to administer at this time?

649433ee-36bc-463d-b339-cb86aa2efeca.question: A 61-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of excessive thirst, frequent urination, and partial visual loss in both eyes for 1 day. His family history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus in his mother and cousin. His weight is 112 kg, height 187 cm, blood pressure 150/90 mm Hg, heart rate 89/min, respiratory rate 14/min, and temperature 36.7℃. Physical examination reveals dry skin, a pustular rash over the shoulders and back, an accentuated second heart sound (S2) in the second intercostal space at the right sternal border, and distal loss of vibration sensitivity in both feet. Fundoscopic examination shows microaneurysms. HbA1c is 9%, and urinalysis demonstrates glucosuria (199 mg/dl) without ketones. Explain the pathophysiological mechanism responsible for the presence of glucose in this patient's urine despite the absence of ketones.
649433ee-36bc-463d-b339-cb86aa2efeca.correct_answer: Secondary active transporters fail to completely reabsorb glucose in the renal tubules

8732a9f3-93f4-469e-9625-7fdc1db5bc27.question: A 65-year-old male presents to his primary care physician with stiffness in his arm, reporting difficulty combing his hair and reaching high shelves. His medical history includes type II diabetes mellitus, obesity, and hypertension, managed with metformin, insulin, lisinopril, and hydrochlorothiazide. He leads a sedentary lifestyle without physical activity. Physical examination reveals decreased passive and active range of motion in the shoulder, with upper extremity strength graded 4/5. What is the most likely diagnosis?

ba0a2184-8d16-486c-bb5b-ff748c494c4e.question: A 52-year-old man presents to the clinic with a headache and dizziness for the past month. He reports that his symptoms began 4 weeks ago with a persistent headache unrelieved by ibuprofen, followed by dizziness and nausea that resolve when he goes outside. His medical history includes hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and asthma, managed with amlodipine, metformin, glimepiride, and a fluticasone/salmeterol inhaler. He has been living in his upstate cabin for the past 5 weeks, denies recent travel or substance use, and is asymptomatic during the office visit. Vital signs are within normal limits, with oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. Lab results show hemoglobin of 20 g/dL, hematocrit of 60%, and normal leukocyte and platelet counts. What is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s clinical presentation and laboratory findings?

e98d6dd0-7a52-4098-be93-ac7f43ac2a94.question: A 20-year-old woman with bipolar I disorder, recently stabilized on lithium after a manic episode and subsequent relapse due to medication non-compliance, presents for her first follow-up visit. She is now compliant with treatment and has no significant complaints. What recommendation would be most helpful in minimizing the risk to the fetus in this patient during pregnancy?
e98d6dd0-7a52-4098-be93-ac7f43ac2a94.correct_answer: Adjust dosage of medication throughout the pregnancy

90761e20-bda4-4c7f-99f2-420a04466be8.question: A 19-year-old female presents to the emergency room with 6 days of lower abdominal pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting following recent treatment with ciprofloxacin for a urinary tract infection. She reports irregular menstrual cycles with a last period 6 weeks ago, multiple sexual partners, and inconsistent use of barrier protection. Vital signs include a temperature of 100.5°C (38.1°F), blood pressure of 102/68 mmHg, and pulse of 97/min. Physical examination reveals suprapubic and right lower quadrant tenderness with voluntary guarding, purulent vaginal discharge, cervical motion tenderness, and a tender right adnexal mass. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
90761e20-bda4-4c7f-99f2-420a04466be8.correct_answer: Intravenous cefotetan and doxycycline with inpatient admission

c446e9f0-edae-40d3-a0e9-6a9c821cbe27.question: A 72-year-old man with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus is admitted to the hospital for evaluation of breathlessness and fatigue. His pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Further evaluation shows a systemic vascular resistance of 35 mm Hg × min/L with an end-systolic volume of 80 mL. What is the ejection fraction in this patient?

e542b061-3378-4a51-85e0-d07312e55277.question: A 24-year-old woman presents to the office for evaluation of intermittent vertigo for the past 2 days, accompanied by vomiting and complete hearing loss in her left ear. She reports a prior suspected untreated ear infection in the same ear. Her medical history includes uterine fibroids managed with daily mifepristone. Vital signs are stable. Physical examination reveals pallor, mild distress, a suppurative and erythematous bulging tympanic membrane with immobility on pneumatoscopy, right-beating nystagmus, and left-sided hearing loss across all frequencies on audiometry. MRI of the brain shows no tumor or abscess. Laboratory results include leukocytosis with neutrophilia. Based on this presentation, what is the most appropriate antibiotic choice for this patient?

a643163c-2afd-4b1f-8a71-3b0fc848dfa9.question: A 52-year-old woman presents to the emergency department due to severe pain in her first metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint, described as sharp and acute in onset. Her medical history includes obesity, hypertension, inflammatory bowel disease, and extensive alcohol use. Physical examination reveals a warm, swollen, erythematous, and exquisitely tender right first MTP joint. Following resolution of the acute episode, she is started on a medication to prevent recurrence. One month later, she develops pancytopenia. What is the mechanism of action of the most likely medication prescribed to this patient?

77186144-6562-4e77-adee-93ec63f44c56.question: A 59-year-old man complains of chest pain that has been present for 4 hours on the 5th day of hospitalization for acute myocardial infarction. Five days ago, he experienced a burning sensation in his chest and left shoulder discomfort. He was diagnosed with an ST-elevation myocardial infarction at initial presentation and treated with alteplase. He now reports recurrent chest and left shoulder discomfort similar to his initial symptoms. Vital signs include a pulse of 86/min, respiratory rate of 16/min, and blood pressure of 146/90 mm Hg. Chest auscultation is unremarkable, and the ECG is difficult to interpret. Which laboratory test result, if abnormal, would provide the most diagnostic utility in this clinical scenario?

a48ec739-5ca1-4f28-a41d-0b82bfb19206.question: A 16-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with left wrist pain and swelling for 5 hours after falling on an outstretched hand while playing basketball. She reports worsening pain and swelling despite using analgesic spray. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox, limited range of motion, decreased grip strength, and a negative Finkelstein's test. Initial wrist x-rays are normal. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
a48ec739-5ca1-4f28-a41d-0b82bfb19206.correct_answer: Thumb spica cast and repeat x-rays in 2 weeks

00ad26b0-43fa-448f-8529-241ac1fdb439.question: A 46-year-old man comes to the physician with a 1-week history of yellowish discoloration of his eyes, generalized fatigue, and pruritus. He was diagnosed with ulcerative colitis 7 years ago and had a positive pANCA test at the time of diagnosis. Physical examination reveals scleral icterus and multiple scratch marks on the trunk and extremities. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Serum studies show a total bilirubin concentration of 3.2 mg/dL, direct bilirubin concentration of 2.5 mg/dL, and alkaline phosphatase level of 450 U/L. Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography demonstrates focal areas of intrahepatic bile duct strictures alternating with dilation. What histologic finding is most likely to be observed in the liver biopsy specimen of this patient?

1828160f-f805-471b-beaf-192f3e1583c6.question: A 29-year-old woman presents to her primary care doctor with a lesion on her left labia. She first noticed the lesion 3 days ago. The patient describes the lesion as painful and swollen. She denies vaginal discharge. Her past medical history includes mild intermittent asthma, gout, and obesity. She uses an albuterol inhaler as needed and takes allopurinol. She reports 5 sexual partners in the past year and uses the pull-out method for contraception. She has a 10-pack-year smoking history and drinks 10-12 alcoholic beverages per week. On exam, she has an ulcerated, tender, and purulent ulcer on the left labia majora with mild unilateral painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. Which pathogen is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?

91f2dde5-d15a-4c26-b57f-d5c86a4ae068.question: A 67-year-old man presents with persistent feelings of nervousness, anxiety, and restlessness that have intensified over the last 2 months, occurring intermittently for the past year. He reports racing thoughts interfering with sleep, episodes of palpitations, light-headedness, near-syncope, and muscle tension in his back and neck. His history includes past cocaine and heroin use in early adulthood but no current smoking or alcohol consumption. Based on his symptoms and substance use history, what pharmacologic treatment is most appropriate for this patient?

98d87fc7-0bea-4113-8ec4-de89fe4e4fdb.question: A 48-year-old woman with systemic lupus erythematosus and hypertension, previously treated with nifedipine and prednisolone, develops dizziness, lethargy, abdominal pain, and nausea two hours after an open cholecystectomy for complicated cholecystitis. Her vital signs include a pulse of 112/min and blood pressure of 90/64 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals central obesity, a soft non-tender abdomen, and clean laparoscopic incisions. Laboratory tests show decreased serum cortisol and ACTH levels. Based on this presentation, what additional laboratory finding is most likely present?

d06e7235-0eeb-4e5f-9664-04b8834a3b9f.question: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 40 weeks of gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor.
