Vital signs are stable. On exam, a friction rub is detected. Laboratory results reveal a potassium level of 7.5 mEq/L and creatinine of 5.1 mg/dL. If these clinical and laboratory findings are indicative of a chronic condition, what would be the expected findings on urinary analysis?

ade06ddf-187b-42e5-beda-8c3b027f98fb.question: A 56-year-old man of Korean descent visits his primary care provider for an annual health check-up. His personal history is relevant for cigarette smoking and a sedentary lifestyle, and he has type-2 diabetes mellitus under control with oral medications. Physical examination reveals a blood pressure of 130/70 mm Hg, pulse of 72/min, respiratory rate of 18/min, temperature of 36.5°C (97.7°F), and an enlarged, nontender left supraclavicular node. In addition to fine needle aspiration or biopsy, what diagnostic test should be included in the further assessment of this patient?

5e216880-86c8-4439-bf6b-7bf3938edea2.question: A 46-year-old woman presents with a 5-month history of worsening dry cough, occasional shortness of breath, and fatigue, now experiencing difficulty walking a full block. She reports bilateral lower leg swelling for the past week but denies chest pain, fever, chills, syncope, or bloody sputum. Vital signs include a temperature of 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 63/min, blood pressure 128/91 mm Hg, and respiratory rate 15/min. Physical examination reveals elevated jugular venous pressure, decreased breath sounds bilaterally at the lung bases, and 1+ non-pitting edema in both lower extremities. Chest X-ray demonstrates a slightly enlarged cardiac silhouette. What is the most appropriate next diagnostic step for this patient?

ef3c009c-3e31-4f24-9c05-db82c5e192bf.question: A 67-year-old woman with depression presents with easy bruising, bleeding gums, and petechiae on the hard palate over the past 2 months. She appears thin with temporal wasting and has bruises on her lower legs and swollen gums. Her symptoms are attributed to defective synthesis of a particular substance. Which amino acid is primarily involved in the composition of this substance?

acca4d39-4e51-4aad-95f3-5e165df2ebd8.question: A 49-year-old female with a history of alcoholism was found unconscious on a park bench and brought to the emergency department. After regaining consciousness, she reported intense bilateral flank pain and a recent decrease in urination. Urine microscopy revealed abundant square calcium oxalate crystals resembling "folded envelopes." What acid-base disorder is most likely present in this patient?

f9a26900-3e04-47e6-995a-b0d63c73efe4.question: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up appointment three days after being prescribed a selective alpha-1 agonist. He reports improvement in his symptoms and has not experienced any adverse effects. For which condition was this medication most likely prescribed?
f9a26900-3e04-47e6-995a-b0d63c73efe4.correct_answer: Nasal congestion due to a viral infection

e63c5399-2616-434b-a47b-f7aef361dfcf.question: A 31-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with fever, right upper quadrant pain, and myalgia. Her boyfriend states she recently returned from a trip to Southeast Asia. She appears ill and is lethargic. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F). Physical examination reveals jaundice and tender hepatomegaly. Laboratory studies demonstrate the presence of anti-hepatitis A IgM antibodies. What histopathological findings would most likely be observed on a liver biopsy performed at this time?
e63c5399-2616-434b-a47b-f7aef361dfcf.correct_answer: Hepatocytes with shrunken, eosinophilic cytoplasm and pyknotic nuclei

7bb864c1-da66-4d3d-bba4-f83f3bdcd8ce.question: A 25-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for pain in his back. The patient describes the pain as feeling worse in the morning, with general stiffness that improves when he exercises or leans forward. He is a current smoker and reports unprotected sexual activity with multiple partners in the past year. Physical exam reveals thoracic kyphosis and reduced spinal mobility in all directions. What dermatologic finding is classically associated with this patient's clinical presentation?
7bb864c1-da66-4d3d-bba4-f83f3bdcd8ce.correct_answer: Punctate bleeding spots when dermatologic scales are removed

991ba13b-cb5a-4c42-8b89-fa928d8ab5b0.question: A 9-month-old boy is brought to his pediatrician for a routine health checkup. He was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery, is up to date on vaccines, and meets all developmental milestones. After being breastfed for the first 3 months, he was switched to cow’s milk, and solid foods (fruits and vegetables) were introduced two months ago. Vital signs are within normal limits, but he appears pale. Laboratory results reveal hemoglobin of 9.1 g/dL, MCV of 65 fL, TIBC of 550 μg/dL, serum iron of 45 µg/dL, and serum lead level <5 µg/dL. Based on this presentation and lab findings, what is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

59c7206d-81d6-4634-8df9-df3524c0a7ac.question: A 39-year-old woman with a history of thyroidectomy and primary hyperparathyroidism presents for surgical evaluation of a right adrenal mass. What preoperative medication should be administered to prevent a hypertensive emergency during surgery?

3756abc4-7af2-421e-beaf-d7be344b0ce3.question: A 58-year-old male with hypertension, managed with daily propranolol after failing other antihypertensive therapies, experiences a severe anaphylactic reaction following a wasp sting and is treated with epinephrine. Given his current medication regimen, what effect on heart rate would be expected after administration of epinephrine?

ffdb88aa-7b4b-4704-9a6a-1451da427d1a.question: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for short stature. Neither his clothing nor his shoe size have changed over the past year. He frequently bumps into obstacles, experiences headaches at night, reports excessive thirst for cold water, and has increased urination. Three years ago, he was treated for an asthma attack with albuterol and a one-week course of steroids. His mother has Hashimoto's thyroiditis and a history of precocious puberty. His parents' heights are 147 cm (mother) and 160 cm (father). He is at the 5th percentile for height and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals Tanner stage 1 genitals and pubic hair, absent axillary hair, and diminished patellar reflexes. Laboratory results show low thyroid-stimulating hormone (0.3 μU/mL), low-normal thyroxine (3.9 μg/dL), and low insulin-like growth factor 1 (24 ng/mL) with normal insulin-like growth factor binding protein 3. What is the most likely diagnosis?

a2e1a7c9-bed9-47f7-bcb5-ed9b23f80cb7.question: A 31-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 32 weeks' gestation presents to the emergency department for clear vaginal discharge that started roughly 26 hours ago. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. Her first child was born at term by vaginal delivery. She has no history of any serious illnesses. She does not drink alcohol or smoke cigarettes. Current medications include vitamin supplements. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/82 mm Hg. Speculum examination demonstrates clear fluid at the cervical os. The fetal heart rate is reactive at 160/min with no decelerations. Tocometry shows uterine contractions. Nitrazine testing is positive. She is started on indomethacin. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
a2e1a7c9-bed9-47f7-bcb5-ed9b23f80cb7.correct_answer: Administer betamethasone, ampicillin, and proceed with cesarean section

db4cc5c2-25c1-402e-953a-193ef51c53a9.question: A 63-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 4-day history of lower abdominal pain, fever, and nausea, along with a history of constipation. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), and abdominal examination reveals left lower quadrant tenderness without guarding or rebound. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 19,000/mm³. A CT scan demonstrates segmental wall thickening of the descending colon with multiple diverticula and a 5.0-cm pelvic lesion containing air-fluid levels. After CT-guided drainage of 250 mL of yellow-greenish fluid from the lesion, which substance is most likely responsible for the formation of this fluid collection?

7a62b3ea-855b-4d08-bfe3-50dd3aab0042.question: What is the null hypothesis for a study investigating whether elderly patients with diabetes (defined as fasting serum glucose ≥126 mg/dL on two separate readings) have an increased risk of developing open-angle glaucoma over time compared to those without diabetes?
7a62b3ea-855b-4d08-bfe3-50dd3aab0042.correct_answer: The future risk of open-angle glaucoma is the same in patients with and those without diabetes

a46ca23a-a72c-4885-83f7-d24d44e3f1e4.question: Given the original research abstract above, what would be the implication of a type 1 error in the authors' findings regarding the efficacy of mepolizumab in reducing asthma exacerbations?
a46ca23a-a72c-4885-83f7-d24d44e3f1e4.correct_answer: A type 1 error occurs when the null hypothesis is true but is rejected in error.

03ee967f-b3e5-4073-8bc0-09a04839ab1f.question: A 30-year-old Japanese woman is brought to the emergency department after fainting at work. She reports being unconscious momentarily with rapid recovery, along with increasing fatigue and joint pain over the past 4 months. Her blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg, and her temperature is 36.6°C (98.0°F). Physical examination reveals absent radial pulse at the right wrist and 1+ radial pulse at the left wrist. Laboratory results include hemoglobin 10.9 g/dL, hematocrit 34.7%, leukocyte count 5,500/mm³, erythrocyte sedimentation rate 56 mm/h, and normal platelet count. Based on this presentation, what complication is this patient at risk for?

ca428207-1fce-49f9-9494-0999157f0078.question: A 25-year-old woman presents with acute onset of painful left labial swelling noticed the same morning, accompanied by discomfort while sitting and walking. She reports recent dyspareunia and is sexually active with her boyfriend. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), and pelvic examination reveals a tender, erythematous, edematous left labial mass. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

f2db04f2-d3be-4397-b4d8-22e7750235b5.question: A 21-year-old female presents to the clinic requesting prenatal counseling. She was born with a disease that has led her to have recurrent upper respiratory infections throughout her life requiring antibiotic prophylaxis and chest physiotherapy as well as pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy. She marries a man (without this disease phenotype) from a population where the prevalence of this disease is 1/100. What is the probability that their child will inherit the disease?

bf0ba735-ab75-4a93-955b-367009c4ee60.question: A 45-year-old woman presents to the physician with a history of headache, palpitations, and episodic diaphoresis. She was diagnosed with hypertension in the past and is now regularly taking antihypertensive medication (amlodipine 10 mg once daily). She has had a diffuse thyroid swelling for the past 4 months and complains of pain in the long bones of her arms and legs for the past 3 months. She is slightly built, appears thin, and is anxious and apprehensive. Her skin is moist and warm. Her weight is 45 kg (99.2 lb) and height is 146 cm (4 ft 7 in); BMI is 21.12 kg/m². Her pulse is 116/min, blood pressure is 196/102 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 29/min, and temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F). Diffuse and firm thyromegaly is present. Her upper extremities exhibit fine tremors during an anxiety attack. Laboratory tests reveal elevated 24-hour urinary VMA and metanephrines, as well as elevated serum epinephrine, calcitonin, and parathormone levels. Hypercalcemia and hyperglycemia are also noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?

f74f1a77-6b3d-430a-8b85-5ce5d4cb1490.question: A 57-year-old man presents with a 1-year history of progressive exertional dyspnea and a cough initially nonproductive but now producing small amounts of grayish-white phlegm. He has no fever or chest pain. He worked in a shipyard for 22 years and smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 13 years (quit 25 years ago). Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical exam reveals fine expiratory crackles at both lung bases. Chest x-ray demonstrates bilateral patchy infiltrates and supradiaphragmatic pleural thickening. What is the most likely finding upon further evaluation of this patient’s respiratory function?

f9e3a997-da17-4e70-8f15-ee90f30013b1.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with sudden-onset dyspnea. Her past medical history includes varicose veins in her lower extremities, well-controlled diabetes mellitus type 2, and a 25 pack-year smoking history. She takes metformin and pioglitazone. Her family history is significant for a sister who died at age 35 from a pulmonary embolism. Vital signs show a temperature of 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse of 111/min, respirations of 18/min, and blood pressure of 130/60 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals pallor, diaphoresis, an S3 gallop on cardiac auscultation, and erythema with swelling over varicose veins in her left leg. Ultrasound confirms a deep vein thrombosis. Despite anticoagulation with a vitamin K inhibitor, she dies shortly after admission. What hereditary deficiency is the most likely underlying etiology of this patient’s condition?

d8761a0f-d971-4efd-8dbf-aa47bcd2d98f.question: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother with increasing swelling of his right jaw over the past 2 months. He has been treated with multiple antibiotics without improvement. He has no recent fever, chills, or night sweats, and no significant medical history. The family recently emigrated from Nigeria. Vital signs show a temperature of 37.8℃ (100.0℉). Physical examination reveals an 8 × 8 cm firm, immobile, tender mass over the right mandible with erythematous overlying skin, mandibular distortion, and disrupted ipsilateral lower teeth and oral mucosa. Biopsy and histopathologic analysis are performed. Which microorganism is most likely associated with this patient’s condition?

5d818d6b-5360-4344-a848-f875154bd07b.question: A 3-year-old male was brought to the pediatrician with severe lip lacerations, a partially bitten-off tongue, and missing portions of the fingers on his right hand. Family history reveals two similar cases in male cousins on the maternal side. Urinalysis shows elevated uric acid levels. What is the most likely mode of inheritance for this disorder?

0b5991f7-2990-42f3-a011-fb86c461227f.question: An asymptomatic 65-year-old woman with a T-score of -2.6 SD on routine bone mineral density screening has a 10-year history of hypertension and esophageal stricture due to severe GERD. Her medical history includes endometrial hyperplasia treated with medroxyprogesterone 20 years ago, menarche at age 11, menopause 8 years ago, and a family history of maternal breast cancer at age 45. Current medications are lansoprazole and hydrochlorothiazide. She is started on a medication to prevent bone resorption and reduce breast cancer risk. What adverse effect is this patient at increased risk of developing due to this treatment?

47d57475-c022-4179-8157-4f522b6afa26.question: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 20 weeks' gestation comes to the physician with her husband for a prenatal visit. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. They are planning to travel to Ethiopia next month to visit the husband's family. Medications include folic acid and an iron supplement. Vital signs are within the normal range. Abdominal examination shows a uterus consistent with a 20-week gestation. What is the most suitable drug for pre-exposure prophylaxis against malaria in this patient?

f1109f8d-b548-4b05-a5cf-6b63331d27a0.question: A 26-year-old man presents to the office complaining of persistent epigastric pain for the past 2 months, which worsens a few hours after eating. He reports a family history of similar symptoms. His past medical history is unremarkable, and he denies smoking or alcohol use. Vital signs include blood pressure 120/90 mm Hg, heart rate 83/min, and temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F). Physical examination reveals mild epigastric tenderness. Lab results show a serum calcium level of 13.2 mg/dL, with other metabolic panel values within normal limits. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy demonstrates multiple duodenal ulcers. What is the most likely diagnosis?

7083b6cb-ddb5-493e-a363-2ae98ca4ac22.question: A 16-year-old boy with type 1 diabetes mellitus has poorly controlled blood glucose levels due to poor adherence to his insulin regimen and difficulty gaining weight despite increased food intake. His BMI is 19 kg/m², and his vital signs are normal. His parents inquire about switching to exenatide, a once-weekly injectable medication. Why is exenatide not an appropriate treatment choice for this patient?
7083b6cb-ddb5-493e-a363-2ae98ca4ac22.correct_answer: Insulin production by the pancreas is insufficient for exenatide to be effective.

f7d5dca3-6895-4bab-8ce9-2d6fb9c70ee0.question: A 79-year-old woman presents with a 2-month history of non-productive cough, fatigue, 4.5-kg weight loss, and worsening exertional dyspnea. Her medical history includes congestive heart failure, hypertension, 47-pack-year smoking, and 50 years working in a textile factory. She traveled to India 3 months ago. Vital signs show tachypnea and borderline oxygen saturation. Physical exam reveals dullness and decreased breath sounds at the right lung base. Chest x-ray demonstrates nodular pleural lesions and a moderate right-sided effusion. Thoracentesis yields turbid fluid with elevated lactate dehydrogenase (248 U/L), low glucose (59 mg/dL), and protein (3.8 g/dL). Serum studies show LDH 227 U/L and protein 6.3 g/dL. What is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s pleural effusion?

7807fdbb-5ebe-403c-a550-6508067b10e0.question: A 25-year-old woman presents with irregular menstrual cycles since menarche, occurring at 30- to 90-day intervals, along with oily skin, severe facial acne, hirsutism on the upper lip and periareolar regions, and elevated serum levels of dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate, luteinizing hormone, and testosterone. Her urine pregnancy test is negative. Given these clinical and laboratory findings, what screening tests for comorbidities should be prioritized as the next diagnostic step?
7807fdbb-5ebe-403c-a550-6508067b10e0.correct_answer: Blood glucose and cholesterol level measurements

9e6c3830-685d-4613-8278-16bd1bc0a03b.question:
<think>
Okay, let me try to tackle this. The original question is a multiple-choice one about a patient's respiratory function test. The answer is 480 mL, which is supposed to represent the total volume of gas that doesn't participate in gas exchange. 

First, I need to understand what the question is really asking. The key here is identifying the parts of the respiratory system where gas exchange doesn't happen. From what I remember, gas exchange occurs in the alveoli. So areas like the conducting airways (trachea, bronchi, etc.) and any areas that are dead space (anatomical or physiological) don't participate.

Looking at the parameters given: there's upper airway volume (100 mL), conducting airway volume (125 mL). Also, the residual volume (RV) is 1000 mL. Wait, but RV is the air left in the lungs after maximal expiration. However, RV includes some alveolar volume as well, right? So maybe the question is combining anatomical dead space (conducting airways) plus alveolar dead space. But how?

Maybe they're including something else. Oh, maybe the FRC? Wait, FRC is functional residual capacity, which is the volume remaining after normal expiration. But FRC includes the residual volume plus expiratory reserve volume. Wait, no, FRC = ERV + RV. But the patient's FRC is 2700 mL, RV is 1000 mL. So ERV would be 1700 mL. But how does that tie in?

Wait, the question is about gas not participating in gas exchange. Anatomical dead space is the volume of the conducting airways where no gas exchange occurs. That's upper airway (100 mL) plus conducting airway (125 mL) = 225 mL. But maybe there's also alveolar dead space, which are alveoli that are ventilated but not perfused, so they don't participate in gas exchange. But how to calculate that?

Alternatively, maybe the question is referring to the physiological dead space, which is anatomical plus alveolar dead space. But how would that be calculated? Physiological dead space is calculated using the Bohr equation: VD/VT = (PaCO2 - PECO2)/PaCO2. The given values are PiCO2=1, PaCO2=50, PeCO2=20. Wait, but Bohr equation uses PaCO2 and mixed expired CO2. So VD = (PaCO2 - PECO2)/PaCO2 * VT. But we don't have VT (tidal volume) here. The answer given is 480 mL. Maybe they're combining anatomical dead space (225 mL) with some other volume. But how?

Wait, the answer is 480, which is 225 (upper and conducting) plus... Hmm, maybe the residual volume? But RV is 1000, which is part of FRC. But RV is in the lungs, but if some alveoli are not perfused, part of RV would be dead space. But without information on perfusion, maybe the question is just asking for anatomical dead space plus the alveolar dead space. But how to get 480?

Alternatively, maybe they're considering the FRC. Wait, FRC is 2700 mL. But FRC is the volume in the lungs after a normal expiration, which includes the residual volume. But if part of the FRC is in the conducting airways, which don't participate in gas exchange. Wait, conducting airways are part of the dead space. But the anatomical dead space is upper airway (100) + conducting (125) = 225 mL. But that's only the conducting part. 2811cf55-5175-4823-9a3e-129e8b558d36.question: A 44-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of fatigue, intermittent fever, 4.0-kg weight loss, and a progressive non-productive cough. She does not smoke. Physical examination reveals mild wheezing over bilateral lung fields and enlarged supraclavicular and cervical lymph nodes. Chest CT scan findings are consistent with granulomatous involvement, and a cervical lymph node biopsy demonstrates organized epithelioid histiocytes and multinucleated giant cells without focal necrosis. What drug should be included in the initial treatment of this patient's condition?

d9d62df4-c123-44e6-a0ca-10d727c73ff4.question: A 55-year-old nulligravid woman presents with a 3-day history of heavy vaginal bleeding post-menopause, requiring more than 5 pads daily. She has a history of hypothyroidism, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and a 20-pack-year smoking history (quit 5 years ago). Menarche occurred at age 10, and menopause 1 year ago. Medications include levothyroxine and metformin. Physical exam reveals mild vaginal atrophy and a nontender uterus. Transvaginal ultrasound shows an endometrial thickness of 6 mm, and biopsy demonstrates non-invasive endometrial gland proliferation without nuclear atypia. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

df921556-78e3-46c4-9f90-69d46d781c2c.question: A 37-year-old woman with HIV infection presents for follow-up after six months of combined antiretroviral therapy with dolutegravir, tenofovir, and emtricitabine. Laboratory studies reveal a decreased CD4 count and increased viral load despite adherence. She is switched to a new regimen containing a drug that inhibits viral DNA synthesis without requiring intracellular phosphorylation. What is the most likely drug added to her treatment?

38c110f3-9055-4bd3-a48c-c2e4355f5cd7.question: A 14-year-old girl presents with sudden drooping of the right side of her face, drooling, and excessive tearing. Her mother reports recent outdoor activities in northern Maine. Physical examination reveals facial asymmetry, inability to whistle or close the right eye, a circular red rash with central clearing on the trunk, and decreased taste sensation. What organism most likely transmitted the causative agent of this patient’s illness?

37bb2ef6-00d7-49e0-97a3-4441e7cd1358.question: A 66-year-old man with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes presents to the clinic with elevated liver function tests from baseline. His current medications include simvastatin, metformin, fenofibrate, hydrochlorothiazide, aspirin, glyburide, and lisinopril. Which of these medications is most likely contributing to his transaminitis?

a74bb725-0f7b-4509-af6c-28a30ce0cf61.question: A 7-day-old newborn boy presents to the emergency department with a history of fever, irritability, and generalized erythema. After the parents attempted symptom control with acetaminophen during the first 2 days of illness, the newborn remained unwell, developing blisters around the buttocks, hands, and feet. Physical examination reveals a temperature of 39.0°C (102.3°F), heart rate of 130/min, respiratory rate of 45/min, diffuse blanching erythema, flaccid blisters with a positive Nikolsky’s sign, and intact ears, nose, and oral mucosa. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

f20a084f-2974-48d4-82a8-94e340c6de41.question: A 60-year-old woman presents to the outpatient clinic complaining of severe vulvar itching that has been gradually worsening for the past year. She mentions that she has tried over-the-counter lubricants without substantial relief. Her medical history includes diet-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. Menopause occurred at 52 years of age. She reports severe pain during vaginal intercourse, which has limited her sexual activity. Physical examination reveals dry, thin, white plaque-like lesions in the vulvar area, atrophy of the labia minora, retraction of the clitoris, and pale, wrinkled perianal skin. What is the most likely diagnosis?

017205bf-f150-4277-9093-25a7ecc49813.question: A 50-year-old woman with Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) presents to your clinic with complaints of left eye pain and reduced vision. She reports sudden left eye vision loss upon waking, following 3 days of progressive tenderness unrelieved by analgesics. Her medical history is otherwise unremarkable. Vital signs are normal. Examination reveals no light perception in the left eye and 20/30 visual acuity in the right eye. When a light is shone in the left eye, there is no pupillary response. What pupillary response would be expected when a light is shone in the right eye?

e60058b3-146c-45a1-a90e-e395b8655c74.question: A 25-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden, severe abdominal pain that began while walking up stairs at work, accompanied by nausea and vomiting. Her medical history is unremarkable, and she takes no medications. Vital signs include a temperature of 99.7°F (37.6°C), blood pressure 122/78 mmHg, pulse 120/min, respirations 17/min, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. Physical exam reveals left adnexal tenderness and a left adnexal mass without abdominal tenderness. Transvaginal ultrasound shows free fluid surrounding the ovary with edema and preserved doppler flow. A urinary pregnancy test is negative, and symptoms persist despite ibuprofen and acetaminophen. What is the best next step in management?

4a60fdf8-bb45-40dc-ba2d-6ccf63187590.question: A 65-year-old man presents with progressively worsening fatigue, shortness of breath, and palpitations on exertion over the past 6 months. He reports intermittent blood in his stools over the last 4 months. His medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus and end-stage renal disease, and he consumes two to four beers daily. Physical examination reveals pale conjunctivae and unremarkable abdominal and rectal findings. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin of 7.2 g/dL, hematocrit of 32%, and a mean corpuscular volume of 68 μm³. What is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s gastrointestinal bleeding?
4a60fdf8-bb45-40dc-ba2d-6ccf63187590.correct_answer: Arteriovenous malformation in the colonic wall

7484d7f3-86f1-4e66-9dc5-d1e2443b8074.question: A 24-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with her boyfriend 2 hours after an episode of loss of consciousness. She was seated and being tattooed on her right upper flank when she became diaphoretic, pale, and passed out. According to her boyfriend, the patient slipped to the floor and had jerky movements of her arms and legs for a few seconds. She regained consciousness within half a minute and was alert and fully oriented immediately. She has no history of serious illness but reports increased stress due to her work as an event manager. Vital signs and cardiopulmonary examination are normal, and neurologic evaluation shows no focal deficits. An ECG reveals an incomplete right bundle branch block. What is the most likely diagnosis?

289d2526-8662-4b6f-8af9-7aaa5d93d587.question: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after falling from his bicycle. He was racing with his cousin when he lost control and fell onto his right side, resulting in nausea and severe right shoulder pain. He is in acute distress with vital signs within normal limits. Examination reveals swelling, tenderness over the right clavicle, pain exacerbated by movement, and limited range of motion. The skin is intact, and neurovascular examination of the right upper limb is normal. A chest x-ray is obtained. What is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient’s shoulder injury?

fcdbabc8-5ee7-4a19-9ee8-2ebf07631393.question: A 51-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because of a 3-week history of abnormal behavior characterized by preoccupation with gambling and restlessness when attempts are made to restrict this activity. He was diagnosed with Parkinson disease four months ago, and treatment was initiated. What mechanism of action of the most likely prescribed medication explains this adverse effect?

207143f9-6383-4c6a-aa0f-2f071afd4887.question: A 55-year-old woman with no significant past medical history presents to her primary care doctor with fever, fatigue, and bleeding gums for the past 3 days. She denies any sick contacts. Her temperature is 101°F (38.3°C), blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, pulse is 96/min, and respirations are 15/min. Physical exam reveals several oral mucosal petechiae, bleeding gums, bilateral submandibular lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. Initial laboratory workup shows pancytopenia with a leukocyte count of 6,600/mm³ (60% segmented neutrophils, 20% bands, 9% eosinophils, 1% basophils, 0% lymphocytes, 10% monocytes), hemoglobin of 8.1 g/dL, hematocrit of 25%, and platelet count of 99,000/mm³. Coagulation studies reveal a prothrombin time of 25 sec, partial thromboplastin time of 50 sec, INR of 1.6, D-dimer of 2,000 µg/mL, and fibrinogen of 99 mg/dL. Bone marrow biopsy demonstrates 34% myeloblasts with Auer rods that are myeloperoxidase positive. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

199e1719-4264-44c4-b326-2750abef5db9.question: A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency room complaining of malaise. Two hours prior to presentation, he developed muscle cramps and nausea. He has had 3 episodes of non-bloody watery stools since his symptoms started. He reports recurrent similar episodes over the past 5 years since starting work as a reptilian caretaker at a zoo. His medical history is unremarkable, and he takes fish oil and a multivitamin daily. Vital signs include a temperature of 101°F (38.3°C). Physical exam reveals sensitivity to bright light, fatigue, but normal orientation. Stool culture identifies abundant non-lactose fermenting, oxidase-negative, H2S-producing gram-negative bacilli. What mechanism of action characterizes the virulence factor of the pathogen responsible for this patient’s condition?
199e1719-4264-44c4-b326-2750abef5db9.correct_answer: Blocking antibody attack on the O antigen

cb19dcb7-8b16-48a4-9c14-08a53b889e66.question: A 62-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife due to difficulties walking for the past year, multiple falls over the past 4 months, and progressive urinary urgency requiring adult diapers. Over the past 6 months, he has experienced decreased appetite and was persuaded to stop driving due to increasing inattentiveness. His medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension, managed with ramipril and metformin. Vital signs show a temperature of 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse of 90/min, and blood pressure of 132/88 mm Hg. Examination reveals a broad-based gait with slow, short steps. Neurologic assessment shows no focal deficits, but mental status testing indicates disorientation to time, impaired attention and concentration, and recall of only one of three objects after 5 minutes. What is the most appropriate therapy for this patient's symptoms?

41f485c1-f380-43b4-afb2-e026b1020afd.question: A 40-year-old woman with Down syndrome presents for evaluation of fatigue, progressive clumsiness in her hands, difficulty walking for 3 months, recurrent dizziness, double vision, and recent episodes of urinary incontinence. She reports no trauma or weight changes. Vital signs are normal. Mental status exam reveals orientation to person and place only. Physical examination demonstrates moderate weakness in all extremities, 3+ deep tendon reflexes bilaterally, bilateral Babinski signs, and intact sensory function. What is the most appropriate management step to address her symptoms?

7837a76e-0be0-4d32-919e-b1e5806b2d66.question: A 74-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus is brought to her primary care doctor by her son due to concerns about her ability to manage daily activities. She has lived alone since her husband died 2 years ago and recently stopped attending her retirement community's wine club meetings after 3 weeks of prior regular attendance. Her home has become increasingly disorganized over the past 2 weeks. She drives short distances but avoids longer trips due to occasional navigational difficulties. She reports worsening balance without falls and has experienced urinary urgency with 2 episodes of incontinence over the past 8 months. She denies feeling unwell but consumes 4-6 glasses of wine daily and was recently started on medications for anxiety by her psychiatrist. Vital signs include a temperature of 99.8°F (37.7°C), blood pressure 115/65 mmHg, pulse 95/min, and respirations 17/min. On examination, she is oriented to person and time but not place or situation, fails to recognize her long-time physician, exhibits intermittent somnolence, recalls 0/3 words after 5 minutes, and has a low-frequency right arm tremor that worsens with deliberate movement. What is the most likely diagnosis?

20e8ecca-3c3a-49b9-b8ac-0cb964bbcc77.question: A 45-year-old male with a history of diabetes and poorly controlled hypertension presents to his primary care physician for an annual check-up. He reports feeling well and has no complaints. His current medications include enalapril and metformin. Vital signs include a temperature of 98.8°F (37.1°C), blood pressure of 155/90 mmHg, pulse of 80/min, and respirations of 16/min. The physician adds another antihypertensive medication to his regimen. One month later, the patient returns complaining of new-onset lower extremity swelling. Which medication was most likely prescribed to this patient, and what adverse effect explains the development of edema?

4761a0e6-720f-4412-908f-2fb890656f33.question: A 29-year-old woman presents with high-grade fever, headache, and muscle pain. She recently returned from India, where she was involved in rural house-building with an NGO. Despite taking chloroquine prophylaxis before and during her trip, she developed symptoms. Vital signs include a temperature of 39.3°C, pulse 102/min, respirations 22/min, and blood pressure 112/78 mm Hg. Physical exam reveals jaundice, and laboratory findings show hemoglobin 10 g/dL, fragmented erythrocytes, and occasional ring-shaped inclusions in red blood cells. What is the most likely causative pathogen?

0afad577-17de-44f5-a2c1-2de4312e4ad1.question: A 39-year-old woman presents to the clinic for her annual physical. Although she feels generally healthy, she has noticed gaining about 9 kg (20 lb) over the last year despite eating a healthy, varied diet and exercising at the gym 4 days a week, including 20 minutes of aerobic exercise. She reports fatigue and constipation but denies shortness of breath, chest pain, lightheadedness, or blood in her stool. Vital signs include a pulse of 52/min, blood pressure of 110/72 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation of 99% on room air. Physical exam reveals slightly dry skin, and her complete blood count (CBC) is within normal limits. Which laboratory value is most likely elevated in this patient?

f6472238-2af7-43d7-859d-77d5fc6bcbf4.question: A 38-year-old woman presents with persistent diarrhea, fatigue, 12 watery stools daily, nocturnal bowel movements, abdominal bloating, cramps, and a 2-kg weight loss over the past month. She returned from Costa Rica 7 weeks ago and has a history of bronchial asthma and bulimia nervosa. Her medications include fish oil, a multivitamin, and a salbutamol inhaler. Vital signs show mild hypotension and dry mucous membranes. Laboratory results reveal hypokalemia (3.2 mEq/L), elevated bicarbonate (33 mEq/L), and colonoscopy findings of dark-colored mucosa with interspersed white spots. What is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?

7302a8f2-a69b-4f27-aacc-eafabdee4efe.question: A 21-year-old college student presents with a 2-month history of daytime fatigue, difficulty falling asleep at night despite going to bed between 11 p.m. and 1 a.m., and excessive daytime drowsiness upon waking at 8:30 a.m. He reports consuming 2–3 cups of coffee daily to combat fatigue, napping for over an hour in the afternoons, and skipping classes. He has tried over-the-counter melatonin and exercising at 8 p.m. without improvement, and he no longer uses his smartphone at night. Physical examination is unremarkable. What is the most appropriate behavioral recommendation to address his sleep difficulties?

d0c1dfa1-21da-44b1-b24f-d5d7255785a3.question: A 19-year-old man is brought to the physician by his mother due to concerns about his unusual behavior. Over the past 3 years, he has dressed entirely in black and worn a long black coat, even during summer. His mother notes he has always struggled socially, lacks friends, and spends most of his time isolated in his room playing online games. He experiences significant anxiety in college, avoids social interactions, and performs poorly academically. Instead of coursework, he focuses extensively on researching paranormal phenomena, particularly demons. He reports no direct visual hallucinations of demons but interprets phenomena like breezes in enclosed spaces as evidence of their presence. Mental status examination reveals labored speech and avoidance of eye contact. What is the most likely diagnosis?

84297953-bbd5-4214-a742-55dfda3f1605.question: A 79-year-old man presents to the office due to shortness of breath with moderate exertion and a slightly productive cough. He has a medical history of 25 years of heavy smoking. His vitals include: heart rate 89/min, respiratory rate 27/min, and blood pressure 120/90 mm Hg. The physical exam shows increased resonance to percussion, decreased breath sounds, and crackles at the lung base. Chest radiography shows signs of pulmonary hyperinflation. Spirometry reveals a forced expiratory volume in the first second (FEV1) of 48%, a forced vital capacity (FVC) of 85%, and an FEV1/FVC ratio of 56%. What is the most likely diagnosis?
